original: hatthehi vā gahetvā dīghavarattādīhi ākaḍḍhanayantaṃ. Cakkavaṭṭakanti arahaṭaghaṭiyantaṃ.🔽Cammakhaṇḍaṃ nāma tulāya vā karakaṭake vā yojetabbakaṃ cammabhājanaṃ. Pākaṭā hotīti
analyzed: hatthehi vā gahetvā dīgha vara tta ādīhi ākaḍḍhana yantam cakka vaṭṭa kanti arahaṭa ghaṭiyantam  cammakhaṇḍam nāma tulāya vā karakaṭake vā yojetabbakam camma bhājanam pākaṭā hoti iti
translated: Scales: scales for weighing, like those for weighing cotton. A balance is a device for weighing by means of a pair of pans suspended from a central beam, and it is used for weighing cattle, etc., by means of the hands. A pair of scales is a pair of pans suspended from a beam, and it is used for weighing by means of weights.🔽A piece of hide: a hide-vessel that can be used for weighing on a balance or a pair of scales. It is exposed: it is not covered.

original: aparikkhittā hoti. Udakapuñchanīti daṇḍamayāpi visāṇamayāpi dārumayāpi vaṭṭati, tassā
analyzed: a parikkhittā hoti udaka puñchanī iti daṇḍa mayā api visāṇa mayā api dāru mayā api vaṭṭati tassā
translated: A water-strainer: a strainer for straining water. It can be made of bamboo, horn, or wood.

original: asati coḷakenāpi udakaṃ paccuddharituṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: asati coḷakena api udakam paccuddharitum vaṭṭati
translated: If there is no strainer, it is allowable to strain the water with a cloth.

original: 263. Udakamātikanti udakassa āgamanamātikaṃ. Nillekhajantāgharaṃ nāma āviddhapakkhapāsakaṃ
analyzed: udaka mātikam ti udakassa āgamana mātikam nillekhajantāgharam nāma āviddha pakkha pāsakam
translated: A water-channel: a channel for the water to flow through. A roof-drain is a drain that is fixed on the roof of a house.

original: vuccati, gopānasīnaṃ upari maṇḍale pakkhapāsake ṭhapetvā katakūṭacchadanassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati gopānasīnam upari maṇḍale pakkha pāsake ṭhapetvā kata kūṭa chadanassa etam nāmam
translated: A roof-peak is a peak on the roof of a house.

original: Cātumāsaṃ nisīdanenāti nisīdanena cattāro māse na vippavasitabbanti attho.🔽264. Pupphābhikiṇṇesūti pupphehi santhatesu. Namatakaṃ nāma eḷakalomehi kataṃ avāyimaṃ
analyzed: cātumāsam nisīdanena ati nisīdanena cattāraḥ māse na vippavasitabbanti attho  puppha abhikiṇṇesu iti pupphehi santhatesu namatakam nāma eḷaka lomehi katam
translated: For four months with a sitting mat: the meaning is that one should not be without a sitting mat for four months.🔽Covered with flowers: strewn with flowers. A namataka is a blanket made of goat’s hair.

original: cammakhaṇḍaparihārena paribhuñjitabbaṃ. Āsittakūpadhānaṃ nāma tambalohena vā rajatena
analyzed: camma khaṇḍa parihārena paribhuñjitabbam āsittakūpadhānam nāma tamba lohena vā rajatena
translated: It should be used as a substitute for a piece of leather. A bag for carrying food is a bag made of copper or silver or lacquer.

original: vā katāya peḷāya etaṃ adhivacanaṃ, paṭikkhittattā pana dārumayāpi na vaṭṭati. Maḷorikāti
analyzed: vā katāya peḷāya etam adhivacanam paṭikkhitta ttā pana dāru mayā api na vaṭṭati maḷorikā ati
translated: But because it is prohibited, it is not allowable even if made of wood. A shoulder-cloak is what is meant.

original: daṇḍadhārako vuccati. Yaṭṭhiādhārakapaṇṇādhārakapacchikapiṭṭhānipi ettheva paviṭṭhāni.
analyzed: daṇḍa dhārakaḥ vuccati yaṭṭhi ādhāraka paṇṇa ādhāraka pacchika piṭṭhāni pi etthā iva paviṭṭhāni
translated: A staff-holder, a walking-stick holder, a leaf-holder, and a back-rest are included here too.

original: Ādhārakasaṅkhepagamanato hi paṭṭhāya chiddaṃ viddhampi aviddhampi vaṭṭatiyeva. Ekabhājaneti🔽ettha sace eko bhikkhu bhājanato phalaṃ vā pūvaṃ vā gahetvā gacchati, tasmiṃ apagate
analyzed: ādhāraka saṅkhepa gamanataḥ hi paṭṭhāya chiddam viddham pi a viddham pi vaṭṭatiyā iva eka bhājana iti  ettha sace ekaḥ bhikkhu bhājanataḥ phalam vā pūvam vā gahetvā gacchati tasmin apagate
translated: For, beginning with the carrying of a shoulder-cloak, a bag, a staff, a walking-stick, a leaf-holder, and a back-rest, it is allowable even if they have holes, whether or not they are stitched,🔽In the case of “in one bowl”: if one bhikkhu takes fruit or cake from the bowl and goes, then when he has gone it is allowable for the other to eat what is left.

original: itarassa sesakaṃ bhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati. Itarassāpi tasmiṃ khīṇe puna gahetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: itarassa sesakam bhuñjitum vaṭṭati itarassa api tasmin khīṇe puna gahetum vaṭṭati
translated: And when the other’s is finished it is allowable for him to take again.

original: 265. Aṭṭhahaṅgehīti ettha ekekenapi aṅgena samannāgatassa antosīmāya vā nissīmaṃ🔽gantvā nadīādīsu vā nikkujjituṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Evaṃ nikkujjite pana patte tassa gehe
analyzed: aṭṭhahaṅgehi iti ettha ekekena api aṅgena samannāgatassa antosīmāya vā nissīmam  gantvā nadī ādīsu vā nikkujjitum vaṭṭati yā iva evam nikkujjite pana patte tassa gehe
translated: 265.With eight factors: if he possesses even one of these factors, he may turn it face downwards either inside the monastery zone or outside it, or in a river, etc.

original: koci deyyadhammo na gahetabbo – “asukassa gehe bhikkhaṃ mā gaṇhitthā”ti aññesu vihāresupi🔽pesetabbaṃ. Ukkujjanakāle pana yāvatatiyaṃ yācāpetvā hatthapāsaṃ vijahāpetvā ñattidutiyakammena ukkujjitabbo.
analyzed: koci deyya dhammaḥ na gahetabbaḥ asukassa gehe bhikkham mā gaṇhittha ati aññesu vihāresu pi  pesetabbam ukkujjana kāle pana yāvatatiyam yācāpetvā hattha pāsam vijahāpetvā ñatti dutiya kammena ukkujjitabbaḥ
translated: But when the bowl has been turned face downwards in this way, no requisites at all are to be accepted in that house. He should be sent to other monasteries, saying, “Do not receive alms food in such-and-such a house.”🔽But when it is turned face upwards, it should be turned face upwards by means of a transaction consisting of a motion and one proclamation, after the consent of the one who turned it face downwards has been obtained and the hand has been passed over .

original: 268. Purakkhatvāti aggato katvā. Saṃharantūti saṃhariyantu. Celapaṭikanti celasantharaṃ.
analyzed: purakkhatvā ati aggataḥ katvā saṃharantu uti saṃhariyantu cela paṭikam ti cela santharam
translated: In front: placing him in front. Let them remove: let them take away. A spread of grass: a spread of grass.

original: So kira “sace ahaṃ puttaṃ lacchāmi, akkamissati me bhagavā celapaṭika”nti iminā ajjhāsayena
analyzed: so kira sace aham puttam lacchāmi akkamissati me bhagavā cela paṭikanti iminā ajjhāsayena
translated: It seems that he had spread it with the thought, “If I get a son, the Blessed One will step on the spread of grass.”

original: santhari, abhabbo cesa puttalābhāya; tasmā bhagavā na akkami. Yadi akkameyya, pacchā
analyzed: santhari abhabbo ca isa putta lābhāya tasmai bhagavā na akkami yadi akkameyya pacchā
translated: He was unable to get a son, so the Blessed One did not step on it. If he had stepped on it,

original: puttaṃ alabhanto “nāyaṃ sabbaññū”ti diṭṭhiṃ gaṇheyya. Idaṃ tāva bhagavato anakkamane
analyzed: puttam a labhantaḥ na ayam sabbaññū ti diṭṭhim gaṇheyya idam tāva bhagavataḥ an akkamane
translated: If he did not get a son, he might think that the Blessed One was not omniscient. This is the reason for the Blessed One’s not stepping.

original: kāraṇaṃ. Yasmā pana bhikkhūpi ye ajānantā akkameyyuṃ, te gihīnaṃ paribhūtā bhaveyyuṃ;
analyzed: kāraṇam yasmā pana bhikkhū upi ye a jānantāḥ akkameyyum te gihīnam paribhūtāḥ bhaveyyum
translated: But if ignorant bhikkhus were to step on them, householders might despise them,

original: tasmā bhikkhū paribhavato mocetuṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññapesi. Idaṃ sikkhāpadapaññāpane kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā bhikkhū paribhavataḥ mocetum sikkhāpadam paññapesi idam sikkhāpada paññāpane kāraṇam
translated: so the Blessed One laid down the training rule in order to protect the bhikkhus from being despised. This is the reason for laying down the training rule.

original: Maṅgalatthāya yāciyamānenāti apagatagabbhā vā hotu garugabbhā vā, evarūpesu ṭhānesu🔽maṅgalatthāya yāciyamānena akkamituṃ vaṭṭati. Dhotapādakaṃ nāma pādadhovanaṭṭhāne🔽dhotehi pādehi akkamanatthāya paccattharaṇaṃ atthataṃ hoti, taṃ akkamituṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: maṅgala atthāya yāciyamānena ati apagata gabbhā vā hotu garu gabbhā vā evarūpesu ṭhānesu  maṅgala atthāya yāciyamānena akkamitum vaṭṭati dhotapādakam nāma pāda dhovana ṭṭhāne  dhotehi pādehi akkamana tthāya paccattharaṇam atthatam hoti tam akkamitum vaṭṭati
translated: For a blessing: if a woman is not pregnant or is in her first month of pregnancy, it is allowable to step on her for the purpose of a blessing.🔽A foot-washing means a mat spread out for the purpose of stepping on it after washing the feet in a place for washing the feet.

original: 269. Katakaṃ nāma padumakaṇṇikākāraṃ pādaghaṃsanatthaṃ kaṇṭake uṭṭhāpetvā kataṃ.
analyzed: katakam nāma paduma kaṇṇikā ākāram pāda ghaṃsana attham kaṇṭake uṭṭhāpetvā katam
translated: A foot-wiping means a foot wiper made by raising up thorns in the shape of a lotus bud for the purpose of rubbing the feet.

original: Taṃ vaṭṭaṃ vā hotu caturassādibhedaṃ vā, bāhulikānuyogattā paṭikkhittameva, neva
analyzed: tam vaṭṭam vā hotu catur assa ādi bhedam vā bāhulika anuyoga ttā paṭikkhittam eva na iva
translated: A foot-wiping mat: whether it is round or square, it is prohibited because it is a form of indulgence.

original: paṭiggahetuṃ na paribhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati. Sakkharāti pāsāṇo vuccati; pāsāṇapheṇakopi🔽vaṭṭati. Vidhūpananti vījanī vuccati. Tālavaṇṭaṃ pana tālapaṇṇehi vā kataṃ hotu veḷudantavilīvehi
analyzed: paṭiggahetum na paribhuñjitum vaṭṭati pāsāṇaḥ vuccati pāsāṇa pheṇakaḥ api  vaṭṭati vidhūpananti vījanī vuccati tālavaṇṭam pana tālapaṇṇehi vā katam hotu veḷu danta vilīvehi
translated: It is not allowable to receive it or to use it. Gravel: a stone is what is meant. Gravel-water is allowable.🔽A fan: a winnowing fan is what is meant. But a fan made of palm leaves or of bamboo strips or of peacock’s tail feathers or of strips of hide is allowable.

original: vā morapiñchehi vā cammavikatīhi vā sabbaṃ vaṭṭati. Makasabījanī dantamayavisāṇamayadaṇḍakāpi🔽vaṭṭati, vākamayabījaniyā ketakapārohakuntālapaṇṇādimayāpi saṅgahitā.
analyzed: vā mora piñchehi vā camma vikatīhi vā sabbam vaṭṭati makasa bījanī danta maya visāṇa maya daṇḍakā api  vaṭṭati vāka maya bījaniyā ketaka pāroha kuntāla paṇṇa ādi mayā api saṅgahitā
translated: A toothpick-holder: a toothpick-holder made of ivory or of horn or of wood is allowable. A toothpick-holder made of bamboo is included in the word “or” .

original: 270. Gilānassa chattanti ettha yassa kāyaḍāho vā pittakopo vā hoti, cakkhu vā dubbalaṃ,
analyzed: gilānassa chattanti ettha yassa kāya ḍāhaḥ vā pitta kopaḥ vā hoti cakkhu vā dubbalam
translated: An umbrella for the sick: if anyone has a burning sensation in the body or an irritation of the bile or weak eyes,

original: añño vā koci ābādho vinā chattena uppajjati, tassa gāme vā araññe vā chattaṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: aññaḥ vā koci ābādhaḥ vinā chattena uppajjati tassa gāme vā araññe vā chattam vaṭṭati
translated: or if any other affliction arises that is relieved by an umbrella, then an umbrella is allowable for him both in the village and in the forest.

original: Vasse pana cīvaraguttatthaṃ vāḷamigacorabhayesu ca attaguttatthampi vaṭṭati. Ekapaṇṇacchattaṃ
analyzed: vasse pana cīvara guttattham vāḷa miga cora bhayesu ca atta guttattham pi vaṭṭati eka paṇṇacchattam
translated: But in the rainy season it is allowable for the purpose of protecting the robe, and in the case of danger from wild beasts and snakes, for the purpose of protecting oneself.

original: pana sabbattheva vaṭṭati.
analyzed: pana sabbattha iva vaṭṭati
translated: But a single-leaf umbrella is allowable in all cases.

original: Asissāti asi assa. Vijjotalatīti vijjotati. Daṇḍasammutinti ettha pamāṇayutto catuhatthoyeva
analyzed: asi assa ettha pamāṇa yuttaḥ
translated: Asissati: asis assa. Vijjotalati: vijjotati. Daṇḍasammutinti: here a staff of four cubits is meant, measured by the standard cubit.

original: daṇḍo sammannitvā dātabbo. Tato ūnātiritto vināpi sammutiyā sabbesaṃ vaṭṭati. Sikkā
analyzed: daṇḍaḥ sammannitvā dātabbaḥ tatas ūna atirittaḥ vinā api sammutiyā sabbesam vaṭṭati sikkā
translated: It should be given after agreement. If it is less than that, it is allowable for all without agreement. But training is

original: pana agilānassa na vaṭṭati, gilānassāpi sammannitvāva dātabbā.
analyzed: pana agilānassa na vaṭṭati gilānassa api sammannitvā ava dātabbā
translated: not allowable for one who is not sick. If he is sick, it should be given after agreement.

original: 273. Romanthakassāti ettha ṭhapetvā romanthakaṃ sesānaṃ āgataṃ uggāraṃ mukhe sandhāretvā gilantānaṃ āpatti. Sace pana asandhāritameva paragalaṃ gacchati, vaṭṭati.
analyzed: romanthakassa ati ettha ṭhapetvā romanthakam sesānam āgatam uggāram mukhe sandhāretvā gilantānam āpatti sace pana a sandhāritam eva para galam gacchati vaṭṭati
translated: Romanthakassā ti: here, except for a Romanthaka, there is an offence for those who come with a vomit which they hold in their mouths. But if it goes into another’s mouth without being held, it is allowable.

original: Yaṃ diyyamānanti yaṃ dāyakehi diyyamānaṃ paṭiggahitabhājanato bahi patitaṃ, taṃ bhikkhunā sāmaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjituṃ anujānāmīti attho. Idaṃ bhojanavagge vaṇṇitameva.
analyzed: yam diyyamānam iti yam dāyakehi diyyamānam paṭiggahita bhājanataḥ bahi patitam tam bhikkhunā sāmam gahetvā paribhuñjitum anujānāmi iti attho idam bhojana vagge vaṇṇitam eva
translated: Yaṃ diyyamānanti: the meaning is, I allow you to take with your own hand what has fallen outside the vessel which is being received by the donors and to consume it. This has been praised in the Feeding Section.

original: 274. Kuppaṃ karissāmīti saddaṃ karissāmi. Nakhādīhi nakhacchedane āpatti natthi,
analyzed: kuppam karissāmi iti saddam karissāmi nakha ādīhi nakha chedane āpatti natthi
translated: Kuppaṃ karissāmī ti: I will make a sound. There is no offence if he cuts his nails with his nails, etc.

original: anurakkhaṇatthaṃ pana nakhacchedanaṃ anuññātaṃ. Vīsatimaṭṭhanti vīsatipi nakhe likhitamaṭṭhe🔽kārāpenti. Malamattanti nakhato malamattaṃ apakaḍḍhituṃ anujānāmīti attho.
analyzed: anurakkhaṇa attham pana nakha chedanam anuññātam vīsatim aṭṭhanti vīsati pi nakhe likhitam aṭṭhe  nakhataḥ mala mattam apakaḍḍhitum anujānāmi iti
translated: But the paring of the nails is allowed for the sake of protection. The twentieth part of a fingernail: they had the nails pared down to the twentieth part of a fingernail. The amount of dirt on a nail: the meaning is, I allow you to remove the amount of dirt on a nail.

original: 275. Khurasipāṭikanti khurakosakaṃ. Massuṃ kappāpentīti kattariyā massuṃ chedāpenti.🔽Massuṃ vaḍḍhāpentīti massuṃ dīghaṃ kārenti. Golomikanti hanukamhi dīghaṃ katvā ṭhapitaṃ
analyzed: khura sipāṭikam ti khura kosakam massum kappāpenti iti kattariyāḥ massum chedāpenti  massum vaḍḍhāpenti iti massum dīgham kārenti golomikam hanukamhi dīgham katvā ṭhapitam
translated: A razor or a knife: a razor case. They had their hair cut: they had their hair cut with a razor.

original: eḷakamassu vuccati. Caturassakanti catukoṇaṃ. Parimukhanti ure lomasaṃharaṇaṃ. Aḍḍhadukanti🔽udare lomarājiṭṭhapanaṃ. Āpatti dukkaṭassāti massukappāpanādīsu sabbattha āpatti
analyzed: vuccati caturassakanti catukoṇam parimukhanti loma saṃharaṇam  udare lomarāji ṭhapanam āpatti dukkaṭassa ati massu kappa āpana ādīsu sabbattha āpatti
translated: They had their hair plaited: they made their hair long. A goad: long hair placed on the jaw is what is meant. A cross-bar: a square. A fringe: a collection of hair on the chest. A half-moon:🔽a line of hair on the stomach. An offense of wrong conduct: in the case of having hair cut, etc., in every case there is an offense of wrong conduct.

original: dukkaṭassa. Ābādhappaccayā sambādhe lomanti gaṇḍavaṇarudhiādiābādhappaccayā. Kattarikāyāti
analyzed: dukkaṭassa ābādha ppaccayā sambādhe gaṇḍa vaṇa rudhi ādi ābādha ppaccayā kattarikāya ati
translated: Because of a disease, in an enclosed place: because of a disease such as a boil, a rash, or blood-dysentery. With a razor:

original: gaṇḍavaṇarudhisīsarogābādhappaccayā. Sakkharādīhi nāsikālomaggāhāpane āpatti natthi.
analyzed: gaṇḍa vaṇa rudhi sīsa roga ābādha ppaccayā sakkhara ādīhi nāsikā loma gāhāpane āpatti natthi
translated: because of a disease such as a boil, a rash, blood-dysentery, or a head disease. There is no offense if one has the nose hair or the ear hair removed with a stone or something else.

original: Anurakkhaṇatthaṃ pana saṇḍāso anuññāto. Na bhikkhave palitaṃ gāhāpetabbanti ettha
analyzed: anurakkhaṇa attham pana saṇḍāsaḥ anuññātaḥ na bhikkhave palitam gāhāpetabbanti ettha
translated: But a belt was allowed for the sake of protection. ‘You should not, monks, wear a grey-coloured robe.’ Herein,

original: yaṃ bhamukāya vā nalāṭe vā dāṭhikāya vā uggantvā bībhacchaṃ ṭhitaṃ, tādisaṃ lomaṃ
analyzed: yam bhamukāya vā nalāṭe vā dāṭhikāya vā uggantvā bībhaccham ṭhitam tādisam lomam
translated: any hair that grows on the face or on the forehead or on the eyebrows,

original: palitaṃ vā apalitaṃ vā gāhāpetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: palitam vā a palitam vā gāhā petum vaṭṭati
translated: whether grey or not, is allowable to wear.

original: 277. Kaṃsapattharikāti kaṃsabhaṇḍavāṇijā. Bandhanamattanti vāsikattarayaṭṭhiādīnaṃ bandhanamattaṃ.🔽278. Na bhikkhave akāyabandhanenāti ettha abandhitvā nikkhamantena yattha sarati,🔽tattha bandhitabbaṃ. Āsanasālāya bandhissāmīti gantuṃ vaṭṭati. Saritvā yāva na bandhati,
analyzed: kaṃsapattharikā iti kaṃsa bhaṇḍa vāṇijāḥ bandhana mattam iti bandhana mattam  na bhikkhave a kāya bandhanena ati ettha a bandhitvā nikkhamantena yattha sarati  tattha bandhitabbam āsana sālāya bandhissāmi iti gantum vaṭṭati saritvā yāva na bandhati
translated: ‘A bronze-worker’s apprentice’: a bronze-worker’s assistant. ‘Just a binding’: just a binding with thread, a binding with a reed-stalk, etc.,

original: na tāva piṇḍāya caritabbaṃ. Kalābukaṃ nāma bahurajjukaṃ. Deḍḍubhakaṃ nāma udakasappasīsasadisaṃ.
analyzed: na tāva piṇḍāya caritabbam kalābukam nāma bahu rajjukam deḍḍubhakam nāma udaka sappa sīsa sadisam
translated: ‘You should not, monks, wear a non-bodily-adorned robe.’ Herein, one who goes out without having bound it should bind it wherever it breaks. It is allowable to go to the assembly hall thinking ‘I shall bind it there’. After binding it, he should not go on all-round alms round until he has untied it. ‘A Kalābu rope’ is a rope with many strands. ‘A Deḍḍu rope’ is like the head of a water-snake.

original: Murajaṃ nāma murajavaṭṭisaṇṭhānaṃ veṭhetvā kataṃ. Maddavīṇaṃ nāma pāmaṅgasaṇṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: murajam nāma muraja vaṭṭi saṇṭhānam veṭhetvā katam maddavīṇam nāma pāmaṅga saṇṭhānam
translated: ‘A Muraja rope’ is made by twisting together the fibres of the Muraja reed. ‘A Maddavīṇa rope’ is shaped like a bow-string.

original: Īdisañhi ekampi na vaṭṭati, pageva bahūni. Paṭṭikaṃ sūkarantakanti ettha pakativītā🔽vā macchakaṇṭakavāyimā vā paṭṭikā vaṭṭati, sesā kuñjaracchikādibhedā na vaṭṭanti.
analyzed: īdisam hi ekam pi na vaṭṭati pagā iva bahūni paṭṭikam ettha pakativītā  vā vā paṭṭikā vaṭṭati sesā kuñjara chikā ādi bhedāḥ na vaṭṭanti
translated: A paduka is a paduka for the feet.🔽A paduka for the feet is allowable if it is made of leather or of fish-bone or of bamboo-splinters. The rest, such as the kuñjara-csikā, are not allowable.🔽A paduka for the feet is shaped like a basket or a bag.

original: Sūkarantakaṃ nāma kuñjikākosakasaṇṭhānaṃ hoti. Ekarajjukaṃ pana muddikakāyabandhanañca
analyzed: sūkarantakam nāma kuñjikā kosaka saṇṭhānam hoti eka rajjukam pana muddika kāya bandhanam ca
translated: A single-stringed one and a body-bandage are in conformity with a paduka for the feet.

original: sūkarantakaṃ anulometi. Anujānāmi bhikkhave murajaṃ maddavīṇanti idaṃ dasāsuyeva
analyzed: sūkarantakam anulomā iti anujānāmi bhikkhave murajam maddavīṇanti idam
translated: The muraja and the maddavīṇa are allowed only in the ten countries.🔽The pāmaṅgada is not allowable in the four .

original: anuññātaṃ. Pāmaṅgadasā cettha catunnaṃ upari na vaṭṭati. Sobhaṇaṃ nāma veṭhetvā mukhavaṭṭisibbanaṃ.
analyzed: anuññātam pāmaṅgadasā ca ittha catunnam upari na vaṭṭati sobhaṇam nāma veṭhetvā mukhavaṭṭi sibbanam
translated: A sobhana is a mouth-wiping cloth.🔽A guṇa is a cloth for wiping the hands, shaped like a mudiṅga-drum. For when it is used in this way, the ends become hard.

original: Guṇakaṃ nāma mudiṅgasaṇṭhānena sibbanaṃ; evaṃ sibbitā hi antā thirā honti. Pavanantoti pāsanto vuccati.
analyzed: guṇakam nāma mudiṅga saṇṭhānena sibbanam evam sibbitāḥ hi antāḥ thirāḥ honti pavananto ti pāsantaḥ vuccati
translated: A pavananta is what is called a pāsana.

original: 280. Hatthisoṇḍakaṃ nāma nābhimūlato hatthisoṇḍasaṇṭhānaṃ olambakaṃ katvā nivatthaṃ
analyzed: hatthisoṇḍakam nāma nābhi mūlataḥ hatthi soṇḍa saṇṭhānam olambakam katvā nivattham
translated: A hatthisoṇḍaka is a cloth worn hanging down from the navel, shaped like an elephant’s trunk.

original: coḷikaitthīnaṃ nivāsanaṃ viya. Macchavāḷakaṃ nāma ekato dasantaṃ ekato pāsantaṃ olambetvā
analyzed: coḷika aitthīnam nivāsanam viya macchavāḷakam nāma ekatas dasantam ekatas pāsantam olambetvā
translated: like the nuns’ sarong. The fish-tail: one edge is sewn together and the other edge is left loose.

original: nivatthaṃ. Catukaṇṇakaṃ nāma upari dve, heṭṭhato dveti evaṃ cattāro kaṇṇe dassetvā🔽nivatthaṃ. Tālavaṇṭakaṃ nāma tālavaṇṭākārena sāṭakaṃ olambetvā nivāsanaṃ. Satavalikaṃ
analyzed: nivattham catukaṇṇakam nāma upari dve heṭṭhatas dve ti evam cattāraḥ kaṇṇe dassetvā  nivattham tālavaṇṭakam nāma tāla vaṇṭā ākārena sāṭakam olambetvā nivāsanam sata valikam
translated: The four-cornered: it is sewn so as to show four corners, two above and two below.🔽The palm-leaf: the sarong is sewn so as to hang down like a palm leaf. The many-striped:

original: nāma dīghasāṭakaṃ anekakkhattuṃ obhañjitvā ovaṭṭikaṃ karontena nivatthaṃ, vāmadakkhiṇapassesu
analyzed: nāma dīgha sāṭakam aneka khattum obhañjitvā ovaṭṭikam karontena nivattham vāma dakkhiṇa passesu
translated: a long sarong is repeatedly folded and sewn together to make a series of stripes. Or it is sewn so as to show stripes on the left and right sides.

original: vā nirantaraṃ valiyo dassetvā nivatthaṃ. Sace pana jāṇuto paṭṭhāya ekā vā dve vā🔽valiyo paññāyanti, vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vā nirantaram valiyaḥ dassetvā nivattham sace pana jāṇutaḥ paṭṭhāya ekā vā dve vā  valiyaḥ paññāyanti vaṭṭati
translated: But if one or two stripes are visible from the knees down, it is allowable.

original: Saṃvelliyaṃ nivāsentīti mallakammakārādayo viya kacchaṃ bandhitvā nivāsenti; evaṃ
analyzed: saṃvelliyam nivāsenti iti malla kammakāra ādayaḥ kaccham bandhitvā nivāsenti evam
translated: Wearing a sarong with a gathered edge: it is sewn so as to gather it up like a wrestler’s loin wrap.

original: nivāsetuṃ gilānassapi maggappaṭipannassapi na vaṭṭati. Yampi maggaṃ gacchantā ekaṃ
analyzed: nivāsetum gilānassa api magga ppaṭipannassa api na vaṭṭati yam pi maggam gacchantā ekam
translated: It is not allowable to wear it in this way, either if one is sick or if one is traveling. If, when traveling,🔽one folds the sarong in half lengthwise and then puts it on, and then when one sits down in the evening and in the morning one spreads it out and sleeps on it, that is allowable.

original: vā dve vā koṇe ukkhipitvā antaravāsakassa upari laggenti, anto vā ekaṃ kāsāvaṃ tathā🔽nivāsetvā bahi aparaṃ nivāsenti, sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati. Gilāno pana anto kāsāvassa ovaṭṭikaṃ
analyzed: vā dve vā koṇe ukkhipitvā antaravāsakassa upari laggenti antare vā ekam kāsāvam tathā  nivāsetvā bahi aparam nivāsenti sabbam na vaṭṭati gilānaḥ pana anto kāsāvassa ovaṭṭikam
translated: If he raises up one or two corners and lets them hang over the upper robe, or if he wears the inner robe inside out, or if he wears another inner robe over it, all this is not allowable. But if he is sick, he may show the hem of the inner robe and wear another one over it.

original: dassetvā aparaṃ upari nivāsetuṃ labhati. Agilānena dve nivāsentena saguṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: dassetvā aparam upari nivāsetum labhati a gilānena dve nivāsentena sa guṇam katvā
translated: If one who is not sick wears two inner robes, he should wear them after making a lining.

original: nivāsetabbāni. Iti yañca idha paṭikkhittaṃ, yañca sekhiyavaṇṇanāyaṃ; taṃ sabbaṃ vajjetvā
analyzed: nivāsetabbāni iti yat ca idha paṭikkhittam yat ca sekhiya vaṇṇanāyam tat sabbam vajjetvā
translated: So, omitting what is prohibited here and in the commentary on the training rule,

original: nibbikāraṃ timaṇḍalaṃ paṭicchādentena parimaṇḍalaṃ nivāsetabbaṃ. Yaṃkiñci vikāraṃ
analyzed: nibbikāram ti maṇḍalam paṭicchādentena parimaṇḍalam nivāsetabbam yaṃkiñci vikāram
translated: he should wear the lower robe evenly all round, covering the navel and the knees, concealing the three points.🔽If he makes any alteration, he is not released from his offense.

original: karonto dukkaṭā na muccati. Na bhikkhave gihipārutaṃ pārupitabbanti evaṃ paṭikkhittaṃ
analyzed: karontaḥ dukkaṭāḥ na muccati na bhikkhave gihi pārutam pārupitabbanti evam paṭikkhittam
translated: ‘Monks should not wear robes in the manner of householders.’

original: gihipārutaṃ apārupitvā, ubho kaṇṇe samaṃ katvā pārupanaṃ parimaṇḍalapārupanaṃ nāma, taṃ pārupitabbaṃ.
analyzed: gihi pārutam a pārupitvā ubho kaṇṇe samam katvā pārupanam parimaṇḍalapārupanam nāma tat pārupitabbam
translated: The wearing of the upper robe after making both corners even is called ‘wearing the upper robe evenly all round.’

original: Tattha yaṃkiñci setapaṭapārutaṃ paribbājakapārutaṃ ekasāṭakapārutaṃ soṇḍapārutaṃ
analyzed: tattha yaṃkiñci setapaṭa pārutam paribbājaka pārutam ekasāṭaka pārutam soṇḍa pārutam
translated: Herein, any wearing of the robe like a white cloth, like a wanderer’s robe, like a sarong, like a loin cloth,

original: antepurikapārutaṃ mahājeṭṭhakapārutaṃ kuṭipavesakapārutaṃ brāhmaṇapārutaṃ pāḷikārakapārutanti
analyzed: antepurika pārutam mahājeṭṭhaka pārutam kuṭipavesaka pārutam brāhmaṇa pārutam pāḷikāraka pārutam anti
translated: the antepura-wrap, the great-elder-wrap, the house-builder’s-wrap, the brahmin’s-wrap, the basket-wrap.

original: evamādi parimaṇḍalalakkhaṇato aññathā pārutaṃ, sabbametaṃ gihipārutaṃ nāma. Tasmā
analyzed: evamādi parimaṇḍala lakkhaṇato aññathā pārutam sabbam etam gihipārutam nāma tasmā
translated: This is called the lay-disciple’s wrap. Therefore

original: yathā setapaṭā aḍḍhapālakanigaṇṭhā pārupanti, yathā ca ekacce paribbājakā uraṃ vivaritvā🔽dvīsu aṃsakūṭesu pāvuraṇaṃ ṭhapenti, yathā ca ekasāṭakā manussā nivatthasāṭakassa🔽ekenantena piṭṭhiṃ pārupitvā ubho kaṇṇe ubhosu aṃsakūṭesu ṭhapenti, yathā ca surāsoṇḍādayo
analyzed: yathā seta paṭāḥ aḍḍha pālaka nigaṇṭhā pārupanti yathā ca ekacce paribbājakāḥ uram vivaritvā  dvīsu aṃsakūṭesu pāvuraṇam ṭhapenti yathā ca eka sāṭakāḥ manussāḥ nivattha sāṭakassa  ekena antena piṭṭhim pārupitvā ubho kaṇṇe ubhosu aṃsakūṭesu ṭhapenti yathā ca surā soṇḍa ādayaḥ
translated: the way the white-clothed lay disciples and the half-and-half sectarians wrap it, and the way some wanderers open out the chest🔽and put the wrap over the two shoulders, and the way people who have only one sarong wrap the back with one end of the sarong

original: sāṭakena gīvaṃ parikkhipantā ubho ante udare vā olambenti; piṭṭhiyaṃ vā khipanti,
analyzed: sāṭakena gīvam parikkhipantāḥ ubho ante udare vā olambenti piṭṭhiyam vā khipanti
translated: and put the two corners over the two shoulders, and the way those who drink liquor and so on wrap the neck with the sarong and let the two ends hang down on the belly or on the back,

original: yathā ca antepurikāyo akkhitārakamattaṃ dassetvā oguṇṭhikaṃ pārupanti, yathā ca mahājeṭṭhā
analyzed: yathā ca antepurikāyaḥ akkhi tāraka mattam dassetvā oguṇṭhikam pārupanti yathā ca mahājeṭṭhā
translated: and the way the women of the royal harem wrap it so as to show the pupils of the eyes, and the way the great elders

original: dīghasāṭakaṃ nivāsetvā tasseva ekenantena sakalasarīraṃ pārupanti, yathā ca kassakā
analyzed: dīghasāṭakam nivāsetvā tassa iva ekena antena sakala sarīram yathā ca kassakā
translated: put on a long sarong and wrap the whole body with one end of it, and the way the ploughmen

original: khettakuṭiṃ pavisantā sāṭakaṃ paliveṭhetvā upakacchake pakkhipitvā tasseva ekenantena
analyzed: khetta kuṭim pavisantā sāṭakam paliveṭhetvā upakacchake pakkhipitvā tassa iva ekena antena
translated: When entering a hut in a field, after having covered the robe with the end of the sarong, he should put it in a corner.

original: sarīraṃ pārupanti, yathā ca brāhmaṇā ubhinnaṃ upakacchakānaṃ antarena sāṭakaṃ pavesetvā
analyzed: sarīram yathā ca brāhmaṇāḥ ubhinnam upakacchakānam antarena sāṭakam pavesetvā
translated: When entering a hut in a field, he should wrap his sarong around him, put it in his carrying net, and cover his body with the upper robe. And just as the brahmans put the sarong between the two carrying nets

original: aṃsakūṭesu pakkhipanti, yathā ca pāḷikārako bhikkhu ekaṃsapārupanena pārutaṃ vāmabāhuṃ
analyzed: aṃsakūṭesu pakkhipanti yathā ca pāḷikārakaḥ bhikkhu eka aṃsa pārupanena pārutam vāma bāhum
translated: and put it on their shoulders, and just as a monk who wears his sarong in the patched wrap style puts the robe on his left arm after opening it out,

original: vivaritvā cīvaraṃ aṃsakūṭaṃ āropeti; evaṃ apārupitvā sabbepi ete aññe ca evarūpe🔽pārupanadose vajjetvā nibbikāraṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ pārupitabbaṃ. Tathā apārupitvā ārāme
analyzed: vivaritvā cīvaram aṃsakūṭam āropeti evam a pārupitvā sabbe pi ete aññe ca evarūpe  pārupana dose vajjetvā nibbikāram parimaṇḍalam pārupitabbam tathā a pārupitvā ārāme
translated: so too, all these and others who wear it in such a way as to cause offense should not wear it like this.

original: vā antaraghare vā anādarena yaṃkiñci vikāraṃ karontassa dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: vā antaraghare vā anādarena yaṃkiñci vikāram karontassa dukkaṭam
translated: They should wear it evenly all round, without causing offense. If, without wearing it like this, they make some kind of alteration, either in the monastery or in a inhabited area, out of disrespect, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.

original: 281. Muṇḍavaṭṭīti yathā rañño kuhiñci gacchato parikkhārabhaṇḍavahanamanussāti adhippāyo. Antarākājanti majjhe laggetvā dvīhi vahitabbabhāraṃ.
analyzed: muṇḍavaṭṭī iti yathā raññaḥ kuhiñci gacchataḥ parikkhāra bhaṇḍa vahana manussā ati adhippāyaḥ majjhe laggetvā dvīhi vahitabba bhāram
translated: ‘A bundle on his head’: the meaning is, like a king, who has people to carry his equipment wherever he goes. ‘A load in the middle’: a load that is carried by two people after putting it down in the middle.

original: 282. Acakkhussanti cakkhūnaṃ hitaṃ na hoti; parihāniṃ janeti. Nacchādetīti na ruccati. Aṭṭhaṅgulaparamanti manussānaṃ pamāṇaṅgulena aṭṭhaṅgulaparamaṃ. Atimaṭāhakanti atikhuddakaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhūnam hitam na hoti parihānim janeti na chādeti iti na ruccati aṭṭha aṅgula paramanti manussānam pamāṇa aṅgulena aṭṭha aṅgula paramam ati maṭāhakam ti ati khuddakam
translated: Not for the eyes’ welfare: it is not beneficial for the eyes; it produces loss. It does not please: it is not agreeable. Up to eight fingerbreadths: up to eight fingerbreadths by the human measure. Too small: too short.

original: 283. Dāyaṃ ālimpentīti tiṇavanādīsu aggiṃ denti. Paṭagginti paṭiaggiṃ. Parittanti
analyzed: dāyam ālimpenti iti aggim denti paṭagginti paṭiaggim parittanti
translated: . Lighting a fire: they light a fire in grass, forest, etc. A counter-fire: a fire to stop the spread of a fire. A protection: a protection by the making of a small clearing or by digging a trench.

original: appaharitakaraṇena vā parikhākhaṇanena vā parittāṇaṃ. Ettha pana anupasampanne sati
analyzed: appaharita karaṇena vā parikhā khaṇanena vā ettha pana anupasampanne sati
translated: . But if there is no one who is not fully admitted to the Order,

original: sayaṃ aggiṃ dātuṃ na labhati, asati aggimpi dātuṃ labhati, bhūmiṃ tacchetvā tiṇānipi🔽harituṃ, parikhampi khaṇituṃ, allasākhaṃ bhañjitvāpi aggiṃ nibbāpetuṃ labhati, senāsanaṃ
analyzed: sayam aggim dātum na labhati asati aggim pi dātum labhati bhūmim tat śetvā tiṇāni pi  haritum khaṇitum alla sākham bhañjitvā api aggim nibbāpetum labhati senāsanam
translated: he is not allowed to light the fire himself. If there is no one, he is allowed to light the fire. He is allowed to cut the grass on the ground and carry it off,🔽to dig a trench, and to extinguish the fire by breaking off the live branches. He is allowed to extinguish the fire in the dwelling or in the bowl or in the place for the bowl in the same way.

original: pattaṃ vā appattaṃ vā tathā nibbāpetuṃ labhatiyeva. Udakena pana kappiyeneva labhati, na itarena.
analyzed: pattam vā appattam vā tathā nibbāpetum labhatiyā iva udakena pana kappiyena iva labhati na itarena
translated: But he is allowed to do so with water that is allowable, not with that which is not allowable.

original: 284. Sati karaṇīyeti sukkhakaṭṭhādiggahaṇakicce sati. Porisiyanti purisappamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: sati karaṇīye iti sukkha kaṭṭha ādi gahaṇa kicce sati porisiyanti purisa ppamāṇam
translated: . If there is work to be done: if there is work to be done in collecting dry timber, etc. Human size: the size of a man.

original: Āpadāsūti vāḷamigādayo vā disvā maggamūḷho vā disā oloketukāmo hutvā davaḍāhaṃ vā
analyzed: āpadāsu iti vāḷa miga ādayaḥ vā disvā magga mūḍhaḥ vā disā oloketu kāmaḥ hutvā davaḍāham vā
translated: The “Sutta on Emergencies” is the sutta in which the Buddha allowed the bhikkhus to eat what was not given when there was a famine, and so on.

original: udakoghaṃ vā āgacchantaṃ disvā evarūpāsu āpadāsu atiuccampi rukkhaṃ ārohituṃ vaṭṭati.🔽285. Kalyāṇavākkaraṇāti madhurasaddā. Chandaso āropemāti vedaṃ viya sakkatabhāsāya🔽vācanāmaggaṃ āropema. Sakāya niruttiyāti ettha sakā nirutti nāma sammāsambuddhena
analyzed: udaka ogham vā āgacchantam disvā evarūpāsu āpadāsu atiuccam pi rukkham ārohitum vaṭṭati  madhura saddā chandasaḥ āropema ati vedam viya sakkata bhāsāya  vācanā maggam āropema sakāya niruttiyā ti ettha sakā nirutti nāma sammāsambuddhena
translated: Or ‘in danger’ means when he sees wild beasts, etc., or when he is confused about the path or wants to look at the directions, or when he sees a forest conflagration or a flood coming, then it is allowable for him to climb a tree even if it is high in such dangers.

original: vuttappakāro māgadhiko vohāro.
analyzed: vutta ppakāraḥ māgadhikaḥ vohāraḥ
translated: ‘One who speaks well’: one who has a sweet voice. ‘We will recite by heart’: we will learn by heart the method of recitation as if it were the Veda. ‘In his own language’: here ‘his own language’ is the speech of Magadha, which is the kind spoken by the Fully Enlightened One.

original: 286. Lokāyataṃ nāma sabbaṃ ucchiṭṭhaṃ, sabbaṃ anucchiṭṭhaṃ, seto kāko, kāḷo bako; iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇenāti evamādiniratthakakāraṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ titthiyasatthaṃ.
analyzed: lokāyatam nāma sabbam ucchiṭṭham sabbam anucchiṭṭham seto kāko kāḷaḥ bakaḥ iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇena ati evamādi niratthaka kāraṇa paṭisaṃyuttam titthiya sattham
translated: ‘Materialism’ is the doctrine of the sectarians, which is connected with purposeless reasons such as ‘Everything is refuse, nothing is refuse; the crow is white, the heron is black; for this reason and for that reason.’

original: 288. Antarā ahosīti antaritā ahosi paṭicchannā.
analyzed: antarā ahosi iti antaritā ahosi paṭicchannā
translated: ‘It was interrupted’: it was interrupted, it was hidden.

original: 289. Ābādhappaccayāti yassa ābādhassa lasuṇaṃ bhesajjaṃ; tappaccayāti attho.
analyzed: ābādha ppaccayā ti yassa ābādhassa lasuṇam bhesajjam tad paccayā ati attho
translated: ‘On the ground of his illness’: the meaning is: on the ground of that illness for which garlic is a remedy.

original: 290. Passāvapādukanti ettha pādukā iṭṭhakāhipi silāhipi dārūhipi kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Vaccapādukāyapi eseva nayo. Pariveṇanti vaccakuṭiparikkhepabbhantaraṃ.🔽293. Yathādhammo kāretabboti dukkaṭavatthumhi dukkaṭena pācittiyavatthumhi pācittiyena
analyzed: ettha pādukāḥ silāhi pi dārūhi pi kātum vaṭṭati esa iva nayo pariveṇam ti vacca kuṭi parikkhepa abbhantaram  yathādhammo kāretabbo ti dukkaṭa vatthumhi dukkaṭena pācittiya vatthumhi pācittiyena
translated: Sandals for the privy: here, sandals can be made of bricks, stones, or wood. The same method applies to sandals for the urine pot. The surrounding area: the area inside the enclosure of the privy.

original: kāretabbo. Paharaṇatthaṃ kataṃ paharaṇīti vuccati, yassa kassaci āvudhasaṅkhātassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ, taṃ ṭhapetvā aññaṃ sabbaṃ lohabhaṇḍaṃ anujānāmīti attho. Katakañca kumbhakārikañcāti
analyzed: kāretabbo paharaṇa attham katam paharaṇī iti vuccati yassa kassaci āvudha saṅkhātassa etam  adhivacanam tam ṭhapetvā aññam sabbam loha bhaṇḍam anujānāmi iti katakam ca kumbhakārikam ca ati
translated: He should be dealt with according to the rule: in the case of an offense entailing confession, he should be dealt with according to the rule for an offense entailing confession.🔽A weapon is what is called a weapon. The meaning is: I allow all metal goods except that.

original: ettha katakaṃ vuttameva. Kumbhakārikañcāti dhaniyasseva sabbamattikāmayakuṭi vuccati.
analyzed: ettha katakam vuttam eva kumbhakārikam ca ati dhaniyassa iva vuccati
translated: And earthenware and ceramic: here, earthenware has already been mentioned. And ceramic: a ceramic hut is what is meant.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.🔽Khuddakavatthukathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati  khuddaka vatthu kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The rest is clear in all cases.🔽The discussion of minor rules is finished.

original: Khuddakavatthukkhandhakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Senāsanakkhandhakaṃ
analyzed: khuddaka vatthu khandhaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  senāsana kkhandhakam
translated: The commentary on the chapter on minor rules is finished.

original: Vihārānujānanakathā
analyzed: vihāra anujānana kathā
translated: The chapter on dwellings🔽The discussion of the allowance of dwellings

original: 294. Senāsanakkhandhake – apaññattaṃ hotīti ananuññātaṃ hoti. Vihāro nāma aḍḍhayogādimuttako🔽avasesāvāso. Aḍḍhayogoti supaṇṇavaṅkagehaṃ. Pāsādoti dīghapāsādo. Hammiyanti upariākāsatale🔽patiṭṭhitakūṭāgāro pāsādoyeva. Guhāti iṭṭhakāguhā silāguhā dāruguhā paṃsuguhā. Āgatānāgatassa🔽cātuddisassa saṅghassāti āgatassa ca anāgatassa ca catūsu disāsu appaṭihatacārassa
analyzed: senāsana kkhandhake a paññattam hoti iti an anuññātam hoti vihāraḥ nāma aḍḍha yoga ādi muttako  avasesa āvāsaḥ aḍḍhayogo ti supaṇṇavaṅkageham pāsādo ti dīgha pāsādaḥ hammiyanti upari ākāsa tale  patiṭṭhita kūṭāgāraḥ pāsādaḥ yā iva guhā ati iṭṭhakā guhā silā guhā dāru guhā paṃsu guhā āgata anāgatassa  cātuddisassa saṅghassa ati āgatassa ca anāgatassa ca catūsu disāsu a paṭihata cārassa
translated: In the Khandhaka on dwellings: It is not laid down: it is not allowed. A dwelling: a building with a gabled roof, etc.,

original: cātuddisassa saṅghassa.
analyzed: cātuddisassa saṅghassa
translated: and the rest are the other kinds of dwelling. A building with a gabled roof: a house with a roof sloping on both sides. A multi-storied building: a building with upper rooms. A gabled building: a building with a peaked roof. A cell: a cell built of brick, stone, wood, or beaten earth. For the Sangha of the four directions, both present and future: for the Sangha of the four directions, which is not restricted by locality, but is present everywhere, and for the future Sangha.

original: 295. Anumodanagāthāsu – sītaṃ uṇhanti utuvisabhāgavasena vuttaṃ. Sisire cāpi vuṭṭhiyoti
analyzed: anumodana gāthāsu sītam uṇhanti utu visa bhāga vasena vuttam sisire ca api vuṭṭhiyā ti
translated: In the verses of appreciation: Cold and hot: said according to the difference in the seasons. And in the cold, rain falls:

analyzed: ettha sisirā iti samphusitaka vātaḥ vuccati vuṭṭhiyā ti ujuka megha vuṭṭhiyaḥ eva etāni
translated: Herein, cold is a wind that is cold to the touch. Rain is only the straight rain from clouds.

original: sabbāni paṭihantīti imināva padena yojetabbāni.
analyzed: sabbāni paṭihanti iti iminā ava padena yojetabbāni
translated: All these are stopped: this should be construed with the phrase “is stopped.”

original: Paṭihaññatīti vihārena paṭihaññati. Leṇatthanti nilīyanatthaṃ. Sukhatthanti sītādiparissayābhāvena
analyzed: paṭihaññati iti vihārena paṭihaññati leṇatthanti nilīyanattham sukhatthanti sītā ādi parissaya abhāvena
translated: It is stopped: it is stopped by the dwelling. For shelter: for the purpose of sheltering. For comfort: because of the absence of cold, etc.,

analyzed: sukha vihāra attham jhāyitum ca vipassitum ti idam pi pada dvayam sukha attham ca ati  padena yojetabbam idam hi vuttam hoti sukha attham ca vihāra dānam katamam sukha attham  jhāyitum vipassitum ca yam sukham tad attham atha vā para padena api yojetabbam jhāyitum ca

original: sabbaṃ tesu ujubhūtesu akuṭilacittesu. Dadeyyāti nidaheyya. Tañca kho vippasannena
analyzed: sabbam tesu uju bhūtesu akuṭila cittesu dadeyya ati nidaheyya tat ca kho vippasannena
translated: He should give them all to those who are upright and have a sincere mind. ‘Should give’: should hand over. And he should do so with a confident mind,

original: cetasā na cittappasādaṃ virādhetvā, evaṃ vippasannacittassa hi te tassa dhammaṃ desenti…pe…
analyzed: cetasā na citta ppasādam virādhetvā evam vippasanna cittassa hi te tassa dhammam desenti pe
translated: not withholding his confidence. For they teach him the Dhamma with a confident mind. …

original: parinibbāti anāsavoti.🔽296. Āviñchanacchiddaṃ āviñchanarajjunti ettha rajju nāma sacepi dīpinaṅguṭṭhena
analyzed: parinibbāti anāsavaḥ ti  āviñchana chiddam āviñchana rajjunti ettha rajju nāma
translated: he attains nibbana without clinging.

original: katā hoti, vaṭṭatiyeva; na kāci na vaṭṭati. Tīṇi tāḷānīti tisso kuñcikāyo. Yantakaṃ
analyzed: katā hoti vaṭṭatiyā iva na kāci na vaṭṭati tīṇi tāḷāni iti tisso kuñcikāyaḥ yantakam
translated: The opening for the rope and the rope for pulling out: if the rope is made of a palm leaf, it is still valid; any kind of rope is valid. Three bolts: three locks. A key-hole:

original: sūcikanti ettha yaṃ yaṃ jānāti taṃ taṃ yantakaṃ, tassa vivaraṇasūcikañca kātuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: sūcikam ti ettha yam yam jānāti tam tam yantakam tassa vivaraṇa sūcikam ca kātum vaṭṭati
