original: Vedikāvātapānaṃ nāma cetiye vedikāsadisaṃ. Jālavātapānaṃ nāma jālakabaddhaṃ. Salākavātapānaṃ
analyzed: vedikāvātapānam nāma cetiye vedikā sadisam jālavātapānam nāma jālaka baddham salāka vāta pānam
translated: A balustrade-window: like a balustrade at a shrine. A lattice-window: made of lattice-work. A bar-window:

original: nāma thambhakavātapānaṃ. Cakkalikanti ettha coḷakapādapuñchanaṃ bandhituṃ anujānāmīti
analyzed: nāma thambhaka vāta pānam ettha coḷaka pāda puñchanam bandhitum anujānāmi iti
translated: a window with bars. A pulley: I allow you to fasten a cloth to the foot of the bed.

original: attho. Vātapānabhisīti vātapānappamāṇena bhisiṃ katvā bandhituṃ anujānāmīti attho.
analyzed: atthaḥ vāta pāna bhisī iti vāta pāna ppamāṇena bhisim katvā bandhitum anujānāmi iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: I allow you to make a bedstead the size of a window.

original: Miḍḍhinti miḍḍhakaṃ. Bidalamañcakanti vettamañcaṃ; veḷuvilīvehi vā vītaṃ.
analyzed: miḍḍhinti miḍḍhakam vettamañcam vā vītam
translated: A frame: a frame of bamboo. A bamboo bed: a bed made of bamboo.

original: 297. Āsandikoti caturassapīṭhaṃ vuccati. Uccakampi āsandikanti vacanato ekatobhāgena
analyzed: āsandiko ti caturassa pīṭham vuccati uccakampi āsandikanti vacanataḥ ekatobhāgena
translated: A couch: a four-legged bench. Since it is said that “a couch is high,”

original: dīghapīṭhameva hi aṭṭhaṅgulapādakaṃ vaṭṭati, caturassaāsandiko pana pamāṇātikkantopi
analyzed: dīgha pīṭham eva hi aṭṭha aṅgula pādakam vaṭṭati catur assa āsandikaḥ pana pamāṇa atikkantaḥ api
translated: a long bench with legs eight fingerbreadths high is allowable. But a four-legged bench, even if it exceeds the right size,

original: vaṭṭatīti veditabbo. Sattaṅgo nāma tīsu disāsu apassayaṃ katvā katamañco, ayampi🔽pamāṇātikkanto vaṭṭati. Bhaddapīṭhanti vettamayaṃ pīṭhaṃ vuccati. Pīṭhikāti pilotikābaddhapīṭhameva.🔽Eḷakapādapīṭhaṃ nāma dārupaṭṭikāya upari pāde ṭhapetvā bhojanaphalakaṃ viya katapīṭhaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti veditabbaḥ sattaṅgaḥ nāma tīsu disāsu apassayam katvā ayam pi  pamāṇa atikkantaḥ vaṭṭati bhadda pīṭhanti vetta mayam pīṭham vuccati pīṭhikā ati pilotikā baddha pīṭham eva  eḷakapādapīṭham nāma dāru paṭṭikāya upari pāde ṭhapetvā bhojana phalakam kata pīṭham
translated: should be understood as allowable. A seven-part bed: a bed made with three spaces on each side and one in the middle. This too🔽is allowable if it exceeds the right size. A fine bed: a bed made of bamboo. A bench: a bench made with strips of leather.🔽A bed with legs: a bed made by placing legs underneath a wooden plank used for sitting and eating.

original: vuccati. Āmalakavaṭṭikapīṭhaṃ nāma āmalakākārena yojitaṃ bahupādakapīṭhaṃ. Imāni
analyzed: vuccati āmalakavaṭṭika pīṭham nāma āmalaka ākārena yojitam bahu pādaka pīṭham imāni
translated: A bed with knobs: a bed with knobs made of fruit. These are allowable if they exceed the right size.

original: tāva pāḷiyaṃ āgatapīṭhāni. Dārumayaṃ pana sabbaṃ pīṭhaṃ vaṭṭatīti ayamettha vinicchayo.🔽Kocchanti usiramayaṃ vā muñjapabbajamayaṃ vā.
analyzed: tāva pāḷiyam āgata pīṭhāni dāru mayam pana sabbam pīṭham vaṭṭati iti ayam ettha vinicchayo  usira mayam vā muñja pabbaja mayam vā
translated: These are the kinds of seats mentioned in the texts. But any wooden seat is allowable. This is the decision here.🔽“Grass” is grass of the kinds called “needle-leaf” and “cluster-leaf.”

original: Aṭṭhaṅgulaparamaṃ mañcapaṭipādakanti ettha manussānaṃ pamāṇaṅgulameva aṭṭhaṅgulaṃ.🔽Cimilikā nāma parikammakatāya bhūmiyā chavisaṃrakkhaṇatthāya attharaṇaṃ vuccati.🔽Rukkhatūlanti simbalirukkhādīnaṃ yesaṃ kesañci rukkhānaṃ tūlaṃ. Latātūlanti khīravalliādīnaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha aṅgula paramam mañca paṭipādakanti ettha manussānam pamāṇa aṅgulam eva aṭṭha aṅgulam  cimilikā nāma parikammakatāya bhūmiyā chavi saṃrakkhaṇa atthāya attharaṇam vuccati  rukkha tūlanti simbali rukkha ādīnam yesam kesañci rukkhānam tūlam latā tūlanti khīravalli ādīnam
translated: “Eight inches” is the human finger.🔽“Mat” is a mat made of grass or bark or thread.🔽“Tree-wool” is the down of such trees as the simsapa. “Creeper-wool” is the down of such creepers as the milky creeper.

original: yāsaṃ kāsañci vallīnaṃ tūlaṃ. Poṭakitūlanti poṭakitiṇādīnaṃ yesaṃ kesañci tiṇajātikānaṃ
analyzed: vallīnam tūlam poṭaki tūlanti poṭaki tiṇa ādīnam yesam kesañci tiṇa jātikānam
translated: “Cotton-tree wool” is the down of such trees as the kaṭāha and such creepers as the cotton creeper.

original: antamaso ucchunaḷādīnampi tūlaṃ. Etehi tīhi sabbabhūtagāmā saṅgahitā honti. Rukkhavallitiṇajātiyo
analyzed: antamasaḥ ucchunaḷa ādīnam pi tūlam etehi tīhi sabba bhūta gāmā saṅgahitāḥ honti rukkha valli tiṇa jātiyaḥ
translated: These three terms include all tree-wool, creeper-wool, and grass-wool.

original: hi muñcitvā añño bhūtagāmo nāma natthi, tasmā yassa kassaci bhūtagāmassa tūlaṃ bimbohane
analyzed: hi muñcitvā aññaḥ bhūtagāmaḥ nāma natthi tasmai yassa kassaci bhūtagāmassa tūlam bimbohane
translated: Apart from the kinds of trees, creepers, and grasses, there is no other kind of wool. Therefore the down of any tree, creeper, or grass is called “wool.”

original: vaṭṭati, bhisiṃ pana pāpuṇitvā sabbampetaṃ akappiyatūlanti vuccati. Na kevalañca
analyzed: vaṭṭati bhisim pana pāpuṇitvā sabbam petam akappiya tūlam ti vuccati na kevalam ca
translated: But when it is made into a pillow, all this is called “improper stuffing.”

original: bimbohane etaṃ tūlameva, haṃsamorādīnaṃ sabbasakuṇānaṃ sīhādīnaṃ sabbacatuppadānañca
analyzed: bimbohane etam tūlam eva haṃsa mora ādīnam sabba sakuṇānam sīha ādīnam sabba catuppadānam ca
translated: And this is not only for a pillow: the feathers of all birds such as geese, peacocks, etc., and the wool of all four-footed animals such as lions, tigers, etc.,

original: lomampi vaṭṭati. Piyaṅgupupphabakuḷapupphādi pana yaṃkiñci pupphaṃ na vaṭṭati. Tamālapattaṃ
analyzed: lomam pi vaṭṭati piyaṅgu puppha bakuḷa puppha ādi pana yaṃkiñci puppham na vaṭṭati tamāla pattam
translated: are allowable. But no flowers such as ironwood flowers, spider lily flowers, etc., are allowable.

original: suddhameva na vaṭṭati, missakaṃ pana vaṭṭati. Bhisīnaṃ anuññātaṃ pañcavidhaṃ uṇṇāditūlampi vaṭṭati.
analyzed: suddham eva na vaṭṭati missakam pana vaṭṭati bhisīnam anuññātam pañcavidham uṇṇa ādi tūlam pi vaṭṭati
translated: A pure betel-leaf is not allowable, but a mixed one is. And the five kinds of pillow mentioned for the sick are allowable.

original: Addhakāyikānīti upaḍḍhakāyappamāṇāni, yesu kaṭito paṭṭhāya yāva sīsaṃ upadahanti.🔽Sīsappamāṇaṃ nāma yassa vitthārato tīsu kaṇṇesu dvinnaṃ kaṇṇānaṃ antaraṃ minīyamānaṃ
analyzed: addhakāyikāni iti upaḍḍha kāya ppamāṇāni yesu kaṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva sīsam upadahanti  sīsappamāṇam nāma yassa vitthārato tīsu kaṇṇesu dvinnam kaṇṇānam antaram minīyamānam
translated: “For the half of the body”: the size of half the body is from the waist to the head.🔽“The size of the head”: the space between the two ears when measured across the three ears is a span and four finger-breadths. The middle part is a span and a half.

original: vidatthi ceva caturaṅgulañca hoti, majjhaṭṭhānaṃ muṭṭhiratanaṃ hoti. Dīghato pana
analyzed: vidatthi ca iva catur aṅgulam ca hoti majjha ṭṭhānam muṭṭhi ratanam hoti dīghataḥ pana
translated: As to length, it is

original: diyaḍḍharatanaṃ vā dviratanaṃ vāti kurundiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ sīsappamāṇassa ukkaṭṭhaparicchedo.
analyzed: diyaḍḍha ratanam vā dvi ratanam vā ati kurundiyam vuttam ayam sīsa ppamāṇassa ukkaṭṭha paricchedo
translated: Or two cubits and a half, or two cubits: this is the maximum size for a head-covering.

original: Ito uddhaṃ na vaṭṭati, heṭṭhā pana vaṭṭati. Agilānassa sīsupadhānañca pādupadhānañcāti
analyzed: itas uddham na vaṭṭati heṭṭhā pana vaṭṭati a gilānassa sīsa upadhānam ca pāda upadhānam ca ati
translated: It is not allowable to make it bigger than this; it is allowable to make it smaller.🔽For one who is not sick only two things are allowable, a head-covering and a foot-covering.

original: dvayameva vaṭṭati. Gilānassa bimbohanāni santharitvā upari paccattharaṇaṃ katvā nipajjitumpi
analyzed: dvayam eva vaṭṭati gilānassa bimbohanāni santharitvā upari paccattharaṇam katvā nipajjitum pi
translated: For one who is sick it is allowable to lie down on a bedspread after spreading out a mattress and pillow.

original: vaṭṭati. “Yāni pana bhisīnaṃ anuññātāni pañca kappiyatūlāni, tehi bimbohanaṃ mahantampi🔽vaṭṭatī”ti phussadevatthero āha. Vinayadharaupatissatthero pana “bimbohanaṃ karissāmī’ti
analyzed: vaṭṭati yāni pana bhisīnam anuññātāni pañca kappiya tūlāni tehi bimbohanam mahantam pi  vaṭṭati iti phussadeva ttheraḥ āha vinayadhara aupatissa theraḥ pana bimbohanam karissāmi iti
translated: The Elder Phussadeva said that a large bedspread made with any of the five kinds of thread allowed for a bedspread is allowable.

original: kappiyatūlaṃ vā akappiyatūlaṃ vā pakkhipitvā karontassa pamāṇameva vaṭṭatī”ti āha.
analyzed: kappiya tūlam vā a kappiya tūlam vā pakkhipitvā karontassa pamāṇam eva vaṭṭati iti āha
translated: But the Elder Upatissa, who knew the Discipline well, said that if one makes a bedspread with the intention of making a bedspread, and he puts in it either thread allowed for a bedspread or thread not allowed for a bedspread, then the size is allowable.

original: Pañca bhisiyoti pañcahi uṇṇādīhi pūritabhisiyo. Tūlagaṇanāya hi etāsaṃ gaṇanā vuttā.
analyzed: pañca bhisiyaḥ ti pañcahi uṇṇa ādīhi pūrita bhisiyaḥ tūla gaṇanāya hi etāsam gaṇanā vuttā
translated: Five kinds of bedspreads: bedspreads filled with cotton wool, etc., the five kinds of thread. For their enumeration is given by way of the kinds of thread.

original: Tattha uṇṇaggahaṇena na kevalaṃ eḷakalomameva gahitaṃ, ṭhapetvā manussalomaṃ yaṃkiñci🔽kappiyākappiyamaṃsajātīnaṃ pakkhicatuppadānaṃ lomaṃ, sabbaṃ idha uṇṇaggahaṇeneva
analyzed: tattha uṇṇa ggahaṇena na kevalam eḷaka lomam eva gahitam ṭhapetvā manussa lomam yaṃkiñcid  kappiya akappiya maṃsa jātīnam pakkhi catuppadānam lomam sabbam idha uṇṇa ggahaṇena iva
translated: Herein, by the words “wool” not only sheep’s wool is included, but also🔽the wool of any of the kinds of birds and quadrupeds that are fit to be eaten or unfit to be eaten, with the exception of human beings.

original: gahitaṃ. Tasmā channaṃ cīvarānaṃ channaṃ anulomacīvarānañca aññatarena bhisicchaviṃ🔽katvā taṃ sabbaṃ pakkhipitvā bhisiṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Eḷakalomāni pana apakkhipitvā
analyzed: gahitam tasmai channam cīvara anam channam anuloma cīvara anam ca aññatarena bhisi chavim  katvā tam sabbam pakkhipitvā bhisim kātum vaṭṭati eḷaka lomāni pana a pakkhipitvā
translated: So it is allowable to make a blanket by taking any one of the six kinds of cloth or any one of the six kinds of cloth that are next mentioned and by adding to it the wool of any of these kinds of birds and quadrupeds.

original: kambalameva catugguṇaṃ vā pañcaguṇaṃ vā pakkhipitvā katāpi uṇṇabhisisaṅkhyameva gacchati.
analyzed: kambalam eva catugguṇam vā pañcaguṇam vā pakkhipitvā katā api uṇṇa bhisi saṅkhyam eva gacchati
translated: But if one makes it with only wool and no cloth, and with four or five layers of wool, it still counts as a blanket made of wool.

original: Coḷabhisiādīsu yaṃkiñci navacoḷaṃ vā purāṇacoḷaṃ vā saṃharitvā vā anto pakkhipitvā
analyzed: coḷa bhisi ādīsu yaṃkiñci nava coḷam vā purāṇa coḷam vā saṃharitvā vā antar pakkhipitvā
translated: In the case of the blanket made of rags, etc., any new cloth or old cloth that is cut up and sewn together is a blanket made of rags.🔽Any blanket made by adding to it any kind of bird’s feathers is a blanket made of feathers.

original: vā katā coḷabhisi, yaṃkiñci vākaṃ pakkhipitvā katā vākabhisi, yaṃkiñci tiṇaṃ pakkhipitvā🔽katā tiṇabhisi, aññatra suddhatamālapattaṃ yaṃkiñci paṇṇaṃ pakkhipitvā katā paṇṇabhisīti
analyzed: vā katā coḷa bhisi yaṃkiñci vākam pakkhipitvā katā vāka bhisi yaṃkiñci tiṇam pakkhipitvā 🔽katā tiṇa bhisi aññatra suddha tamāla pattam yaṃkiñci paṇṇam pakkhipitvā katā paṇṇa bhisi iti
translated: Any blanket made by adding to it any kind of grass is a blanket made of grass.🔽Any blanket made by adding to it any kind of leaf, except the pure white lotus leaf, is a blanket made of leaves.

original: veditabbā. Tamālapattaṃ pana aññena missameva vaṭṭati, suddhaṃ na vaṭṭati. Bhisiyā
analyzed: veditabbā tamāla pattam pana aññena missam eva vaṭṭati suddham na vaṭṭati bhisiyā
translated: But a mattress of tāla leaves is allowable only if it is mixed with something else; pure tāla leaves are not allowable. A mattress is

original: pamāṇaniyamo natthi, mañcabhisi pīṭhabhisi bhūmattharaṇabhisi caṅkamanabhisi pādapuñchanabhisīti
analyzed: pamāṇa niyamaḥ natthi mañca bhisi pīṭha bhisi bhūmattharaṇa bhisi caṅkamana bhisi pāda puñchana bhisi iti
translated: not restricted in size. There is a bed-mattress, a chair-mattress, a floor-mattress, a walking-meditation-path mattress, and a foot-washing- place mattress.

original: etāsaṃ anurūpato sallakkhetvā attano rucivasena pamāṇaṃ kātabbaṃ. Yaṃ panetaṃ uṇṇādipañcavidhatūlampi
analyzed: etāsam anurūpataḥ sat lakkhetvā attanaḥ ruci vasena pamāṇam kātabbam yam pana itam uṇṇa ādi pañcavidha tūlam pi
translated: The size should be made according to one’s wish after considering what is suitable for these. But the five kinds of stuffing beginning with kaṭṭissa are allowable for a mattress.

original: bhisiyaṃ vaṭṭati, taṃ “masūrakepi vaṭṭatī”ti kurundiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Etena masūrakaṃ paribhuñjituṃ🔽vaṭṭatīti siddhaṃ hoti.🔽Mañcabhisiṃ pīṭhe santharantīti mañcabhisiṃ pīṭhe attharanti; attharaṇatthāya harantīti🔽yujjati. Ullokaṃ akaritvāti heṭṭhā cimilikaṃ adatvā. Phositunti rajanena vā haliddiyā
analyzed: bhisiyam vaṭṭati tam masūrake pi vaṭṭati iti kurundiyam vuttam etena masūrakam paribhuñjitum  vaṭṭati iti siddham hoti  mañca bhisim pīṭhe santharanti iti mañca bhisim pīṭhe attharanti attharaṇa tthāya haranti iti  yujjati ullokam a karitvā ati heṭṭhā cimilikam rajanena vā haliddiyā
translated: And in the Kurundi Commentary it is said that cotton down is allowable. By this it is established that cotton down is allowable to use.

original: vā upari phusitāni dātuṃ. Bhattikammanti bhisicchaviyā upari bhattikammaṃ. Hatthabhattinti pañcaṅgulibhattiṃ.
analyzed: vā upari phusitāni dātum bhatti kammanti bhisi chaviyāḥ upari bhatti kammam hattha bhattim ti pañca aṅguli bhattim
translated: “They spread the bed-mattress on the chair”: they spread the bed-mattress on the chair; it is appropriate to take it for the purpose of spreading. “Without having it looked over”: without having the underside made smooth. “To have it beaten”: to have it beaten with dye or turmeric. “To have it embroidered”: to have embroidery work done on the surface of the mattress. “A five-finger breadth embroidery”: a five-finger breadth embroidery.

original: 298. Ikkāsanti rukkhaniyyāsaṃ vā silesaṃ vā. Piṭṭhamaddanti piṭṭhakhaliṃ. Kuṇḍakamattikanti🔽kuṇḍakamissakamattikaṃ. Sāsapakuṭṭanti sāsapapiṭṭhaṃ. Sitthatelakanti vilīnamadhusitthakaṃ.🔽Accussannaṃ hotīti bindu bindu hutvā tiṭṭhati. Paccuddharitunti puñchituṃ. Gaṇḍumattikanti
analyzed: ikkāsanti rukkha niyyāsam vā silesam vā piṭṭha maddanti piṭṭha khalim kuṇḍaka mattikanti  kuṇḍaka missaka mattikam sāsapa kuṭṭanti sāsapa piṭṭham sittha telakam ti vilīna madhu sitthakam  accussannam hoti iti bindu bindu hutvā tiṭṭhati paccuddharitum ti puñchitum gaṇḍumattikam ti
translated: ‘A lump of clay’: a lump of clay or a lump of lime. ‘A lump of cow-dung’:🔽a lump of cow-dung mixed with clay. ‘A lump of salt’: a lump of salt mixed with cow-dung. ‘Honey and oil’: honey and oil mixed together.🔽‘It trickles down’: it remains in drops. ‘To wipe off’: to wipe it off. ‘A lump of foam’:🔽

original: gaṇḍuppādagūthamattikaṃ. Kasāvanti āmalakaharītakānaṃ kasāvaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇḍuppāda gūtha mattikam kasāvanti āmalaka harītakānam kasāvam
translated: ‘A plaster’: a plaster of clay or lime. ‘A plaster for the back-ache’: a plaster for the back. ‘A plaster mixed with urine’: a plaster mixed with urine and clay. ‘A plaster of sesame flour’: a plaster of sesame flour. ‘Honey-vinegar’: honey mixed with water. ‘It trickles out’: it remains in drops. ‘He should remove it’: he should wipe it off. ‘A plaster of cow-dung’: a plaster of cow-dung and urine. ‘A decoction’: a decoction of emblic myrobalan or yellow myrobalan.

original: 299. Na bhikkhave paṭibhānacittanti ettha na kevalaṃ itthipurisarūpameva, tiracchānarūpampi
analyzed: na bhikkhave paṭibhāna cittam ti ettha na kevalam itthi purisa rūpam eva tiracchāna rūpam pi
translated: ‘A mind to make fun of’: not only the form of a woman or a man, but also the form of an animal,

original: antamaso gaṇḍuppādarūpampi bhikkhuno sayaṃ kātuṃ vā “karohī”ti vattuṃ vā na vaṭṭati,🔽“upāsaka dvārapālaṃ karohī”ti vattumpi na labbhati. Jātakapakaraṇaasadisadānādīni
analyzed: antamasaḥ gaṇḍuppāda rūpam pi bhikkhuno sayam kātum vā karohi iti vattum vā na vaṭṭati  upāsaka dvārapālam karohi iti vattum pi na labbhati jātaka pakaraṇa asadisa dāna ādīni
translated: down to the form of a cow-dung beetle, it is not allowable for a bhikkhu to make it himself or to tell someone else to make it,🔽or to say to a layman, “Make a door-keeper, lay follower.” But it is allowable to have others make such things as the stories of the past-birth tales, the stories of the gifts of dung, etc.,

original: pana pasādanīyāni nibbidāpaṭisaṃyuttāni vā vatthūni parehi kārāpetuṃ labbhati. Mālākammādīni
analyzed: pana pasādanīyāni nibbidā paṭisaṃyuttāni vā vatthūni parehi kārāpetum labbhati mālā kamma ādīni
translated: which are inspiring and connected with the arousing of the emotions. Garlands, etc.,

original: sayampi kātuṃ labbhati.🔽300. Aḷakamandāti ekaṅgaṇā manussābhikiṇṇā. Tayo gabbheti ettha sivikāgabbhoti caturassagabbho.
analyzed: sayam pi kātum labbhati  aḷakamandā ati ekaṅgaṇā manussābhikiṇṇā tayo gabbhe ti ettha sivikāgabbho ti catur assa gabbhaḥ
translated: One may also have it done for oneself.🔽A hall with a single courtyard: a hall with a single entrance.

original: Nāḷikāgabbhoti vitthārato diguṇatiguṇāyāmo dīghagabbho. Hammiyagabbhoti ākāsatale
analyzed: nāḷikāgabbho ti vitthārataḥ diguṇa tiguṇa āyāmaḥ dīgha gabbhaḥ hammiya gabbhaḥ ti ākāsa tale
translated: Three kinds of buildings: a square building, a long building, and a multi-storied building.

original: kūṭāgāragabbho vā muṇḍacchadanagabbho vā.🔽Kalaṅkapādakanti rukkhaṃ vijjhitvā tattha khāṇuke ākoṭetvā kataṃ, taṃ āharimaṃ bhittipādaṃ
analyzed: kūṭāgāra gabbhaḥ vā muṇḍacchadana gabbhaḥ vā  kalaṅkapādakam ti rukkham vijjhitvā tattha khāṇuke ākoṭetvā katam tam bhitti pādam
translated: A multi-storied building: a building with a peaked roof or a flat roof.

original: jiṇṇakuṭṭapādassa upatthambhanatthaṃ bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhāpetuṃ anujānāmīti attho. Parittāṇakiṭikanti
analyzed: jiṇṇa kuṭṭa pādassa upatthambhana attham bhūmiyam patiṭṭhāpetum anujānāmi iti parittāṇa kiṭikanti
translated: A support for a rotten wall: a support for a wall that is about to collapse. The meaning is: I allow you to place a support in the ground by driving a post into the ground and then striking it.🔽A small shelter: a shelter for protection from the rain.

original: vassaparittāṇatthaṃ kiṭikaṃ. Uddasudhanti vacchakagomayena ceva chārikāya ca saddhiṃ madditamattikaṃ.
analyzed: vassa parittāṇa ttham kiṭikam vacchaka gomayena ca iva chārikāya ca saddhim maddita mattikam
translated: A mixture of cow dung and clay: clay mixed with cow dung and chaff.🔽A threshold: the front edge of a door is what is meant.

original: Āḷindo nāma pamukhaṃ vuccati. Paghanaṃ nāma yaṃ nikkhamantā ca pavisantā ca pādehi
analyzed: āḷindaḥ nāma pamukham vuccati paghanam nāma yam nikkhamantā ca pavisantā ca pādehi
translated: A door frame: a place where the door opens and closes and where the feet

original: hananti, tassa vihāradvāre ubhato kuṭṭaṃ nīharitvā katapadesassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ,
analyzed: hananti tassa vihāra dvāre ubhatas kuṭṭam nīharitvā kata padesassa itam adhivacanaṃ
translated: hit it. The meaning is: having removed the wall on both sides of the door of the dwelling, I allow you to make a door frame in the place that is left.

original: “paghāna”ntipi vuccati. Pakuṭṭanti majjhe gabbhassa samantā pariyāgāro vuccati. “Pakuṭa”ntipi
analyzed: paghānanti pi vuccati pakuṭṭanti majjhe gabbhassa samantā pariyāgāraḥ vuccati pakuṭanti pi
translated: “paghāna” is also said. Pakuṭṭa is said to be the surrounding building all around the middle of the womb. “Pakuṭa” is also said.

original: pāṭho. Osārakanti anāḷindake vihāre vaṃsaṃ datvā tato daṇḍake osāretvā katachadanapamukhaṃ.
analyzed: anāḷindake vihāre vaṃsam da tvā tatas daṇḍake osāretvā kata chadana pamukham
translated: “paghāna” is also said. Pakuṭṭa is said to be the surrounding building all around the middle of the womb. “Pakuṭa” is also a reading. Osāraka is a roof made by putting a beam in a house without a roof and then putting a pole on it.

original: Saṃsāraṇakiṭiko nāma cakkalayutto kiṭiko.
analyzed: saṃsāraṇa kiṭikaḥ nāma cakkala yutto kiṭiko
translated: Saṃsāraṇakiṭika is a kiṭika with a wheel.

original: 301. Pānīyabhājananti pivantānaṃ pānīyadānabhājanaṃ. Uḷuṅko ca thālakañca pānīyasaṅkhassa anulomāni.
analyzed: pānīya bhājananti pivantānam pānīya dāna bhājanam uḷuṅkaḥ ca thālakam ca pānīya saṅkhassa anulomāni
translated: Pānīyabhājana is a vessel for giving drinking water to those who are drinking. Uḷuṅka and thālaka are suitable for a water pot.

original: 303. Apesīti dīghadārumhi khāṇuke pavesetvā kaṇṭakasākhāhi vinandhitvā kataṃ dvārathakanakaṃ. Palighoti gāmadvāresu viya cakkayuttaṃ dvārathakanakaṃ.
analyzed: dīghadārumhi khāṇuke pavesetvā kaṇṭaka sākhāhi vinandhitvā katam dvāratha kanakam gāma dvāresu viya cakka yuttam dvāratha kanakam
translated: Apesī is a door-bolt made by inserting a long piece of wood into a hole and fastening it with thorny branches. Paligha is a door-bolt with a wheel like at the entrance to a village.

original: 305. Assatarīhi yuttā rathā assatarīrathā. Āmuttamaṇikuṇḍalāti āmuttamaṇikuṇḍalāni.
analyzed: assatarīhi yuttāḥ rathāḥ assatarī rathāḥ āmutta maṇi kuṇḍalāti āmutta maṇi kuṇḍalāni
translated: Assatarīrathas are chariots yoked with asses. Āmuttamaṇikuṇḍalāni are earrings with hanging jewels.

original: Parinibbutoti kilesaparinibbānena parinibbuto. Sītibhūtoti kilesātapābhāvena sītibhūto. Nirūpadhīti kilesupadhiabhāvena nirūpadhīti vuccati.
analyzed: parinibbutoti kilesa parinibbānena parinibbutaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ iti kilesa ātapa abhāvena sīti bhūtaḥ nirūpadhī iti kilesupadhi abhāvena nirūpadhī iti vuccati
translated: Parinibbuto is one who has attained Nibbāna through the destruction of defilements. Sītibhūto is one who has become cool through the heat of defilements. Nirūpadhī is said to be one who is without clinging through the absence of clinging to defilements.

original: Sabbā āsattiyo chetvāti rūpādīsu vā visayesu sabbabhavesu vā patthanāyo chinditvā. Hadaye daranti citte kilesadarathaṃ vinetvā. Veyyāyikanti vayakaraṇaṃ vuccati.
analyzed: sabbāḥ āsattiyaḥ chetvā ti rūpa ādīsu vā visayesu sabba bhavesu vā patthanāyo chinditvā hadaye citte kilesa daratham vinetvā veyyāyikam ti vaya karaṇam vuccati
translated: ‘Having cut off all attachments’: having cut off all longings for objects such as visible forms, etc., or for all kinds of existence. ‘They pierced his heart’: they subdued the dart of defilements in his mind. ‘The work’: the performance is what is meant.

original: 307. Ādeyyavācoti tassa vacanaṃ bahū janā ādiyitabbaṃ sotabbaṃ maññantīti attho.
analyzed: ādeyya vācaḥ ti tassa vacanam bahū janāḥ ādiyitabbam sotabbam maññanti iti attho
translated: ‘His word was accepted’: the meaning is that many people thought his word should be accepted and listened to.

original: Ārāme akaṃsūti ye sadhanā, te attano dhanena akaṃsu. Ye mandadhanā ceva adhanā ca,
analyzed: ārāme akaṃsūti ye sa dhanā te attanaḥ dhanena akaṃsu ye manda dhanā ca iva adhanā ca
translated: ‘They built monasteries’: those who were wealthy built them with their own money,

original: tesaṃ dhanaṃ adāsi. Iti so satasahassakahāpaṇe satasahassagghanakañca bhaṇḍaṃ datvā
analyzed: tesam dhanam adāsi iti saḥ sata sahassa kahāpaṇe bhaṇḍam da tvā
translated: but he gave money to those who were poor and had no money. Thus he gave away a hundred thousand kahāpaṇas and goods worth a hundred thousand kahāpaṇas.

original: pañcacattālīsayojanike addhāne yojane yojane vihārapatiṭṭhānaṃ katvā sāvatthiṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: pañcacattālīsa yojanike addhāne yojane yojane vihāra patiṭṭhānam katvā sāvatthim agamāsi
translated: He went to Sāvatthī, having had a monastery site established every yojana along the fifty-four-yojana route.

original: Koṭisantharaṃ santharāpesīti kahāpaṇakoṭiyā kahāpaṇakoṭiṃ paṭipādetvā santhari. Ye
analyzed: koṭi santharam kahāpaṇa koṭiyā kahāpaṇa koṭim paṭipādetvā santhari ye
translated: ‘He had a koṭisanthara spread’: he had it spread by spending a koṭi of kahāpaṇas for each kahāpaṇa.

original: tattha rukkhā vā pokkharaṇiyo vā tesaṃ parikkhepappamāṇaṃ gahetvā aññasmiṃ ṭhāne
analyzed: tattha rukkhāḥ vā pokkharaṇiyaḥ vā tesam parikkhepa ppamāṇam gahetvā aññasmim ṭhāne
translated: He measured off the extent of the trees and lotus ponds there and had them made in another place.

original: santharitvā adāsi. Evamassa aṭṭhārasakoṭikaṃ nidhānaṃ parikkhayaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: santharitvā adāsi evam assa aṭṭhārasa koṭikam nidhānam parikkhayam agamāsi
translated: and he gave it to the Buddha. Thus his treasure of eighteen koṭis was exhausted.

original: Kumārassa etadahosīti gahapatino evaṃ bahudhanaṃ cajantassāpi mukhassa vippasannākāraṃ disvā etaṃ ahosi. Koṭṭhakaṃ māpesīti sattabhūmikaṃ dvārakoṭṭhakapāsādaṃ māpesi.
analyzed: kumārassa etat ahosi iti gahapatino evam bahu dhanam cajantassa api mukhassa vippasanna ākāram disvā etam ahosi koṭṭhakam māpesi iti satta bhūmikam dvāra koṭṭhaka pāsādam māpesi
translated: The thought occurred to the youth: seeing the clear complexion of the householder’s face even though he was giving away so much wealth, this thought occurred to him. He had a gatehouse built: he had a seven-story gatehouse built.

original: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati jetavane vihāre kārāpesi…pe… maṇḍape kārāpesīti aparāhipi
analyzed: atha kho anāthapiṇḍikaḥ gahapati jetavane vihāre maṇḍape kārāpesi iti
translated: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika had dwelling places built in the Jeta Grove. … He had a pavilion built: he had other dwelling places built.

original: aṭṭhārasahi koṭīhi ete vihārādayo kārāpesi aṭṭhakarīsappamāṇāya bhūmiyā. Vipassissa🔽hi bhagavato punabbasumitto gahapati yojanappamāṇaṃ bhūmiṃ suvaṇṇiṭṭhakāsantharena🔽kiṇitvā vihāraṃ kārāpesi. Sikhissa pana sirivaḍḍho gahapati tigāvutappamāṇaṃ suvaṇṇayaṭṭhisantharena,
analyzed: aṭṭhārasahi koṭīhi ete vihāra ādayo aṭṭhakarīsa pamāṇāya bhūmiyā vipassissa  hi bhagavataḥ punar basumittaḥ gahapati yojana ppamāṇam bhūmim suvaṇṇiṭṭha kāsantharena  kiṇitvā vihāram kārāpesi sikhissa pana sirivaḍḍhaḥ gahapati tiga avuta ppamāṇam suvaṇṇa yaṭṭhi santharena
translated: … with eighteen koṭis he had these dwelling places built, etc., on land measuring eight karīsa. For when the Lord Buddha Vipassī🔽the householder Punabbasu, having bought land measuring a league with a piece of cloth worth a hundred thousand, had a dwelling place built. But when the Lord Buddha Sikhī🔽the householder Sirivaḍḍha, having bought land measuring three gavutas with a piece of cloth worth a hundred thousand, had a dwelling place built. When the Lord Buddha Vessabhū

original: vessabhussa sotthijo gahapati aḍḍhayojanappamāṇaṃ suvaṇṇaphālasantharena, kakusandhassa
analyzed: vessabhussa sotthijaḥ gahapati aḍḍha yojana ppamāṇam suvaṇṇa phāla santharena kakusandhassa
translated: the householder Sotthijja, having bought land measuring a half-league with a piece of cloth worth a hundred thousand, had a dwelling place built. When the Lord Buddha Kakusandha

original: pana accuto gahapati gāvutappamāṇaṃ suvaṇṇahatthipadasantharena, koṇāgamanassa uggo
analyzed: pana accutaḥ gahapati gāvuta ppamāṇam suvaṇṇa hatthi pada santharena koṇa āgamanassa uggo
translated: But the householder Accuta covered a distance of a gāvuta with gold pieces the size of elephant’s footprints,

original: gahapati aḍḍhagāvutappamāṇaṃ suvaṇṇiṭṭhakāsantharena, kassapassa sumaṅgalo gahapati🔽vīsatiusabhappamāṇaṃ suvaṇṇakacchapasantharena, amhākaṃ bhagavato sudatto gahapati
analyzed: gahapati aḍḍhagau utappamāṇam suvaṇṇiṭṭha kāsantharena kassapassa sumaṅgalaḥ gahapati  vīsati usabha ppamāṇam suvaṇṇa kacchapa santharena amhākam bhagavataḥ sudattaḥ gahapati
translated: the householder Ugga of Kotigāma a distance of half a gāvuta with gold pieces the size of chariot wheels, the householder Sumangala of Kāsī🔽a distance of twenty usabha with gold pieces the size of tortoise shells, and the householder Sudatta of our Blessed One a distance of eight kārīsa with gold pieces the size of kahāpaṇa coins, and had a monastery built.

original: aṭṭhakarīsappamāṇaṃ bhūmiṃ kahāpaṇasantharena kiṇitvā vihāraṃ kārāpesīti; evaṃ anupubbena
analyzed: aṭṭha karīsa ppamāṇam bhūmim kahāpaṇa santharena kiṇitvā vihāram kārāpesi iti evam anupubbena
translated: Thus the prosperity of the world gradually diminishes.

original: parihāyanti sampattiyoti alameva sabbasampattīsu virajjituṃ alaṃ vimuccitunti.
analyzed: parihāyanti sampattiyaḥ ti alam eva sabba sampattīsu virajjitum alam vimuccitum ti
translated: Therefore it is enough to be detached from all prosperity, enough to be liberated.”

original: 308. Khaṇḍanti bhinnokāso. Phullanti phalitokāso. Paṭisaṅkharissatīti pākatikaṃ karissati.
analyzed: khaṇḍanti bhinna ukāso phullanti phalita ukāso paṭisaṅkharissati iti pākatikam karissati
translated: “They split” means they are not continuous. “They burst” means they are continuous but burst open. “He will restore them” means he will make them ripe.

original: Laddhanavakammena pana bhikkhunā vāsipharasunikhādanādīni gahetvā sayaṃ na kātabbaṃ,
analyzed: laddha nava kammena pana bhikkhunā vāsi pharasu nikhādana ādīni gahetvā sayam na kātabbam
translated: But a monk who has obtained leave should not take axe, spade, and so on, and do the work himself.

original: katākataṃ jānitabbaṃ.
analyzed: kata akatam jānitabbam
translated: He should know what has and has not been done.

original: 310. Piṭṭhito piṭṭhito gantvāti thero kira gilāne paṭijagganto jiṇṇe vuḍḍhe saṅgaṇhanto
analyzed: piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ gantvā iti thero kira gilāne paṭijaggantaḥ jiṇṇe vuḍḍhe saṅgaṇhantaḥ
translated: Following behind, following behind: the Elder, it seems, was attending on the sick, looking after the old and infirm,

original: sabbapacchato āgacchati. Idamassa cārittaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “piṭṭhito piṭṭhito gantvā”ti.
analyzed: sabba pacchatas āgacchati idam assa cārittam tena vuttam piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ gantvā iti
translated: and so he came last of all. This was his practice. Hence it was said above: “Following behind, following behind. ”

original: Aggāsananti therāsanaṃ. Aggodakanti dakkhiṇodakaṃ. Aggapiṇḍanti saṅghattherapiṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: aggāsananti thera āsanam aggodakanti dakkhiṇa udakam agga piṇḍanti saṅgha tthera piṇḍam
translated: The chief seat: the Elder’s seat. The chief water: the water for the right hand. The chief alms: the alms of the senior Elder of the Community.

original: Antarā satthīnaṃ karitvāti catunnaṃ pādānaṃ antare karitvā.
analyzed: antarā satthīnam karitvā ati catunnam pādānam antare karitvā
translated: Having placed it between his feet: having placed it between the four feet of the bed.

original: 315. Patiṭṭhāpesīti aṭṭhārasakoṭipariccāgaṃ katvā patiṭṭhāpesi. Evaṃ sabbāpi catupaṇṇāsakoṭiyo pariccaji.
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpesi iti aṭṭhārasa koṭi pariccāgam katvā patiṭṭhāpesi evam sabbā api catupaṇṇāsa koṭiyaḥ pariccaji
translated: He established: he established it after giving eighteen koṭis. Thus he gave away all the fifty-four koṭis.

original: Vihārānujānanakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vihāra anujānana kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The discussion of the permission to build dwellings is finished.

original: Āsanappaṭibāhanādikathā🔽316. Vippakatabhojanoti antaraghare vā vihāre vā araññe vā yattha katthaci bhuñjamāno
analyzed: āsana paṭibāhana ādi kathā  vippakata bhojano ti antara ghare vā vihāre vā araññe vā yattha katthaci bhuñjamāno
translated: The discussion of the prohibition against reserving seats, etc.🔽One who has eaten what has been publicly exhibited: a bhikkhu who is eating in a house, in a monastery, or in the forest

original: bhikkhu aniṭṭhite bhojane na vuṭṭhāpetabbo. Antaraghare pacchā āgatena bhikkhaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: bhikkhu a niṭṭhite bhojane na vuṭṭhāpetabbaḥ antaraghare pacchā āgatena bhikkham gahetvā
translated: should not get up until the food has been concluded. If he goes to another house to get alms,

original: gantabbaṃ. Sace manussā vā bhikkhū vā “pavisathā”ti vadanti, “mayi pavisante bhikkhū
analyzed: gantabbam sace manussāḥ vā bhikkhū vā pavisatha ati vadanti mayi pavisante bhikkhū
translated: He should go. If people or monks say to him, “Come in,” he should enter and say this:

original: uṭṭhahissantī”ti vattabbaṃ. “Etha, bhante, āsanaṃ atthī”ti vuttena pana pavisitabbaṃ.
analyzed: uṭṭhahissanti iti vattabbam etha bhante āsanam atthi iti vuttena pana pavisitabbam
translated: He should go. If people or monks say to him, “Come in,” he should say, “If I come in, the monks will get up.” But if they say, “Come in, Venerable, there are seats,” he should go in.

original: Sace koci kiñci na vadati, āsanasālaṃ gantvā atisamīpaṃ agantvā sabhāgaṭṭhāne ṭhātabbaṃ.🔽Okāse kate “pavisathā”ti vuttena pana pavisitabbaṃ. Sace pana yaṃ āsanaṃ tassa pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: sace koci kiñci na vadati āsana sālam gantvā atisamīpam a gantvā sabhā gaṭṭhāne ṭhātabbam  okāse kate pavisatha ati vuttena pana pavisitabbam sace pana yam āsanam tassa pāpuṇāti
translated: If no one says anything, he should go to the assembly hall. Without going too close, he should stand in a suitable place.

original: tattha abhuñjanto bhikkhu nisinno hoti, taṃ uṭṭhāpetuṃ vaṭṭati. Yāgukhajjakādīsu🔽pana yaṃkiñci pivitvā vā khāditvā vā yāva añño āgacchati, tāva nisinnaṃ rittahatthampi
analyzed: tattha a bhuñjantaḥ bhikkhu nisinnaḥ hoti tam uṭṭhāpetum vaṭṭati yāgu khajjaka ādīsu  pana yaṃkiñci pivitvā vā khāditvā vā yāva aññaḥ āgacchati tāva nisinnam ritta hattham pi
translated: If an opening is made and he is told to come in, he should go in. But if the seat that comes to him is occupied by a monk who is not eating, he may make that monk get up.

original: vuṭṭhāpetuṃ na vaṭṭati. Vippakatabhojanoyeva hi so hoti.
analyzed: vuṭṭhāpetum na vaṭṭati vippakata bhojanoyā iva hi so hoti
translated: But if the monk is drinking rice porridge, fresh food, etc., or if he is sitting there after drinking or eating something, he should not make him get up, even if he is not holding anything in his hands.🔽For he is already a “person who has finished his meal”.

original: Sace vuṭṭhāpetīti sace āpattiṃ atikkamitvāpi vuṭṭhāpetiyeva. Pavārito ca hotīti yaṃ
analyzed: sace vuṭṭhāpeti iti sace āpattim atikkamitvā api pavāritaḥ ca hoti iti yam
translated: If he makes him get up: if he makes him get up, even though he has transgressed the rule. And he is one who has refused an invitation: if he has refused an invitation to partake of the meal.

original: so vuṭṭhāpeti, ayañca bhikkhu pavārito ca hoti, tena vattabbo – “gaccha udakaṃ āharāhī”ti.
analyzed: so vuṭṭhāpeti ayam ca bhikkhu pavārito ca hoti tena vattabbaḥ gaccha udakam āharāhi iti
translated: If he sends him away, and if the other monk has already participated in the invitation ceremony, then he should be told to go and fetch water.

original: Vuḍḍhatarañhi bhikkhuṃ āṇāpetuṃ idameva ekaṃ ṭhānanti. Sace so udakampi na āharati,
analyzed: vuḍḍhataran hi bhikkhum āṇāpetum idam eva ekam ṭhānan ti sace saḥ udakam pi na āharati
translated: Because it is proper for a more senior monk to order a junior monk to do this. This is the only instance. If he does not even fetch the water,

original: tato yañca navakatarena kattabbaṃ, taṃ dassento “sādhukaṃ sitthānī”tiādimāha.🔽Gilānassa patirūpaṃ seyyanti ettha yo kāsabhagandarātisārādīhi gilāno hoti, kheḷamallakavaccakapālādīni
analyzed: tatas yat ca navakatarena kattabbam tam dassento sādhukam sitthāni iti ādim āha  gilānassa patirūpam ettha yaḥ kāsa bhagandara atisāra ādīhi gilānaḥ hoti kheḷa mallaka vacca kapāla ādīni
translated: then the more junior monk should do what is proper for him to do. He says, “Please put away the bowl and robe,” and so on.🔽A suitable resting place for one who is sick: if someone is sick with a disease such as a cold, diarrhea, or dysentery, and he needs to spit, urinate, defecate, or wash,

original: ṭhapetabbāni honti. Kuṭṭhi vā hoti, senāsanaṃ dūseti; evarūpassa heṭṭhāpāsādapaṇṇasālādīsu
analyzed: ṭhapetabbāni honti kuṭṭhi vā hoti senāsanam dūseti evarūpassa heṭṭhā pāsāda paṇṇa sāla ādīsu
translated: he should be given a place that is suitable for that. If he is a leper, and he defiles the dwelling, then he should be given a place

original: aññataraṃ ekamantaṃ senāsanaṃ dātabbaṃ. Yasmiṃ vasante senāsanaṃ na dussati, tassa
analyzed: aññataram ekamantam senāsanam dātabbam yasmin vasante senāsanam na dussati tassa
translated: in a stilt house, a cave, or a building below the dwelling. If he does not defile the dwelling,

original: varaseyyāpi dātabbāva. Yopi sinehapānavirecananatthukammādīsu yaṃkiñci bhesajjaṃ
analyzed: varaseyyā api yaṃ kiñci bhesajjam
translated: then he should be given the best resting place. If he needs any kind of medicine, such as oil for anointing, a purgative, or a medicinal drink,

original: karoti, sabbo so gilānoyeva, tassāpi sallakkhetvā patirūpaṃ senāsanaṃ dātabbaṃ. Lesakappenāti
analyzed: karoti sabbaḥ saḥ gilānaḥ yā iva tassa api sallakkhetvā patirūpam senāsanam dātabbam lesa kappena ati
translated: If he does, he is sick. He should be given a suitable dwelling after he has been considered. If he is slightly sick:

original: appakena sīsābādhādimattena. Bhikkhū gaṇetvāti “ettakā nāma bhikkhū”ti vihāre bhikkhūnaṃ paricchedaṃ ñatvā.
analyzed: appakena sīsa ābādha ādi mattena bhikkhū gaṇetvā ti ettakāḥ nāma bhikkhū iti vihāre bhikkhūnam paricchedam ñatvā
translated: if he has a slight headache, etc. Having counted the monks: having determined the number of monks in the dwelling thus, “So many monks.”

original: Āsanappaṭibāhanādikathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āsana paṭibāhana ādi kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The discussion of the allocation of seats, etc. is finished.

original: Senāsanaggāhakathā
analyzed: senāsana ggāha kathā
translated: The discussion of the assigner of dwellings

original: 318. Seyyāti mañcaṭṭhānāni vuccanti. Seyyaggenāti seyyāparicchedena, vassūpanāyikadivase🔽kālaṃ ghosetvā ekamañcaṭṭhānaṃ ekassa bhikkhuno gāhetuṃ anujānāmīti attho. Seyyaggena🔽gāhentāti seyyāparicchedena gāhiyamānā. Seyyā ussārayiṃsūti mañcaṭṭhānāni atirekāni🔽ahesuṃ. Vihāraggādīsupi eseva nayo. Anubhāganti puna aparampi bhāgaṃ dātuṃ. Atimandesu
analyzed: seyyā ati mañca ṭṭhānāni vuccanti seyyaggena ati seyyā paricchedena vassūpanāyika divase  kālam ghosetvā eka mañca ṭṭhānam ekassa bhikkhuno gāhetum anujānāmi iti seyyaggena  gāhentā ati seyyā paricchedena gāhiyamānā seyyā ussārayiṃsū ti mañca ṭṭhānāni atirekāni  ahesum bhāgam dātum ati mandesu
translated: “Dwellings”: beds is what is meant. “By means of the best”: by means of the best selection. On the invitation day for entering the rainy-season residence

original: hi bhikkhūsu ekekassa bhikkhuno dve tīṇi pariveṇāni dātabbāni. Na akāmā dātabboti
analyzed: hi bhikkhūsu ekekassa bhikkhunaḥ dve tīṇi pariveṇāni dātabbāni na akāmā dātabbā uti
translated: I allow you to assign one bed to one monk.” “By means of the best selection”: being assigned by means of the best selection. “The best were chosen”: the beds were in excess. The same method applies to the best of the dwelling rooms, etc. “A share”: another portion. For if the monks are not too strict, two or three yards should be given to each monk. “Should not be given without their consent”:

original: anicchāya na dātabbo. Tattha vassūpanāyikadivase gahite anubhāge pacchā āgatānaṃ🔽na attano aruciyā so anubhāgo dātabbo. Sace pana yena gahito, so ca attano ruciyā
analyzed: an icchāya na dātabbaḥ tattha vassūpanāyika divase gahite anubhāge pacchā āgatānam  na attanaḥ aruciyā saḥ anubhāgaḥ dātabbaḥ sace pana yena gahito saḥ ca attanaḥ ruciyā
translated: It should not be given unwillingly. If the first part is taken on the day for entering for the Rains, then afterwards, if others come,

original: taṃ anubhāgaṃ vā paṭhamabhāgaṃ vā deti, vaṭṭati.
analyzed: tam anubhāgam vā paṭhama bhāgam vā deti vaṭṭati
translated: that first part should not be given to them unwillingly. But if he who took it gives it, either the first part or the second part, willingly, that is allowable.

original: Nissīme ṭhitassāti upacārasīmato bahi ṭhitassa. Anto upacārasīmāya pana dūre ṭhitassāpi
analyzed: nissīme ṭhitassa ati upacāra sīmataḥ bahi ṭhitassa antar upacāra sīmāya pana dūre ṭhitassa api
translated: To one who is not on the same boundary: to one who is outside the boundary of the monastery zone. But to one who is within the monastery zone, even if he is far away,

original: labbhatiyeva. Senāsanaṃ gahetvāti vassūpanāyikadivase gahetvā. Sabbakālaṃ paṭibāhantīti
analyzed: labbhatiyā iva senāsanam gahetvā ati vassūpanāyika divase gahetvā sabba kālam paṭibāhanti iti
translated: it is allowable. Having taken the lodging: having taken it on the day for entering for the Rains. For all the time:

original: catumāsaccayena utukālepi paṭibāhanti. Tīsu senāsanaggāhesu purimako ca pacchimako
analyzed: catu māsa cayena utu kāle pi paṭibāhanti tīsu senāsana ggāhesu purimako ca pacchimako
translated: they reserve it for four months, even for the season. In the three kinds of taking of a lodging, the first and the last

original: cāti ime dve gāhā thāvarā.
analyzed: cāti ime dve gāhā thāvarā
translated: are fixed.

original: Antarāmuttake ayaṃ vinicchayo – ekasmiṃ vihāre mahālābhasenāsanaṃ hoti. Senāsanasāmikā
analyzed: antarāmuttake ayam vinicchayaḥ ekasmin vihāre mahā lābha senāsanam hoti senāsana sāmikā
translated: This is the decision about that which is in between: in a certain monastery there is a lodging with a large endowment. The owners

original: vassūpagataṃ bhikkhuṃ sabbapaccayehi sakkaccaṃ upaṭṭhahitvā pavāretvā gamanakāle
analyzed: vassūpagatam bhikkhum sabba paccayehi sakkaccam upaṭṭhahitvā pavāretvā gamana kāle
translated: having respectfully attended on a monk who has entered for the Rains with all requisites, and having invited him, at the time of his going away

original: bahuṃ samaṇaparikkhāraṃ denti. Mahātherā dūratopi āgantvā vassūpanāyikadivase taṃ🔽gahetvā phāsuṃ vasitvā vutthavassā lābhaṃ gaṇhitvā pakkamanti. Āvāsikā “mayaṃ etthuppannaṃ
analyzed: bahum samaṇa parikkhāram denti mahā therāḥ dūratas pi āgantvā vassūpanāyika divase tam  gahetvā phāsum vasitvā vuttha vassāḥ lābham gaṇhitvā pakkamanti āvāsikāḥ mayam ettha uppannam
translated: They give the monks much requisites. The senior monks come from afar, and on the day for entering upon the rains🔽they take possession of the dwelling place, live there comfortably, and when the rains are over they take the gains and go away. The resident monks think, “We do not get the gains that arise here.

original: lābhaṃ na labhāma, niccaṃ āgantukamahātherāva labhanti, teyeva naṃ āgantvā paṭijaggissantī”ti
analyzed: lābham na labhāma niccam āgantuka mahā therāḥ ava labhanti teyeva nam āgantvā paṭijaggissanti iti
translated: The senior monks who come from afar always get them. They will come and look after it themselves.”

original: palujjantampi na olokenti. Bhagavā tassa paṭijagganatthaṃ “aparajjugatāya pavāraṇāya
analyzed: palujjantam pi na olokenti bhagavā tassa paṭijaggana attham apa rajju gatāya pavāraṇāya
translated: So they do not look after it. The Blessed One said that in order to look after it, “On the invitation day after next,

original: āyatiṃ vassāvāsatthāya antarāmuttako gāhetabbo”ti āha.
analyzed: āyatim vassa āvāsa atthāya antarāmuttakaḥ gāhetabbaḥ iti āha
translated: a dwelling place for the future rains should be taken possession of.”

original: Taṃ gāhentena saṅghatthero vattabbo – “bhante antarāmuttakasenāsanaṃ gaṇhathā”ti.
analyzed: tam gāhentena saṅgha ttheraḥ vattabbaḥ bhante antarāmuttaka senāsanam gaṇhatha ati
translated: When taking possession of it, the senior monk should be told, “Venerable sir, take possession of the dwelling place for the future.”

original: Sace gaṇhāti, dātabbaṃ; no ce eteneva upāyena anutheraṃ ādiṃ katvā yo gaṇhāti, tassa
analyzed: sace gaṇhāti dātabbam no ce etena iva upāyena ādim katvā yaḥ gaṇhāti tassa
translated: If he takes possession of it, it should be given to him. If not, then in the same way, starting with the next most senior, it should be given to whoever takes possession of it,

original: antamaso sāmaṇerassāpi dātabbaṃ. Tena taṃ senāsanaṃ aṭṭhamāse paṭijaggitabbaṃ. Chadanabhittibhūmīsu
analyzed: antamasaḥ sāmaṇerassa api dātabbam tena tat senāsanam aṭṭha māse paṭijaggitabbam chadana bhitti bhūmīsu
translated: even if he is only a novice. He should look after that dwelling place for eight months. The roof, the walls, and the floor

original: yaṃ kiñci khaṇḍaṃ vā phullaṃ vā hoti, taṃ sabbaṃ paṭisaṅkharitabbaṃ. Uddesaparipucchādīhi
analyzed: yam kiñci khaṇḍam vā phullam vā hoti tam sabbam paṭisaṅkharitabbam uddesa paripucchā ādīhi
translated: If the dwelling is completed by recitation and questioning, etc.,🔽it is allowable to spend the day there and to spend the night there.

original: divasaṃ khepetvā rattiṃ tattha vasitumpi vaṭṭati. Rattiṃ pariveṇe vasitvā tattha
analyzed: divasam khepetvā rattim tattha vasitum pi vaṭṭati rattim pariveṇe vasitvā tattha
translated: If one spends the night in the surrounding area and completes the dwelling by day,🔽it is allowable to spend the night there.

original: divasaṃ khepetumpi vaṭṭati. Rattindivaṃ tattheva vasitumpi vaṭṭati. Utukāle āgatānaṃ
analyzed: divasam khepetum pi vaṭṭati rattindivam tattha iva vasitum pi vaṭṭati utu kāle āgatānam
translated: It is allowable to spend the night there both by day and by night.🔽But if senior monks arrive during the rainy season,

original: vuḍḍhānaṃ na paṭibāhitabbaṃ. Vassūpanāyikadivase pana sampatte sace saṅghatthero
analyzed: vuḍḍhānam na paṭibāhitabbam vassūpanāyika divase pana sampatte sace saṅgha tthero
translated: they should not be refused. But if the day for entering upon the rains has arrived,

original: “mayhaṃ idaṃ senāsanaṃ dethā”ti vadati, na labhati. “Bhante, idaṃ antarāmuttakaṃ
analyzed: mayham idam senāsanam detha iti vadati na labhati bhante idam antarāmuttakam
translated: if the senior monk of the Community says, “Give me this dwelling,” he should not be given it. He should be told, “Venerable sir, this is an interim dwelling.

original: gahetvā aṭṭhamāse ekena bhikkhunā paṭijaggita”nti vatvā na dātabbaṃ. Aṭṭhamāse paṭijaggakabhikkhusseva gahitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: gahetvā aṭṭha māse ekena bhikkhunā paṭijaggitanti vatvā na dātabbam aṭṭha māse paṭijaggaka bhikkhussa iva gahitam hoti
translated: It has been accepted for eight months by a certain monk.” It is accepted by the monk who looks after it for eight months.

original: Yasmiṃ pana senāsane ekasaṃvacchare dvikkhattuṃ paccaye denti chamāsaccayena chamāsaccayena,
analyzed: yasmin pana senāsane eka saṃvacchare dvi kkhattum paccaye denti cha māsa cayena cha māsa cayena
translated: But if they give requisites twice a year in a dwelling, after six months and again after six months,

original: taṃ antarāmuttakaṃ na gāhetabbaṃ. Yasmiṃ vā tikkhattuṃ denti catumāsaccayena catumāsaccayena,
analyzed: tam antarāmuttakam na gāhetabbam yasmin vā tikkhattum denti catu māsa ccayena catu māsa ccayena
translated: He should not accept the one that is given every half-month.🔽Or the one that is given every four months,

original: yasmiṃ vā catukkhattuṃ denti temāsaccayena temāsaccayena, taṃ antarāmuttakaṃ na gāhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: yasmin vā catukkhattum denti temāsa cayena temāsa cayena tam antarāmuttakam na gāhetabbam
translated: or the one that is given every three months.🔽For he will get the approval by means of the requisite.

original: Paccayeneva hi taṃ paṭijagganaṃ labhissati. Yasmiṃ pana ekasaṃvacchare sakideva bahupaccaye🔽denti, etaṃ antarāmuttakaṃ gāhetabbanti. Ayaṃ tāva antovasse vassūpanāyikadivasena
analyzed: paccayena iva hi tam paṭijagganam labhissati yasmin pana eka saṃvacchare sakid eva bahu paccaye  denti etam gāhetabbanti ayam tāva antovasse vassūpanāyika divasena
translated: But he may accept the one that is given once a year.

original: pāḷiyaṃ āgatasenāsanaggāhakathā.
analyzed: pāḷiyam āgata senāsana ggāha kathā
translated: This, firstly, is the explanation of the acceptance of a dwelling during the Rains residence, according to the Dispensation, by the day on which the Rains is entered upon.

original: Ayaṃ pana senāsanaggāho nāma duvidho hoti – utukāle ca vassāvāse ca. Tattha utukāle
analyzed: ayam pana senāsanaggāhaḥ nāma duvidhaḥ hoti utu kāle ca vassa āvāse ca tattha utu kāle
translated: This acceptance of a dwelling is of two kinds, namely, for the season and for the Rains residence.

original: tāva keci āgantukā bhikkhū purebhattaṃ āgacchanti, keci pacchābhattaṃ paṭhamayāmaṃ
analyzed: tāva keci āgantukā bhikkhū purebhattam āgacchanti keci pacchābhattam paṭhama yāmam
translated: Herein, some incoming bhikkhus arrive before the meal, some after the meal, some in the first watch of the night,🔽some in the middle watch of the night, some in the last watch of the night.

original: vā majjhimayāmaṃ vā pacchimayāmaṃ vā ye yadā āgacchanti, tesaṃ tadāva bhikkhū uṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: vā majjhima yāmam vā pacchima yāmam vā ye yadā āgacchanti tesam tadā ava bhikkhū uṭṭhāpetvā
translated: Those who arrive when the bhikkhus are already asleep should be roused and given a dwelling.

original: senāsanaṃ dātabbaṃ. Akālo nāma natthi. Senāsanapaññāpakena pana paṇḍitena bhavitabbaṃ,
analyzed: senāsanam dātabbam akālaḥ nāma natthi senāsana paññāpakena pana paṇḍitena bhavitabbam
translated: He should give them. There is no wrong time. But the one who assigns the dwellings should be wise.

original: ekaṃ vā dve vā mañcaṭṭhānāni ṭhapetabbāni. Sace vikāle eko vā dve vā therā āgacchanti,
analyzed: ekam vā dve vā mañcaṭṭhānāni ṭhapetabbāni sace vikāle ekaḥ vā dve vā therāḥ āgacchanti
translated: He should set aside one or two places for beds. If one or two senior monks arrive at the wrong time,

original: te vattabbā – “bhante, ādito paṭṭhāya vuṭṭhāpiyamāne sabbepi bhikkhū ubbhaṇḍikā bhavissanti,
analyzed: te vattabbā bhante āditas paṭṭhāya vuṭṭhāpiyamāne sabbe api bhikkhū ubbhaṇḍikāḥ bhavissanti
translated: he should say, “Venerables, if we were to assign the dwellings from the beginning, all the monks would be upset.

original: tumhe amhākaṃ vasanaṭṭhāneyeva vasathā”ti.
analyzed: tumhe amhākam vasana ṭṭhāneya iva vasatha ati
translated: Please stay in our living quarters.”

original: Bahūsu pana āgatesu vuṭṭhāpetvā paṭipāṭiyā dātabbaṃ. Sace ekekaṃ pariveṇaṃ pahoti,🔽ekekaṃ pariveṇaṃ dātabbaṃ. Tattha aggisāladīghasālamaṇḍalamālādayo sabbepi tasseva
analyzed: bahūsu pana āgatesu vuṭṭhāpetvā paṭipāṭiyā dātabbam sace ekekam pariveṇam pahoti  ekekam pariveṇam dātabbam tattha aggisāla dīghasāla maṇḍalamāla ādayo sabbe pi tassa iva
translated: But if many arrive, he should assign the dwellings in order. If there are enough individual dwellings,🔽he should give them. In this case, the fire hut, the long house, the circular hut, the pavilion, and so on, all belong to the individual dwelling.

original: pāpuṇanti. Evaṃ appahonte pāsādaggena dātabbaṃ. Pāsādesu appahontesu ovarakaggena
analyzed: pāpuṇanti evam appahonte pāsāda aggena dātabbam pāsādesu appahontesu ovaraka aggena
translated: If there are not enough individual dwellings, he should give the stilt houses.🔽If there are not enough stilt houses, he should give the multi-storied buildings.

original: dātabbaṃ. Ovarakesu appahontesu seyyaggena dātabbaṃ. Seyyaggesu appahontesu mañcaṭṭhānena
analyzed: dātabbam ovarakesu appahontesu seyyaggena dātabbam seyyaggesu appahontesu mañca ṭṭhānena
translated: If there are not enough multi-storied buildings, he should give the beds.

original: dātabbaṃ. Mañcaṭṭhāne appahonte ekapīṭhakaṭṭhānavasena dātabbaṃ. Bhikkhuno pana ṭhitokāsamattaṃ
analyzed: dātabbam mañca ṭṭhāne eka pīṭhaka ṭṭhāna vasena dātabbam bhikkhuno pana ṭhita ukāsa mattam
translated: If there is not enough space for a bed, it should be given as space for a bench. But the space for a standing bhikkhu

original: na gāhetabbaṃ. Etañhi senāsanaṃ nāma na hoti. Pīṭhakaṭṭhāne pana appahonte ekaṃ mañcaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vā pīṭhakaṭṭhānaṃ vā vārena vārena gahetvā “bhante, vissamathā”ti tiṇṇaṃ janānaṃ
analyzed: na gāhetabbam etat hi senāsanam nāma na hoti pīṭhaka ṭṭhāne pana ekam mañca ṭṭhānam  vā pīṭhaka ṭṭhānam vā vārena vārena gahetvā bhante tiṇṇam janānam
translated: should not be taken. For that is not called a dwelling. If there is not enough space for a bench, then one space for a bed

original: dātabbaṃ, na hi sakkā sītasamaye sabbarattiṃ ajjhokāse vasituṃ. Mahātherena paṭhamayāmaṃ
analyzed: dātabbam na hi sakkā sīta samaye sabbarattim ajjhokāse vasitum mahā therena paṭhama yāmam
translated: or one space for a bench should be given by turns. After giving it, one should say, “Venerable sir, rest here.” For it is not possible to live all night in the open air in cold weather. The senior elder

original: vissamitvā nikkhamitvā dutiyattherassa vattabbaṃ – “āvuso, idha pavisāhī”ti. Sace
analyzed: vissamitvā nikkhamitvā dutiya therassa vattabbam āvuso idha pavisāhi iti sace
translated: should rest in the first watch of the night and leave. He should tell the second elder, “Friend, you enter here.” If the

original: mahāthero niddāgaruko hoti, kālaṃ na jānāti, ukkāsitvā dvāraṃ ākoṭetvā “bhante, kālo
analyzed: mahā theraḥ niddā garukaḥ hoti kālam na jānāti ukkāsitvā dvāram ākoṭetvā bhante kālo
translated: senior elder is drowsy and does not know the time, he should wake up and knock on the door and say, “Venerable sir,

original: jāto, sītaṃ anudahatī”ti vattabbaṃ. Tena nikkhamitvā okāso dātabbo, adātuṃ na labhati.
analyzed: jātaḥ sītam anudahati iti vattabbam tena nikkhamitvā okāsaḥ dātabbaḥ a dātum na labhati
translated: the time has come. It is cold and drizzling.” The other should leave and give him the space. He should not refuse.

original: Dutiyattherenapi majjhimayāmaṃ vissamitvā purimanayeneva itarassa dātabbaṃ. Niddāgaruko
analyzed: dutiya therena api majjhima yāmam vissamitvā purima nayena iva itarassa dātabbam niddā garukaḥ
translated: The second elder should also spend the middle watch in the same way and give the place to the other.🔽If he is sleepy, he should get up and pace up and down or do the meditation subject in the mind.🔽If he is still sleepy, he should lie down on his right side in the lion’s posture, with one foot overlapping the other, mindful and clearly comprehending, after which he can lie down to sleep.

original: vuttanayeneva vuṭṭhāpetabbo. Evaṃ ekarattiṃ ekamañcaṭṭhānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ dātabbaṃ. Jambudīpe🔽pana ekacce bhikkhū “senāsanaṃ nāma mañcaṭṭhānaṃ vā pīṭhaṭṭhānaṃ vā kiñcideva kassaci
analyzed: vutta nayena iva vuṭṭhāpetabbaḥ evam eka rattim eka mañcaṭṭhānam tiṇṇam dātabbam jambudīpe  pana ekacce bhikkhū senāsanam nāma mañca ṭṭhānam vā pīṭha ṭṭhānam vā kiñcid eva kassaci
translated: In this way the one place on the bed should be given to three people for one night.

original: sappāyaṃ hoti, kassaci asappāya”nti āgantukā hontu vā mā vā, devasikaṃ senāsanaṃ
analyzed: sappāyam hoti kassaci a sappāyanti āgantukāḥ hontu vā mā vā devasikam senāsanam
translated: But in India some bhikkhus, instead of being visitors, make their abode in a monastery and live there permanently. They take possession of a bed and chair and a place in the refectory and a place for easing nature’s needs, and they do not give them to visitors.

original: gāhenti. Ayaṃ utukāle senāsanaggāho nāma.
analyzed: ayam utu kāle senāsanaggāhaḥ nāma
translated: This is called “daily possession of a resting place.”

original: Vassāvāse pana atthi āgantukavattaṃ, atthi āvāsikavattaṃ, āgantukena tāva sakaṭṭhānaṃ🔽muñcitvā aññattha gantvā vasitukāmena vassūpanāyikadivasameva tattha na gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: vassāvāse pana atthi āgantuka vattam atthi āvāsika vattam āgantukena tāva saka ṭṭhānam  muñcitvā aññattha gantvā vasitu kāmena vassūpanāyika divasam eva tattha na gantabbam
translated: But there is a rule for visitors and one for residents in regard to the residence for the Rains.🔽The visitor should not go to the monastery on the invitation day, that is, on the day of the Uposatha, in order to take up residence there.

original: Vasanaṭṭhānaṃ vā hi tatra sambādhaṃ bhaveyya, bhikkhācāro vā na sampajjeyya, tena
analyzed: vasana ṭṭhānam vā hi tatra sambādham bhaveyya bhikkhā ācāraḥ vā na sampajjeyya tena
translated: For the place of residence may be crowded, or alms may not be available there, or he may not be able to get the use of a bed and chair.

translated: The first attachment is then abandoned. But if he thinks, “It will be comfortable there; I shall live there. If not, I shall return,” and he goes and finds it uncomfortable and returns, it is allowable.

translated: Here is the connected explanation: this five-fold requisites is not allowable to exchange for a field, a site, a tank, or a monastery.🔽But it is allowable to exchange one heavy thing for another heavy thing.🔽But it is not allowable to exchange a field, a site, a tank, or a monastery for the Community of Bhikkhus to consider or to consent to or to agree to.
