analyzed: senāsana paribhoge pana āmāsam pi anāmāsam pi sabbam vaṭṭati
translated: But in the case of furniture, all is allowed, whether it is heavy or not.

original: Vāsiādīsu yāya vāsiyā ṭhapetvā daṇḍakaṭṭhacchedanaṃ vā ucchutacchanaṃ vā aññaṃ mahākammaṃ
analyzed: vāsi ādīsu yāya vāsiyā ṭhapetvā daṇḍa kaṭṭha chedanam vā ucchutacchanam vā aññam mahākammam
translated: As to the razor, etc., the razor with which one cuts the hair, or the knife with which one cuts the nails, or the large tools such as an axe or a saw, etc.,

original: kātuṃ na sakkā, ayaṃ bhājanīyā. Tato mahattarī yena kenaci ākārena katā vāsi garubhaṇḍameva.
analyzed: kātum na sakkā ayam yena kenacid ākārena katā vā asi
translated: It cannot be used, it is a grave offense. More than that, even if it is made in some other way, it is a grave offense.

original: Pharasu pana antamaso vejjānaṃ sirāvedhanapharasupi garubhaṇḍameva. Kuṭhāriyaṃ pharasusadiso
analyzed: pana antamasaḥ vejjānam sirāvedhana pharasupi garu bhaṇḍam eva kuṭhāriyam pharasu sadisaḥ
translated: But an axe, even if it is an axe for blood-letting by a doctor, is a grave offense. An adze is similar to an axe.

original: eva vinicchayo. Yā pana āvudhasaṅkhepena katā, ayaṃ anāmāsā. Kudālo antamaso caturaṅgulamattopi
analyzed: eva vinicchayaḥ yā pana āvudha saṅkhepena katā ayam catur aṅgula mattaḥ api
translated: This is the decision. But if it is made in the form of a weapon, it is not a grave offense. A hoe, even if it is four fingerbreadths long,

original: garubhaṇḍameva. Nikhādanaṃ caturassamukhaṃ vā hotu doṇimukhaṃ vā vaṅkaṃ vā ujukaṃ
analyzed: garu bhaṇḍam eva nikhādanam catur assa mukham vā hotu doṇi mukham vā vaṅkam vā ujukam
translated: is a grave offense. A spade may have four sides or a mouth like a bowl, it may be bent or straight,

original: vā, antamaso sammuñjanidaṇḍakavedhanampi daṇḍabaddhaṃ ce, garubhaṇḍameva. Sammuñjanidaṇḍakhaṇanakaṃ
analyzed: vā daṇḍa baddham garubhaṇḍam eva sammuñjani daṇḍa khaṇanakam
translated: but if it is bound with a handle, it is a grave offense. But a spade for digging with a handle

original: pana adaṇḍakaṃ phalamattameva, yaṃ sakkā sipāṭikāya pakkhipitvā pariharituṃ, taṃ
analyzed: pana adaṇḍakam phala mattam eva yam sakkā sipāṭikāya pakkhipitvā pariharitum tam
translated: that is not bound, is just the size of a fruit, and can be carried around after being put into a bag,

original: bhājanīyaṃ. Sikharampi nikhādaneneva saṅgahitaṃ. Yehi manussehi vihāre vāsiādīni
analyzed: bhājanīyam sikharam pi nikhādanena iva saṅgahitam yehi manussehi vihāre vāsi ādīni
translated: it is not a grave offense. A pickaxe is also included in the spade. If people in a monastery have

original: dinnāni honti, te ca ghare daḍḍhe vā corehi vā vilutte “detha no, bhante, upakaraṇe,
analyzed: dinnāni honti te ca ghare daḍḍhe vā corehi vā vilutte detha naḥ bhante upakaraṇe
translated: If they say, “Venerables, give us the requisites.

original: puna pākatike karissāmā”ti vadanti, dātabbā. Sace āharanti, na vāretabbā; anāharantāpi na codetabbā.
analyzed: puna pākatike karissāma ati vadanti dātabbā sace āharanti na vāretabbā an āharantā api na codetabbā
translated: We’ll make new ones and give them to you,” they should be given. If they bring the old ones back, they should not be refused. And they should not remind them if they don’t.

original: Kammārataṭṭakāracundakāranaḷakāramaṇikārapattabandhakānaṃ adhikaraṇimuṭṭhikasaṇḍāsatulādīni
analyzed: kammāra taṭṭakāra cundakāra naḷakāra maṇikāra pattabandhakānam adhikaraṇi muṭṭhika saṇḍāsa tulā ādīni
translated: The tools of blacksmiths, weavers, carpenters, basket makers, potters, and garland makers, the weights and scales of those who work with weights and scales,

original: sabbāni lohamayaupakaraṇāni saṅghe dinnakālato paṭṭhāya garubhaṇḍāni. Tipukoṭṭakasuvaṇṇakāracammakāraupakaraṇesupi
analyzed: sabbāni loha maya upakaraṇāni saṅghe dinna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya garu bhaṇḍāni tipu koṭṭaka suvaṇṇakāra cammakāra upakaraṇesu pi
translated: all the iron tools are heavy goods from the time they are given to the Sangha. The tools of those who work with tin, gold, and leather

original: eseva nayo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – tipukoṭṭakaupakaraṇesupi tipucchedanasatthakaṃ, suvaṇṇakāraupakaraṇesu
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ tipu koṭṭaka upakaraṇesu pi tipu chedana satthakam suvaṇṇakāra upakaraṇesu
translated: are also like this. But there is this difference: the tools of those who work with tin include the tin saw and the knife. The tools of those who work with gold

original: suvaṇṇacchedanasatthakaṃ, cammakāraupakaraṇesu kataparikammacammachiddanakaṃ khuddakasatthakanti
analyzed: suvaṇṇa chedana satthakam cammakāra upakaraṇesu kata parikamma camma chiddanakam khuddaka satthakanti
translated: include the gold saw and the knife. The tools of those who work with leather include the knife for cutting raw hide and the small knife.

original: imāni bhājanīyabhaṇḍāni. Nahāpitatunnakāraupakaraṇesupi ṭhapetvā mahākattariṃ mahāsaṇḍāsaṃ
analyzed: imāni bhājanīya bhaṇḍāni ṭhapetvā mahā kattarim mahā saṇḍāsam
translated: These are goods that can be used as vessels. The tools of those who work with bath powder, oil, and ointments, except for the large knife and the large mortar,

original: mahāpipphalakañca sabbaṃ bhājanīyaṃ. Mahākattariādīni garubhaṇḍāni.
analyzed: mahā pipphalakam ca sabbam bhājanīyam mahā kattari ādīni garu bhaṇḍāni
translated: The large pipphali fruit is an object of use. The large axe, etc., are heavy goods.

original: Valliādīsu vettavalliādikā yā kāci aḍḍhabāhuppamāṇā valli saṅghassa dinnā vā tatthajātakā
analyzed: valli ādīsu vetta valli ādikā yā kāci aḍḍha bāhu ppamāṇā valli saṅghassa dinnā vā tattha jātakā
translated: As regards creepers, etc., any creeper, whether it is a bamboo creeper, etc., and whether it is given to the Community or grows there,

original: vā rakkhitagopitā garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti, sā saṅghakamme ca cetiyakamme ca kate sace atirekā
analyzed: vā rakkhita gopitā garu bhaṇḍam hoti sā saṅgha kamme ca cetiya kamme ca kate sace atirekā
translated: if it is guarded and protected, is heavy goods. If, after the Community transaction and the shrine transaction have been done, there is any left over,

original: hoti, puggalikakammepi upanetuṃ vaṭṭati; arakkhitā pana garubhaṇḍameva na hoti. Suttamakacivākanāḷikerahīracammamayā
analyzed: hoti puggalika kamme pi upanetum vaṭṭati arakkhitā pana garu bhaṇḍam eva na hoti suttamaka civāka nāḷikera hīra camma mayā
translated: it is allowable to take it to a personal transaction. But if it is not guarded, it is not heavy goods. A rope made of thread, of bark, of reed, of bamboo, of hide,

original: rajjukā vā yottāni vā vāke ca nāḷikerahīre ca vaṭṭetvā katā ekavaṭṭā vā dvivaṭṭā
analyzed: rajjukā vā yottāni vā vāke ca nāḷikera hīre ca vaṭṭetvā katā eka vaṭṭā vā dvi vaṭṭā
translated: or a harness, or a mat, or a mat made of reed or hide, whether it is single-woven or double-woven,

original: vā saṅghassa dinnakālato paṭṭhāya garubhaṇḍaṃ. Suttaṃ pana avaṭṭetvā dinnaṃ makacivākanāḷikerahīrā
analyzed: vā saṅghassa dinna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya garu bhaṇḍam suttam pana avaṭṭetvā dinnam maka civāka nāḷikera hīrā
translated: is heavy goods from the time it is given to the Community. But thread given without being woven, and bark, reed, bamboo, hide,

original: ca bhājanīyā. Yehi panetāni rajjukayottādīni dinnāni honti, te attano karaṇīyena
analyzed: ca bhājanīyāḥ dinnāni honti te karaṇīyena
translated: are objects of use. But those who have given these ropes, harnesses, etc.,

original: harantā na vāretabbā.
analyzed: harantā na vāretabbā
translated: may take them away for their own use without hindrance.

original: Yo koci antamaso aṭṭhaṅgulasūcidaṇḍamattopi veḷu saṅghassa dinno vā tatthajātako
analyzed: yaḥ koci antamasaḥ aṭṭhaṅgula sūci daṇḍa mattaḥ api saṅghassa dinnaḥ vā tattha jātakaḥ
translated: If anyone gives to the Sangha even a bamboo stick as much as eight inches long, or if it grows there,

original: vā rakkhitagopito garubhaṇḍaṃ, sopi saṅghakamme ca cetiyakamme ca kate atireko puggalikakamme🔽dātuṃ vaṭṭati. Pādagaṇhanakatelanāḷi pana kattarayaṭṭhi, upāhanadaṇḍako, chattadaṇḍo,🔽chattasalākāti idamettha bhājanīyabhaṇḍaṃ. Daḍḍhagehamanussā gaṇhitvā gacchantā na
analyzed: vā rakkhita gopitaḥ garu bhaṇḍam saḥ api saṅgha kamme ca cetiya kamme ca kate atirekaḥ puggalika kamme  dātum vaṭṭati pana upāhana daṇḍako chatta daṇḍo  chatta salākā ati idam ettha bhājanīya bhaṇḍam daḍḍha geha manussāḥ gaṇhitvā gacchantā na
translated: and if it is protected and guarded, and if it is a valuable thing, then, after the Sangha transaction and the shrine transaction have been done, it is allowable to give it over to an individual transaction.🔽But a bamboo tube for taking oil, a bamboo stick for a carrying pole, a walking stick for a pair of sandals, a stick for an umbrella,🔽and a bamboo pole for an umbrella—these are the things that are allowable. When people whose house has been burnt down are taking away,

original: vāretabbā. Rakkhitagopitaṃ veḷuṃ gaṇhantena samakaṃ vā atirekaṃ vā thāvaraṃ antamaso🔽taṃagghanakampi phātikammaṃ katvā gahetabbo. Phātikammaṃ akatvā gaṇhantena tattheva🔽vaḷañjetabbo, gamanakāle saṅghikāvāse ṭhapetvā gantabbaṃ. Asatiyā gahetvā gatena
analyzed: vāretabbā rakkhita gopitam veḷum gaṇhantena samakam vā atirekam vā thāvaram antamasaḥ  phāti kammam katvā gahetabbaḥ phāti kammam a katvā gaṇhantena tattha eva  vaḷañjetabbaḥ gamana kāle saṅghikā vāse ṭhapetvā gantabbam asatiyā gahetvā gatena
translated: they are not to be stopped. When someone is taking away a protected and guarded bamboo, he should take it after making amends for the value of it, whether it is equal to or more than the value of the bamboo.🔽If he takes it without making amends, he should be made to pay a fine on the spot. When he is going, he should put it in the Sangha dwelling place. If there is no dwelling place, he should take it away.

original: pahiṇitvā dātabbo. Desantaraṃ gatena sampattavihāre saṅghikāvāse ṭhapetabbo.
analyzed: pahiṇitvā dātabbaḥ desa antaram gatena sampatta vihāre saṅghikā vāse ṭhapetabbaḥ
translated: If he has gone to another country, he should give it after sending it. If he has gone to another country, he should put it in the Sangha dwelling place in the monastery where he has arrived.

original: Tiṇanti muñjaṃ pabbajañca ṭhapetvā avasesaṃ yaṃkiñci tiṇaṃ. Yattha pana tiṇaṃ natthi,
analyzed: tiṇanti muñjam pabbajam ca ṭhapetvā avasesam yaṃkiñci tiṇam yattha pana tiṇam natthi
translated: Grass: except for muñja grass and coir, any kind of grass. But where there is no grass,

original: tattha paṇṇehi chādenti; tasmā paṇṇampi tiṇeneva saṅgahitaṃ. Iti muñjādīsu yaṃkiñci
analyzed: tattha paṇṇehi chādenti tasmā paṇṇam pi tiṇena iva saṅgahitam iti muñja ādīsu yaṃkiñcid
translated: they cover it with leaves. Therefore leaves are included with grass. So any kind of grass,

original: muṭṭhippamāṇampi tiṇaṃ tālapaṇṇādīsu ca ekaṃ paṇṇampi saṅghassa dinnaṃ vā tatthajātakaṃ🔽vā bahārāme saṅghassa tiṇavatthuto jātatiṇaṃ vā rakkhitagopitaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti,
analyzed: tiṇam tāla paṇṇa ādīsu ca ekam paṇṇam pi saṅghassa dinnam vā tatthajātakam  vā baha ārāme saṅghassa tiṇa vatthutaḥ jāta tiṇam vā rakkhita gopitam garu bhaṇḍam hoti
translated: even as much as a handful of muñja grass, etc., or a single leaf, such as a palm leaf, etc., given to the Sangha, or grown there,🔽or grass grown from grass that was given to the Sangha in another monastery, if it is protected and guarded, is a heavy article.

original: tampi saṅghakamme ca cetiyakamme ca kate atirekaṃ puggalikakamme dātuṃ vaṭṭati. Daḍḍhagehamanussā
analyzed: tam pi saṅgha kamme ca cetiya kamme ca kate atirekam puggalika kamme dātum vaṭṭati daḍḍha geha manussā
translated: People who take it away after a dwelling has burned down

original: gahetvā gacchantā na vāretabbā. Aṭṭhaṅgulappamāṇopi rittapotthako garubhaṇḍameva.
analyzed: gahetvā gacchantā na vāretabbāḥ aṭṭha aṅgula ppamāṇaḥ api ritta potthakaḥ garu bhaṇḍam eva
translated: need not be stopped. Even a potsherd eight fingerbreadths across is a heavy article.

original: Mattikā pakatimattikā vā hotu pañcavaṇṇā vā sudhā vā sajjurasakaṅguṭṭhasilesādīsu
analyzed: mattikā pakatimattikā vā hotu pañca vaṇṇā vā sudhā vā sajju rasa kaṅguṭṭha silesa ādīsu
translated: Clay: whether it is ordinary clay or clay with five colors, or whether it is lime, or whether it is a clay pot, a clay saucer, a clay bowl, a clay water filter, a clay toy,

original: vā yaṃkiñci, dullabhaṭṭhāne ānetvā vā dinnaṃ tatthajātakaṃ vā rakkhitagopitaṃ tālaphalapakkamattaṃ🔽garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Tampi saṅghakamme ca cetiyakamme ca niṭṭhite atirekaṃ puggalikakamme
analyzed: vā yaṃkiñci dullabha ṭṭhāne ānetvā vā dinnam tattha jātakam vā rakkhita gopitam tāla phala pakka mattam  garu bhaṇḍam hoti tam pi saṅgha kamme ca cetiya kamme ca niṭṭhite atirekam puggalika kamme
translated: Or whatever is brought from a place where it is difficult to get, or given there, or guarded and protected there, even if it is only a palm-leaf hut,

original: dātuṃ vaṭṭati. Hiṅguhiṅgulakaharitālamanosilañjanāni pana bhājanīyabhaṇḍāni.
analyzed: dātum vaṭṭati hiṅgu hiṅgulaka haritāla manosilañjanāni pana bhājanīya bhaṇḍāni
translated: is heavy property. That too, when the work for the Sangha and the work for the shrine are finished, is allowed to be given over to individual use. But asafoetida, yellow orpiment, realgar, and collyrium are goods that can be used in common.

original: Dārubhaṇḍe yo koci aṭṭhaṅgulasūcidaṇḍamattopi dārubhaṇḍako dārudullabhaṭṭhāne saṅghassa
analyzed: dāru bhaṇḍe yaḥ koci aṭṭhaṅgula sūci daṇḍa mattaḥ api dāru bhaṇḍakaḥ dāru dullabha ṭṭhāne saṅghassa
translated: As regards wooden goods, any wooden goods whatsoever, even if only a stick for a tooth cleaner eight fingerbreadths long, given to the Sangha

original: dinno vā tatthajātako vā rakkhitagopito, ayaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ hotīti kurundiyaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dinnaḥ vā tattha jātakaḥ vā rakkhita gopitaḥ ayam garu bhaṇḍam hoti iti kurundiyam vuttam
translated: in a place where wood is difficult to get, or produced there, or guarded and protected there, is heavy property. This is said in the Kurundi.

original: Mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana sabbampi dāruveḷucammapāsāṇādivikatiṃ dārubhaṇḍena saṅgaṇhitvā
analyzed: mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam pana sabbam pi dāru veḷu camma pāsāṇa ādi vikatim dāru bhaṇḍena saṅgaṇhitvā
translated: But in the Mahā-Aṭṭhakathā, after including all kinds of wood, bamboo, hide, stone, etc., under wooden goods,

original: “tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa āsandiko uppanno hotī”ti ito paṭṭhāya dārubhaṇḍavinicchayo vutto.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa āsandikaḥ uppannaḥ hoti iti itas paṭṭhāya dāru bhaṇḍa vinicchayaḥ vutto
translated: the decision about wooden goods is given starting from the words, “Now on that occasion a couch was given to the Sangha” .

original: Tatrāyaṃ atthuddhāro, āsandiko, sattaṅgo, bhaddapīṭhaṃ, pīṭhikā, eḷakapādakapīṭhaṃ,🔽āmalakavaṭṭakapīṭhaṃ, phalakaṃ, kocchaṃ, palālapīṭhakanti imesu tāva yaṃkiñci khuddakaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam atthuddhāraḥ āsandikaḥ sattaṅgaḥ bhaddapīṭham pīṭhikā eḷakapādakapīṭham  āmalaka vaṭṭaka pīṭham phalakam koccham palāla pīṭhakanti imesu tāva yaṃkiñci khuddakam
translated: Here is the explanation of the meaning: a stool, a seven-strip bamboo chair, a good seat, a mat, a chair with legs of elephant tusks,

original: vā hotu mahantaṃ vā, saṅghassa dinnaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Palālapīṭhena cettha kadalipattādipīṭhānipi
analyzed: vā hotu mahantam vā saṅghassa dinnam garu bhaṇḍam hoti palāla pīṭhena ca ittha kadali patta ādi pīṭhāni pi
translated: a chair with legs of jujube wood, a plank, a couch, a straw mat. Of these, whatever is small or large, if it is given to the Sangha, it is a heavy article. The straw mat here includes mats of bread-fruit leaves, etc.

original: saṅgahitāni. Byagghacammaonaddhampi vāḷarūpaparikkhittaṃ, ratanaparisibbitaṃ, kocchakaṃ garubhaṇḍameva.🔽Vaṅkaphalakaṃ, dīghaphalakaṃ, cīvaradhovanaphalakaṃ, ghaṭṭanaphalakaṃ, ghaṭṭanamuggaro,🔽dantakaṭṭhacchedanagaṇṭhikā, daṇḍamuggaro, ambaṇaṃ, rajanadoṇi, udakapaṭicchako,
analyzed: saṅgahitāni vāḷa rūpa parikkhittam ratana parisibbitam kocchakam garubhaṇḍam eva  vaṅka phalakam dīgha phalakam cīvara dhovana phalakam ghaṭṭana phalakam ghaṭṭana muggaraḥ  danta kaṭṭha chedana gaṇṭhikā daṇḍamuggaraḥ ambaṇam rajana doṇi udaka paṭicchakaḥ
translated: A couch covered with tiger skin, surrounded by a tiger skin, and decorated with jewels is also a heavy article.🔽A curved knife, a long knife, a knife for washing robes, a knife for cutting grass, a hammer,🔽a key for cutting tooth cleaners, a staff with a hammer, a water filter, a dye container, a water strainer,

original: dārumayo vā dantamayo vā veḷumayo vā sapādakopi apādakopi samuggo, mañjūsā, pādagaṇhanakato
analyzed: dāru mayaḥ vā danta mayaḥ vā veḷu mayaḥ vā sa pādakaḥ api a pādakaḥ api sa muggaḥ mañjūsā pāda gaṇhana kato
translated: a mortar made of wood, ivory, or bamboo, with or without legs, a pestle, a fan, a foot wiper,

original: atirekappamāṇo karaṇḍo, udakadoṇi, udakakaṭāhaṃ, uḷuṅko, kaṭacchu, pānīyasarāvaṃ,
analyzed: atireka ppamāṇaḥ karaṇḍo udaka doṇi udaka kaṭāham uḷuṅkaḥ kaṭacchu pānīya sarāvam
translated: A large basket, a water-pot, a water-jar, a water-jug, a water-filter, a water-strainer,

original: pānīyasaṅkhoti etesupi yaṃkiñci saṅghe dinnaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ. Saṅkhathālakaṃ pana bhājanīyaṃ,
analyzed: pānīya saṅkhaḥ ti saṅghe dinnam garu bhaṇḍam saṅkhathālakam bhājanīyam
translated: a water-pot, a water-bowl: these are heavy articles given to the Sangha. But a water-pot with a handle is a light article.

original: tathā dārumayo udakatumbo.
analyzed: tathā dāru mayaḥ udaka tumbaḥ
translated: So too a wooden water-pot.

original: Pādakathalikamaṇḍalaṃ dārumayaṃ vā hotu coḷapaṇṇādimayaṃ vā sabbaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ. Ādhārako
analyzed: pāda kathalika maṇḍalam dāru mayam vā hotu coḷa paṇṇa ādi mayam vā sabbam garu bhaṇḍam ādhārakaḥ
translated: A foot-wiping cloth, a foot-wiping mat, whether made of wood or of cloth, rags, etc., is a heavy article. A stand

original: pattapidhānaṃ, tālavaṇṭaṃ, bījanī, caṅkoṭakaṃ, pacchi, yaṭṭhisammuñjanī muṭṭhisammuñjanīti
analyzed: patta pidhānam tālavaṇṭam bījanī caṅkoṭakam pacchi yaṭṭhi sammuñjanī muṭṭhi sammuñjanī iti
translated: for a bowl, a fan, a palm-leaf sunshade, a sunshade-handle, a sunshade-frame, a walking stick, a bamboo walking stick, a staff:

original: etesupi yaṃkiñci khuddakaṃ vā mahantaṃ vā dāruveḷupaṇṇacammādīsu yena kenaci kataṃ garubhaṇḍameva.
analyzed: etesu pi yaṃkiñci khuddakam vā mahantam vā dāru veḷu paṇṇa camma ādīsu yena kenacid katam garu bhaṇḍam eva
translated: whatever is small or large, made of wood, bamboo, leaves, leather, etc., is a heavy article.

original: Thambhatulāsopānaphalakādīsu dārumayaṃ vā pāsāṇamayaṃ vā yaṃkiñci gehasambhārarūpaṃ,
analyzed: thambha tulā sopāna phalaka ādīsu dāru mayam vā pāsāṇa mayam vā yaṃkiñci geha sambhāra rūpam
translated: A pillar, a scale, a ladder, a plank, etc., whether made of wood or of stone, any kind of household equipment,

original: yo koci kaṭasārako, yaṃkiñci bhūmattharaṇaṃ, yaṃkiñci akappiyacammaṃ, sabbaṃ saṅghe
analyzed: yaḥ koci kaṭasārakaḥ yaṃ kiñci bhūmattharaṇam yaṃ kiñci a kappiya cammam sabbam saṅghe
translated: a wooden mortar, a pestle, a threshing floor, a threshing roller, a winnowing fan, a broom, a broom of grass, a broom of chaff, a broom of husk, a broom of leaves, a broom of cow-dung: whatever is used for sweeping,🔽a mat, a mat of grass, a mat of leaves, a mat of bark, a mat of rush, a mat of coir, a mat of rags, a mat of wood shavings, a mat of bamboo splinters, a mat of rope, a mat of clay, a mat of plaster, a mat of resin, a mat of lacquer, a mat of grass, a mat of leaves, a mat of bark, a mat of rush, a mat of coir, a mat of rags, a mat of wood shavings, a mat of bamboo splinters, a mat of rope, a mat of clay, a mat of plaster, a mat of resin, a mat of lacquer, a mat of grass, a mat of leaves, a mat of bark, a mat of rush, a mat of coir, a mat of rags, a mat of wood shavings, a mat of bamboo splinters, a mat of rope, a mat of clay, a mat of plaster, a mat of resin, a mat of lacquer, a mat of grass, a mat of leaves, a mat of bark, a mat of rush, a mat of coir, a mat of rags, a mat of wood shavings, a mat of bamboo

original: dinnaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ, bhūmattharaṇaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Eḷakacammaṃ pana paccattharaṇagatikaṃ🔽hoti, tampi garubhaṇḍameva. Kappiyacammāni bhājanīyāni. Kurundiyaṃ pana “sabbaṃ mañcappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: dinnam garu bhaṇḍam bhūmattharaṇam kātum vaṭṭati eḷaka cammam pana paccattharaṇa gatikam  hoti tam pi garubhaṇḍam eva kappiya cammāni bhājanīyāni kurundiyam pana sabbam mañca ppamāṇam
translated: A heavy article is what is given, and it is allowable to make a floor-covering of it. But an elephant’s hide is a counter-quilt.

original: cammaṃ garubhaṇḍa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cammam garubhaṇḍam ti vuttam
translated: That too is a heavy article. The allowable hides are a personal possession. But in the Kurundi it is said: “All hides the size of a bed are heavy articles.”

original: Udukkhalaṃ, musalaṃ, suppaṃ, nisadaṃ, nisadapoto, pāsāṇadoṇi, pāsāṇakaṭāhaṃ, turivemabhastādi
analyzed: udukkhalam musalam suppam nisadam nisada poto pāsāṇa doṇi pāsāṇa kaṭāham turi vema bhasta ādi
translated: A mortar, a pestle, a mill, a bench, a bench leg, a stone trough, a stone pillow, a winnowing basket, a basket, a plough, a ploughshare, and so on,

original: sabbaṃ pesakārādibhaṇḍaṃ, sabbaṃ kasibhaṇḍaṃ, sabbaṃ cakkayuttakayānaṃ garubhaṇḍameva.
analyzed: sabbam pesakāra ādi bhaṇḍam sabbam kasi bhaṇḍam sabbam cakkayuttaka yānam garu bhaṇḍam eva
translated: all basket-work, all agricultural implements, all vehicles with wheels—all these are heavy articles.

original: Mañcapādo, mañcaaṭanī, pīṭhapādo, pīṭhaaṭanī, vāsipharasuādīnaṃ daṇḍāti etesu yaṃkiñci
analyzed: mañca pādaḥ mañca aṭanī pīṭha pādaḥ pīṭha aṭanī etesu yaṃkiñcid
translated: A bed leg, a bedstead, a chair leg, a chair-stead, the handle of a knife, axe, etc., of these

original: vippakatatacchanakammaṃ aniṭṭhitameva bhājanīyaṃ, tacchitamaṭṭhaṃ pana garubhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: aniṭṭhitam eva bhājanīyam pana garu bhaṇḍam
translated: whatever is unfinished carpentry is a personal possession, but when it is finished it is a heavy article.

original: hoti. Anuññātavāsiyā pana daṇḍo chattamuṭṭhipaṇṇaṃ kattarayaṭṭhi upāhanā araṇisahitaṃ
analyzed: hoti anuññāta vāsiyā pana daṇḍaḥ chattam uṭṭhi paṇṇam kattara yaṭṭhi upāhanā araṇi sahitam
translated: But the handle of the knife allowed, the handle of an umbrella, a fan, a walking stick, sandals, a fire-drilling stick together with the fire-drilling implements,

original: dhammakaraṇo pādagaṇhanakato anatirittaṃ āmalakatumbaṃ āmalakaghaṭo lābukatumbaṃ
analyzed: dhamma karaṇo pāda gaṇhanakataḥ anatirittam āmalaka tumbam āmalaka ghaṭaḥ lābuka tumbam
translated: A fruit-bowl, a fruit-pot, a myrobalan-bowl, a myrobalan-pot, a gourd-bowl,

original: lābughaṭo visāṇakatumbanti sabbametaṃ bhājanīyaṃ, tato mahantataraṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ.🔽Hatthidanto vā yaṃkiñci visāṇaṃ vā atacchitaṃ yathājātameva bhājanīyaṃ, tehi katamañcapādādīsu
analyzed: lābu ghaṭaḥ visāṇaka tumbanti sabbam etam bhājanīyam tatas mahantataram garubhaṇḍam  hatthi dantaḥ vā yaṃ kiñci visāṇam vā a tacchitam yathā jātam eva bhājanīyam tehi
translated: a gourd-pot, a horn-bowl, a horn-pot: all these are vessels. Anything larger than that is heavy goods.🔽An elephant tusk or any horn that is not cut is a vessel just as it grows. But if it is made into a bed leg, etc.,

original: purimasadisoyeva vinicchayo. Tacchitaniṭṭhitopi hiṅgukaraṇḍako añjanakaraṇḍako gaṇṭhikā
analyzed: purima sadisaḥ yeva vinicchayaḥ tad śita niṭṭhitaḥ api hiṅgu karaṇḍakaḥ añjana karaṇḍakaḥ gaṇṭhikā
translated: the decision is the same as before. A horn case, an ointment box, a string,

original: vidho añjanī añjanisalākā udakapuñchanīti idaṃ sabbaṃ bhājanīyameva.
analyzed: vidho añjanī añjani salākā udaka puñchanī iti idam sabbam bhājanīyam eva
translated: a horn spoon, an ointment stick, a water strainer: all this is a vessel.

original: Mattikābhaṇḍe sabbaṃ manussānaṃ upabhogaparibhogaṃ ghaṭapiṭharādikulālabhājanaṃ pattakaṭāhaṃ
analyzed: mattikā bhaṇḍe sabbam manussānam upabhoga paribhogam ghaṭa piṭhara ādi kulāla bhājanam patta kaṭāham
translated: In the case of earthenware, all the vessels used by people, such as a water pot, a bowl, a cooking pot, a saucer,

original: aṅgārakaṭāhaṃ dhūmadānakaṃ dīparukkhako dīpakapallikā cayaniṭṭhakā chadaniṭṭhakā
analyzed: aṅgāra kaṭāham dhūma dānakam dīpa rukkhakaḥ dīpaka pallikā caya niṭṭhakā chada niṭṭhakā
translated: a charcoal pan, a smoke-drying pan, a lamp stand, a lamp bowl, a heap of bricks, a heap of tiles,

original: thūpikāti saṅghassa dinnakālato paṭṭhāya garubhaṇḍaṃ, pādagaṇhanakato anatirittappamāṇo
analyzed: thūpikā ati saṅghassa dinna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya garu bhaṇḍam pāda gaṇhanakataḥ an atiritta ppamāṇaḥ
translated: a mound: from the time they are given to the Sangha they are heavy goods. A vessel that is not more than a cubit is a vessel.

original: pana ghaṭako pattaṃ thālakaṃ kañcanako kuṇḍikāti idamettha bhājanīyabhaṇḍaṃ. Yathā
analyzed: pana ghaṭakaḥ pattam thālakam kañcanakaḥ kuṇḍikā iti idam ettha bhājanīya bhaṇḍam yathā
translated: But the pot, the bowl, the saucer, the golden water-pot: these are the things that are to be used as vessels.

original: ca mattikābhaṇḍe; evaṃ lohabhaṇḍepi kuṇḍikā bhājanīyakoṭṭhāsameva bhajatīti ayamettha anupubbikathā.
analyzed: ca mattikā bhaṇḍe evam loha bhaṇḍe pi kuṇḍikā bhājanīya koṭṭhāsam eva bhajati iti ayam ettha anupubbi kathā
translated: And just as with earthenware vessels, so also with metal ones: the water-pot is to be used as a vessel. This is the consecutive explanation here.

original: Avissajjiyavatthukathā niṭṭhitā.🔽Navakammadānakathā
analyzed: avissajjiya vatthu kathā niṭṭhitā  nava kamma dāna kathā
translated: The Discussion of the Undisposed-of Articles is finished.🔽The Discussion of Giving Building Materials

original: 323. Bhaṇḍikāṭṭhapanamattenāti dvārabāhānaṃ upari kapotabhaṇḍikayojanamattena. Paribhaṇḍakaraṇamattenāti
analyzed: bhaṇḍika aṭṭhapana mattena ati upari kapota bhaṇḍika yojana mattena paribhaṇḍa karaṇa mattena ati
translated: As soon as the shelf is fixed: as soon as the pigeon-shelf is fixed above the door-posts. As soon as the plastering is done:

original: gomayaparibhaṇḍakasāvaparibhaṇḍakaraṇamattena. Dhūmakālikanti idaṃ yāvassa citakadhūmo🔽na paññāyati, tāva ayaṃ vihāro etassevāti evaṃ dhūmakāle apaloketvā katapariyositaṃ🔽vihāraṃ denti. Vippakatanti ettha vippakato nāma yāva gopānasiyo na ārohanti. Gopānasīsu
analyzed: gomaya paribhaṇḍaka sāva paribhaṇḍa karaṇa mattena dhūma kālikam idam yāvassa citaka dhūmaḥ  na paññāyati tāva ayam vihāraḥ etassa iva ati evam dhūma kāle apaloketvā kata pariyositam  vihāram denti vippakatanti ettha vippakataḥ nāma yāva gopānasiyaḥ na ārohanti gopānasīsu
translated: as soon as the cow-dung plastering or the lime plastering is done. As long as the smoke lasts: they give the dwelling as long as the smoke

original: pana āruḷhāsu bahukato nāma hoti, tasmā tato paṭṭhāya na dātabbo, kiñcideva samādapetvā
analyzed: pana āruḷhāsu bahukataḥ nāma hoti tasmā tatas paṭṭhāya na dātabbo kiñcid eva samādapetvā
translated: from the funeral pyre is visible, thinking, “As long as the smoke is visible, this dwelling belongs to him.” When it is finished: here what is “finished” is when the roof-ridge-poles have not yet been fixed. But when the roof-ridge-poles have been fixed, it is “much finished.” Therefore it should not be given after that. Having made some agreement,

original: kāressati. Khuddake vihāre kammaṃ oloketvā chappañcavassikanti kammaṃ oloketvā catuhatthavihāre
analyzed: kāressati khuddake vihāre kammaṃ oloketvā chappañcavassikanti kammaṃ oloketvā catuhattha vihāre
translated: If he is building a small dwelling, after inspecting the work, for four years if it is four cubits wide,

original: catuvassikaṃ, pañcahatthe pañcavassikaṃ, chahatthe chavassikaṃ dātabbaṃ. Aḍḍhayogo
analyzed: catu vassikam pañca hatthe pañca vassikam cha hatthe cha vassikam dātabbam aḍḍha yogo
translated: for five years if it is five cubits wide, for six years if it is six cubits wide. But if it is a double-tiered dwelling,

original: pana yasmā sattaṭṭhahattho hoti, tasmā ettha “sattaṭṭhavassika”nti vuttaṃ. Sace pana🔽so navahattho hoti navavassikampi dātabbaṃ. Mahallake pana dasahatthe ekādasahatthe
analyzed: pana yasmā satta ṭṭha hatthaḥ hoti tasmā ettha satta ṭṭhavassikan ti vuttam sace pana  saḥ nava hatthaḥ hoti nava vassikam pi dātabbam mahallake pana dasa hatthe ekādasa hatthe
translated: since it is seven or eight cubits wide, it is said here that it is for seven or eight years. But if it is🔽nine cubits wide, it may be given for nine years. But if it is a large dwelling, ten or eleven cubits wide,

original: vihāre vā pāsāde vā dasavassikaṃ vā ekādasavassikaṃ vā dātabbaṃ. Dvādasahatthe pana
analyzed: vihāre vā pāsāde vā dasa vassikam vā ekādasa vassikam vā dātabbam dvādasa hatthe pana
translated: it may be given for ten or eleven years. But if it is twelve cubits wide,

original: tato adhike vā lohapāsādasadisepi dvādasavassikameva dātabbaṃ, na tato uttari.
analyzed: tatas adhike vā loha pāsāda sadise pi dvādasa vassikam eva dātabbam na tatas uttari
translated: or more, even if it is like a palace of gold, it may be given for twelve years, not more than that.

original: Navakammiko bhikkhu antovasse taṃ āvāsaṃ labhati, utukāle paṭibāhituṃ na labhati.
analyzed: nava kammikaḥ bhikkhu antovasse tam āvāsam labhati utu kāle paṭibāhitum na labhati
translated: If a monk who is doing building work gets that dwelling during the rainy season, he is not allowed to reserve it for the time of the rains.

original: Sace so āvāso jīrati, āvāsasāmikassa vā tassa vaṃse uppannassa vā kassaci kathetabbaṃ
analyzed: sace saḥ āvāsaḥ jīrati āvāsa sāmikassa vā tassa vaṃse uppannassa vā kassaci kathetabbam
translated: If that dwelling is dilapidated, he should tell either the owner of the dwelling or someone in his family,

original: – “āvāso te nassati, jaggatha etaṃ āvāsa”nti. Sace so na sakkoti, bhikkhūhi ñātī🔽vā upaṭṭhāke vā samādapetvā jaggitabbo. Sace tepi na sakkonti, saṅghikena paccayena🔽jaggitabbo. Tasmimpi asati ekaṃ āvāsaṃ vissajjetvā avasesā jaggitabbā. Bahū vissajjetvā
analyzed: āvāsaḥ te nassati jaggatha etam āvāsanti sace saḥ na sakkoti bhikkhūhi ñātī  vā upaṭṭhāke vā samādapetvā jaggitabbaḥ sace te pi na sakkonti saṅghikena paccayena  jaggitabbaḥ tasmin pi asati ekam āvāsam vissajjetvā avasesāḥ jaggitabbāḥ bahū vissajjetvā
translated: “Your dwelling will be lost. You should look after it.” If he is unable to do so, then the monks should get his relatives

original: ekaṃ saṇṭhāpetumpi vaṭṭatiyeva.🔽Dubbhikkhe bhikkhūsu pakkantesu sabbe āvāsā nassanti, tasmā ekaṃ vā dve vā tayo vā
analyzed: ekam saṇṭhāpetum pi vaṭṭatiyā iva  dubbhikkhe bhikkhūsu pakkantesu sabbe āvāsāḥ nassanti tasmai ekam vā dve vā tayaḥ vā
translated: to look after it or his supporters. If they are unable, it should be looked after with the requisites belonging to the Community. If these are not available, then one dwelling should be given up and the rest looked after. It is quite allowable to give up many and keep one.

original: āvāse vissajjetvā tato yāgubhattacīvarādīni paribhuñjantehi sesāvāsā jaggitabbāyeva.🔽Kurundiyaṃ pana vuttaṃ “saṅghike paccaye asati eko bhikkhu ‘tuyhaṃ ekaṃ mañcaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: āvāse vissajjetvā tatas yāgu bhatta cīvara ādīni paribhuñjantehi sesa āvāsāḥ jaggitabbāya eva  kurundiyam pana vuttam saṅghike paccaye asati ekaḥ bhikkhu tuyham ekam mañcaṭṭhānam
translated: In a famine, when the monks have gone away, all the dwellings are lost. Therefore, after giving up one, two, or three dwellings, the rest should be looked after by those who remain and make use of the rice-gruel, meals, robes, etc., that belong to the Community.

original: gahetvā jaggāhī’ti vattabbo. Sace bahutaraṃ icchati, tibhāgaṃ vā upaḍḍhabhāgaṃ vā
analyzed: gahetvā jaggāhi iti vattabbaḥ sace bahutaram icchati ti bhāgam vā upaḍḍha bhāgam vā
translated: But in the Kurundi it is said that if there are no requisites belonging to the Community, one monk should be told, “Take charge of so many beds and benches and look after them.” If he wants more, a third or a half

original: datvāpi jaggāpetabbaṃ. Atha ‘thambhamattamevettha avasiṭṭhaṃ, bahukammaṃ kātabba’nti
analyzed: datvā api jaggāpetabbam atha thambha mattam eva itthā avasiṭṭham bahu kammam kātabbanti
translated: Even if he gives it, it should be looked after. If he says, “There is only the stump left. There is much work to be done,”

original: na icchati, ‘tuyhaṃ puggalikameva katvā jagga; evampi hi saṅghassa bhaṇḍakaṭṭhapanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: na icchati tuyham puggalikam eva katvā jagge evam pi hi saṅghassa bhaṇḍaka ṭṭhapana ṭṭhānam
translated: and he does not want to look after it, then he should be told, “Look after it as your own. In this way the Sangha will get a place to store its goods

original: navakānañca vasanaṭṭhānaṃ labhissatī’ti jaggāpetabbo. Evaṃ jaggito pana tasmiṃ jīvante
analyzed: navakānam ca vasana ṭṭhānam labhissati iti jaggāpetabbo evam jaggitaḥ pana tasmim jīvante
translated: and the new monks will get a place to live.” It should be looked after in this way. But if he dies while it is being looked after in this way,

original: puggaliko hoti, mate saṅghikoyeva. Sace saddhivihārikānaṃ dātukāmo hoti, kammaṃ oloketvā
analyzed: puggalikaḥ hoti mate sace saddhivihārikānam dātu kāmo hoti kammaṃ oloketvā
translated: it becomes the personal property of the deceased monk. If he wants to give it to his students, he should look at the work done

original: tibhāgaṃ vā upaḍḍhaṃ vā puggalikaṃ katvā jaggāpetabbo. Evañhi saddhivihārikānaṃ dātuṃ
analyzed: ti bhāgam vā upaḍḍham vā puggalikam katvā jaggāpetabbaḥ evam hi saddhivihārikānam dātum
translated: and have it looked after as the personal property of the deceased monk, either a third or a half. In this way he can give it to his students.

original: labhati. Evaṃ jagganake pana asati ‘ekaṃ āvāsaṃ vissajjetvā’tiādinā nayena jaggāpetabbo”ti.
analyzed: labhati evam jagganake pana asati ekam āvāsam vissajjetvā ati ādinā nayena jaggāpetabbaḥ ti
translated: If there is no one to look after it in this way, it should be looked after in the way beginning, ‘After giving up one dwelling.’”

original: Idampi ca aññaṃ tattheva vuttaṃ – dve bhikkhū saṅghikaṃ bhūmiṃ gahetvā sodhetvā saṅghikaṃ
analyzed: idam api ca aññam tattha eva vuttam dve bhikkhū saṅghikam bhūmim gahetvā sodhetvā saṅghikam
translated: And this is said here too: “Two monks took possession of Sangha land, cleared it, and built a dwelling there.

original: senāsanaṃ karonti. Yena sā bhūmi paṭhamaṃ gahitā, so sāmī. Ubhopi puggalikaṃ karonti,
analyzed: senāsanam karonti yena sā bhūmi paṭhamam gahitā saḥ sāmī karonti
translated: They make a dwelling. The one who first took possession of the site is the owner. If both make it their own,

original: soyeva sāmī. So saṅghikaṃ karoti, itaro puggalikaṃ karoti, aññaṃ ce bahuṃ senāsanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: saḥ yā iva sāmī so saṅghikam karoti itaraḥ puggalikam karoti aññam ce bahum senāsana ṭṭhānam
translated: he is the owner. If he makes it the Community’s, the other makes it his own, and if there is another site for a dwelling

original: atthi, puggalikaṃ karontopi na vāretabbo. Aññasmiṃ pana tādise paṭirūpe ṭhāne asati
analyzed: atthi puggalikam karontaḥ api na vāretabbaḥ aññasmin pana tādise paṭirūpe ṭhāne asati
translated: that is extensive, he should not be prevented from making it his own. But if there is no other suitable site,

original: taṃ paṭibāhitvā saṅghikaṃ karonteneva kātabbaṃ. Yaṃ pana tassa tattha vayakammaṃ
analyzed: tam paṭibāhitvā saṅghikam karontena iva kātabbam yam pana tassa tattha vaya kammam
translated: he should be prevented from doing so and it should be made the Community’s. But whatever work he has done there

original: kataṃ, taṃ dātabbaṃ. Sace pana katāvāse vā āvāsakaraṇaṭṭhāne vā chāyūpagaphalūpagarukkhā
analyzed: katam tat dātabbam sace pana kata āvāse vā āvāsa karaṇa ṭṭhāne vā chāyūpaga phalūpaga rukkhā
translated: should be given to him. If there are trees there that provide shade or fruit,

original: honti, apaloketvā hāretabbā. Puggalikā ce honti, sāmikā āpucchitabbā; no ce denti,
analyzed: honti apaloketvā hāretabbā puggalikā ce honti sāmikā āpucchitabbā no ce denti
translated: they should be removed only after consultation. If they are private, the owners should be informed. If they do not give permission,

original: yāvatatiyaṃ āpucchitvā “rukkhaagghanakamūlaṃ dassāmā”ti hāretabbā.
analyzed: yāvatatiyam āpucchitvā rukkha agghanaka mūlam dassāma ati hāretabbā
translated: they should be removed after informing them three times, saying, “We will give the value of the trees.”

original: Yo pana saṅghikavallimattampi aggahetvā āharimena upakaraṇena saṅghikāya bhūmiyā
analyzed: yaḥ pana saṅghika valli mattam pi aggahetvā āharimena upakaraṇena saṅghikāya bhūmiyā
translated: But if someone takes possession of even just a vine belonging to the Community and uses it for a site for a dwelling belonging to the Community,

original: puggalikavihāraṃ kāreti, upaḍḍhaṃ saṅghikaṃ hoti; upaḍḍhaṃ puggalikaṃ. Pāsādo ce
analyzed: puggalika vihāram kāreti upaḍḍham saṅghikam hoti upaḍḍham puggalikam pāsādaḥ ce
translated: If he builds a dwelling for an individual, half belongs to the Sangha and half to the individual. If it is a stilt house,

original: hoti, heṭṭhāpāsādo saṅghiko; upari puggaliko. Sace so heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ icchati, tassa
analyzed: hoti heṭṭhā pāsādaḥ saṅghikaḥ upari puggaliko sace saḥ heṭṭhā pāsādam icchati tassa
translated: the stilt house belongs to the Sangha, but the rooms underneath belong to the individual. If he wants the stilt house,

original: hoti. Atha heṭṭhā ca upari ca icchati, ubhayattha upaḍḍhaṃ labhati. Dve senāsanāni
analyzed: hoti atha heṭṭhā ca upari ca icchati ubhayattha upaḍḍham labhati dve senāsanāni
translated: it belongs to him. If he wants both the stilt house and the rooms underneath, he gets half of each.

original: kāreti – ekaṃ saṅghikaṃ, ekaṃ puggalikaṃ. Sace vihāre uṭṭhitena dabbasambhārena kāreti,
analyzed: kāreti ekam saṅghikam ekam puggalikam sace vihāre uṭṭhitena dabba sambhārena kāreti
translated: If he builds two dwellings—one for the Sangha and one for an individual—if he builds it with materials obtained by the Sangha,

original: tatiyabhāgaṃ labhati. Sace akataṭṭhāne cayaṃ vā pamukhaṃ vā karoti, bahikuṭṭe upaḍḍhaṃ🔽saṅghassa, upaḍḍhaṃ tassa. Atha mahantaṃ visamaṃ pūretvā apade padaṃ dassetvā kataṃ
analyzed: tatiya bhāgam labhati sace a kata ṭṭhāne cayam vā pamukham vā karoti bahi kuṭṭe upaḍḍham  saṅghassa upaḍḍham tassa atha mahantam visamam pūretvā a pade padam dassetvā katam
translated: he gets a third of it. If he builds it in an uninhabited area, on a site that he has cleared or that he has had cleared, then half belongs to the Sangha

original: hoti, anissaro tattha saṅgho.
analyzed: hoti anissaraḥ tattha saṅghaḥ
translated: and half to him. If he builds it by filling in a ravine, making it even all around, then the Sangha is not obliged to give it up.

original: Ekaṃ varaseyyanti ettha navakammadānaṭṭhāne vā vassaggena pattaṭṭhāne vā yaṃ icchati, taṃ ekaṃ varaseyyaṃ anujānāmīti attho.
analyzed: ekam varaseyyam ti ettha nava kamma dāna ṭhāne vā vassaggena patta ṭṭhāne vā yam icchati tam ekam varaseyyam anujānāmi iti attho
translated: One choice dwelling: in the case of a gift for repairs or a gift for the Rains-bathing ceremony, I allow you to choose one dwelling.

original: Pariyosite pakkamati tassevetanti puna āgantvā vasantassa antovassaṃ tasseva taṃ; anāgacchantassa pana saddhivihārikādayo gahetuṃ na labhanti.
analyzed: pariyosite pakkamati punar āgantvā vasantassa antovassam tassa iva tam an āgacchantassa pana saddhivihārika ādayaḥ gahetum na labhanti
translated: If he leaves while the robe-making ceremony is in progress, it is for the one who is staying there. If he does not return, then his pupils and so on do not get it.

original: Navakammadānakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nava kamma dāna kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Discussion of Giving Building Materials is finished.

original: Aññatrapaṭibhogapaṭikkhepādikathā🔽324. Nātiharantīti aññatra haritvā na paribhuñjanti. Guttatthāyāti yaṃ tattha mañcapīṭhādi,
analyzed: aññatra paṭibhoga paṭikkhepa ādi kathā  na atiharanti iti aññatra haritvā na paribhuñjanti yam mañca pīṭha ādi
translated: The Discussion of the Prohibition Against Taking Away, etc.

original: tassa guttatthāya, taṃ aññatra harituṃ anujānāmīti attho. Tasmā taṃ aññatra haritvā
analyzed: tassa gutta tthāya tam aññatra haritum anujānāmi iti tasmā tam aññatra haritvā
translated: “They do not take it away”: they do not use it after taking it away to another place. “For the sake of protection”: for the sake of protecting the bed, bench, etc. that are there. The meaning is: I allow you to take it away to another place. Therefore, if someone uses it after taking it away to another place

original: saṅghikaparibhogena paribhuñjantassa naṭṭhaṃ sunaṭṭhaṃ, jiṇṇaṃ sujiṇṇaṃ. Sace arogaṃ
analyzed: saṅghika paribhogena paribhuñjantassa naṭṭham su naṭṭham jiṇṇam su jiṇṇam sace arogam
translated: and using it as the Saṅgha’s furniture, then if it is lost or destroyed, it is not a loss to the owner. If it is broken, it is not badly broken. If it is not lost,

original: tasmiṃ vihāre paṭisaṅkhate puna pākatikaṃ kātabbaṃ. Puggalikaparibhogena paribhuñjato
analyzed: tasmin vihāre paṭisaṅkhate puna pākatikam kātabbam puggalika paribhogena paribhuñjataḥ
translated: then when that dwelling is dismantled, it must be made again. If someone uses it as his own furniture,

original: naṭṭhaṃ vā jiṇṇaṃ vā gīvā hoti, tasmiṃ paṭisaṅkhate dātabbameva. Sace tato gopānasiādīni
analyzed: naṭṭham vā jiṇṇam vā gīvā hoti tasmin paṭisaṅkhate dātabbam eva sace tatas gopānasi ādīni
translated: then if it is lost or broken, he is responsible. When it is dismantled, it must be given back. If from that dwelling he takes away a bed net, etc.,

original: gahetvā aññasmiṃ saṅghikāvāse yojenti, suyojitāni. Puggalikāvāse yojentehi pana mūlaṃ🔽vā dātabbaṃ, paṭipākatikaṃ vā kātabbaṃ chaḍḍitavihārato mañcapīṭhādīni theyyacittena🔽gaṇhanto uddhāreyeva bhaṇḍagghena kāretabbo. Puna āvāsikakāle dassāmīti gahetvā saṅghikaparibhogena
analyzed: gahetvā aññasmin saṅghika āvāse yojenti su yojitāni puggalika āvāse yojentehi pana mūlam  vā dātabbam paṭipākatikam vā kātabbam chaḍḍita vihārataḥ mañca pīṭha ādīni theyya cittena  gaṇhantaḥ uddhāreya iva bhaṇḍagghena kāretabbo puna āvāsika kāle dassāmi iti gahetvā saṅghika paribhogena
translated: If they are taken and used in another monastery belonging to the Community, they are properly used. But if they are used in a monastery belonging to an individual, the value must be paid for them🔽or they must be replaced. If the beds, benches, etc., are taken from a deserted monastery with the intention of stealing them, he is to be dealt with according to the rule for theft.

original: paribhuñjantassa naṭṭhaṃ sunaṭṭhaṃ, jiṇṇaṃ sujiṇṇaṃ. Arogañce pākatikaṃ kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: paribhuñjantassa naṭṭham su naṭṭham jiṇṇam su jiṇṇam arogañce pākatikam kātabbaṃ
translated: If they are taken with the intention of returning them at the time of re-occupation, and if they are used as furniture belonging to the Community, there is no offence. But if they are lost or destroyed or broken, he must make good the loss.

original: Puggalikaparibhogena paribhuñjantassa naṭṭhaṃ gīvā hoti. Tato dvāravātapānādīni saṅghikāvāse
analyzed: puggalika paribhogena paribhuñjantassa naṭṭham gīvā hoti tatas dvāra vāta pāna ādīni saṅghika āvāse
translated: If they are used as furniture belonging to an individual, he is responsible for the loss. Then the doors, windows, etc., which have been used in a monastery belonging to the Community

original: vā puggalikāvāse vā yojitāni paṭidātabbāniyeva.
analyzed: vā puggalikā vāse vā yojitāni paṭidātabbāni iva
translated: or in a monastery belonging to an individual, must be returned.

original: Phātikammatthāyāti vaḍḍhikammatthāya. Phātikammañcettha samakaṃ vā atirekaṃ vā agghanakaṃ mañcapīṭhādisenāsanameva vaṭṭati.
analyzed: phāti kamma atthāya ati vaḍḍhi kamma atthāya phāti kammam ca ittha samakam vā atirekam vā agghanakam mañca pīṭha ādi senāsanam eva vaṭṭati
translated: For the purpose of improvement: for the purpose of increasing. Herein, the improvement is allowable only if the value of the bed, bench, etc., is equal to or greater than the value of the original furniture.

original: Cakkalikanti kambalādīhi veṭhetvā katacakkalikaṃ. Allehi pādehīti yehi akkantaṭṭhāne
analyzed: cakkalikan ti kambala ādīhi veṭhetvā kata cakkalikam allehi pādehi iti yehi akkanta ṭṭhāne
translated: A mat means a mat made by plaiting together strips of grass, etc., and covering them with blankets, etc. With wet feet means with feet from which water drips down

original: udakaṃ paññāyati, evarūpehi pādehi paribhaṇḍakatabhūmi vā senāsanaṃ vā na akkamitabbaṃ.
analyzed: udakam paññāyati evarūpehi pādehi paribhaṇḍakata bhūmi vā senāsanam vā na akkamitabbam
translated: when they are lifted up. One should not step on a floor that is a store-room or on a dwelling with such feet.

original: Sace pana udakasinehamattameva paññāyati, na udakaṃ, vaṭṭati. Pādapuñchaniṃ pana
analyzed: sace pana udaka sineha mattam eva paññāyati na udakam vaṭṭati pāda puñchanim pana
translated: But if only a little water is clinging to the feet, not dripping down, it is allowable. But if the feet are wet with water for washing the feet,

original: allapādehipi akkamituṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Saupāhanena dhotapādehi akkamitabbaṭṭhāneyeva na vaṭṭati.🔽Coḷakena paliveṭhetunti sudhābhūmiyaṃ vā paribhaṇḍabhūmiyaṃ vā sace taṭṭikā vā kaṭasārako
analyzed: alla pādehi pi akkamitum vaṭṭatiyā iva sa upāhanena dhota pādehi na vaṭṭati  coḷakena sudhā bhūmiyam vā paribhaṇḍa bhūmiyam vā sace vā
translated: it is allowable to step on the foot-wiping cloth. It is not allowable to step on a place where it is proper to step with washed feet, with feet that are washed but still wet.

original: vā natthi, coḷakena pādā veṭhetabbā, tasmiṃ asati paṇṇampi attharituṃ vaṭṭati. Kiñci🔽anattharitvā ṭhapentassa pana dukkaṭaṃ. Yadi pana tattha nevāsikā anatthatāyapi bhūmiyā
analyzed: vā natthi coḷakena pādā veṭhetabbā tasmin asati paṇṇam pi attharitum vaṭṭati kiñci  an attharitvā ṭhapentassa pana dukkaṭam yadi pana tattha nevāsikāḥ bhūmiyā
translated: Having wiped the feet with a cloth means that if there is no mat or a piece of cloth on the floor of the store-room or on the floor of the dwelling, one should wipe one’s feet with a cloth. If that is not available, it is allowable to wipe the feet on a leaf.

original: ṭhapenti, adhotapādehipi vaḷañjenti, tatheva vaḷañjetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vaḷañjenti tathā iva vaḷañjetum vaṭṭati
translated: But if one leaves the place without wiping the feet, there is an offence of wrong-doing. But if the residents of the monastery wipe their feet on the floor even though it is not wiped, and if they step on the floor with wet feet, it is allowable to step on it in the same way.

original: Na bhikkhave parikammakatā bhittīti setabhitti vā cittakammakatā vā. Na kevalañca🔽bhittimeva, dvārampi vātapānampi apassenaphalakampi pāsāṇatthambhampi rukkhatthambhampi
analyzed: na bhikkhave parikammaka tā bhitti iti seta bhitti vā citta kammaka tā vā na kevalam ca  bhittim eva dvāram pi vāta pānam pi apassena phalakam pi pāsāṇa tthambham pi rukkha tthambham pi
translated: Not a wall that has been prepared: not a plastered wall or one with paintings on it.

original: cīvarena vā kenaci vā appaṭicchādetvā apassayituṃ na labbhatiyeva.
analyzed: cīvarena vā kenaci vā a paṭicchādetvā a passayitum na labbhatiyā iva
translated: And not only a wall: one must not urinate or excrete on a door, a window, a drainpipe, a stone pillar, or a wooden pillar, without first covering them with something.

original: Dhotapādakāti dhotapādakā hutvā dhotehi pādehi akkamitabbaṭṭhāne nipajjituṃ kukkuccāyanti.
analyzed: dhota pādakā ati dhota pādakā hutvā dhotehi pādehi akkamitabba ṭṭhāne nipajjitum kukkuccāyanti
translated: With washed feet: they are scrupulous about lying down in a place where one should step with washed feet.

original: “Dhotapādake”tipi pāṭho. Dhotehi pādehi akkamitabbaṭṭhānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Paccattharitvāti
analyzed: dhota pādaka itipi pāṭhaḥ dhotehi pādehi akkamitabba ṭṭhānassa etam adhivacanam paccattharitvā iti

original: paribhaṇḍakataṃ bhūmiṃ vā bhūmattharaṇasenāsanaṃ vā saṅghikamañcapīṭhaṃ vā attano🔽santakena paccattharaṇena paccattharitvāva nipajjitabbaṃ. Sace niddāyatopi paccattharaṇe
analyzed: paribhaṇḍakatam bhūmim vā bhūmattharaṇa senāsanam vā saṅghika mañca pīṭham vā  santakena paccattharaṇena paccattharitvā ava nipajjitabbam sace niddāyataḥ api paccattharaṇe
translated: Having spread out: having spread out a mat on the ground that has been swept clean, or a bedspread on a bed belonging to the Sangha, or his own mat or bedspread.

analyzed: saṅkuṭite koci sarīra avayavaḥ mañcam vā pīṭham vā phusati āpattiyā iva lomesu pana
translated: If, while lying down, his body touches the bed or bench because the mat or bedspread has slipped, he commits an offense. But if the bed or bench is covered with grass or leaves,

original: lomagaṇanāya āpattiyeva. Paribhogasīsena apassayantassāpi eseva nayo. Hatthatalapādatalehi
analyzed: loma gaṇanāya āpattiyā iva paribhoga sīsena a passayantassa api esa iva nayaḥ hattha tala pāda talehi
translated: If he counts the hairs, he commits an offense. The same applies if he is not looking for a fault but is just enjoying the sensation.🔽But it is allowable to touch the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.

original: pana phusituṃ vā akkamituṃ vā vaṭṭati. Mañcapīṭhaṃ nīharantassa kāye paṭihaññati, anāpatti.
analyzed: pana phusitum vā akkamitum vā vaṭṭati mañca pīṭham nīharantassa kāye paṭihaññati anāpatti
translated: If he is taking out a bed or a bench and it touches his body, there is no offense.

original: Aññatraparibhogapaṭikkhepādikathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aññatra paribhoga paṭikkhepa ādi kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The discussion of the prohibition against using other than the proper posture, etc. is finished.

analyzed: pattāni yasmā pana te sace pi dubbhikkhe na sakkonti subhikkhe jāte pana puna saṅgha bhattam

analyzed: kātum sakkhissanti tasmai bhagavā tam pi antar katvā anujānāmi bhikkhave saṅgha bhattam

analyzed: uddesa bhattanti ādim āha  tattha saṅgha bhatte ṭhitikā nāma natthi tasmai amhākam ajja dasa dvādasa divasā

analyzed: amhehi na laddham idāni tam amhākam gāhetha ati evam pi vattum na labbhati tat hi

analyzed: saṅgha bhatta ādi anujānana kathā niṭṭhitā

analyzed: alasa jātikā mahā therā pacchā āgacchanti bhante vīsati vassānam tumhākam
translated: if senior elders who are lazy come later, they should not be told, “Venerable sirs, the standing invitation of twenty years is being taken. Your

original: ṭhitikā atikkantā”ti na vattabbā, ṭhitikaṃ ṭhapetvā tesaṃ gāhetvā pacchā ṭhitikāya🔽gāhetabbaṃ. “Asukavihāre bahuṃ uddesabhattaṃ uppanna”nti sutvā yojanantarikavihāratopi
analyzed: ṭhitikā atikkantā ati na vattabbā ṭhitikam ṭhapetvā tesam gāhetvā pacchā ṭhitikāya  gāhetabbam asuka vihāre bahum uddesa bhattam uppannanti sutvā yojana ntarika vihārataḥ pi
translated: standing invitation has been exceeded.” The standing invitation should be set aside and it should be taken for them. Afterwards the standing invitation

original: bhikkhū āgacchanti, sampattasampattānaṃ ṭhitaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya gāhetabbaṃ. Asampattānampi
analyzed: bhikkhū āgacchanti sampatta sampattānam ṭhita ṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya gāhetabbam a sampattānam pi
translated: should be taken. If they hear that “Much invitation-food has arisen in such-and-such a monastery,” bhikkhus come from monasteries ten leagues away. It should be taken from the place where those who have arrived have stood. As regards those who have not arrived,

original: upacārasīmaṃ paviṭṭhānaṃ antevāsikādīsu gaṇhantesu gāhetabbameva. Bahiupacārasīmāya
analyzed: upacāra sīmam paviṭṭhānam antevāsika ādīsu gaṇhantesu gāhetabbam eva bahi upacāra sīmāya
translated: If they are taking it from the pupils, etc., who have entered the threshold, it should be taken.

original: ṭhitānaṃ gāhethāti vadanti, na gāhetabbaṃ. Sace pana upacārasīmaṃ okkantehi ekābaddhā
analyzed: ṭhitānam gāhetha iti vadanti na gāhetabbam sace pana upacāra sīmam okkantehi eka ābaddhā
translated: They say that it should be taken from those who are outside the threshold. But it should not be taken. But if they have come within the threshold and they are all together,

original: hutvā attano vihāradvāre vā antovihāreyeva vā honti, parisāvasena vaḍḍhitā nāma sīmā
analyzed: hutvā vihāra dvāre vā vā honti parisā vasena vaḍḍhitā nāma sīmā
translated: and they are in the monastery door or inside the monastery, then the territory is extended by the assembly and is called “extended territory.”

original: hoti, tasmā gāhetabbaṃ. Saṅghanavakassa dinnepi pacchā āgatānaṃ gāhetabbameva. Dutiyabhāge
analyzed: hoti tasmā gāhetabbam saṅgha navakassa dinne pi pacchā āgatānam gāhetabbam eva dutiya bhāge
translated: So it should be taken. And it should also be taken by those who come later if it has been given to the senior monk.

original: pana therāsanaṃ āruḷhe puna āgatānaṃ paṭhamabhāgo na pāpuṇāti, dutiyabhāgato vassaggena gāhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana thera āsanam āruḷhe puna āgatānam paṭhama bhāgaḥ na pāpuṇāti dutiya bhāgataḥ vassaggena gāhetabbam
translated: But when the senior monk has gone up to the senior seat in the second part, those who come later do not get a share of the first part. They should take it from the second part.

original: Ekasmiṃ vihāre ekaṃ bhattuddesaṭṭhānaṃ paricchinditvā gāvutappamāṇāyapi upacārasīmāya
analyzed: ekasmin vihāre ekam bhattuddesaṭṭhānam paricchinditvā upacāra sīmāya
translated: In one monastery, after defining one place for the announcement of almsfood,🔽the almsfood announced anywhere within the threshold, even if it is a league in extent,

original: yattha katthaci ārocitaṃ uddesabhattaṃ, tasmiṃyeva bhattuddesaṭṭhāne gāhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: yattha katthaci ārocitam uddesa bhattam tasmin yeva bhatta uddesaṭṭhāne gāhetabbam
translated: should be taken in that very place where the announcement of almsfood was made.

original: Eko ekassa bhikkhuno pahiṇāti “svepi saṅghato uddisitvā dasa bhikkhū pahiṇathā”ti,
analyzed: ekaḥ ekassa bhikkhunaḥ pahiṇāti sve api saṅghataḥ uddisitvā dasa bhikkhū pahiṇatha ati
translated: One sends to one monk, “Send ten monks tomorrow after announcing it to the Sangha.”

original: tena so attho bhattuddesakassa ārocetabbo. Sace taṃ divasaṃ pamussati, dutiyadivase
analyzed: tena saḥ atthaḥ bhattuddesakassa ārocetabbo sace tam divasam pamussati dutiya divase
translated: He should then inform the one who has been appointed to announce the meal. If he forgets on that day,

original: pātova ārocetabbo. Atha pamussitvāva piṇḍāya pavisanto sarati, yāva upacārasīmaṃ
analyzed: ārocetabbo atha pamussitvā ava piṇḍāya pavisanto sarati yāva upacāra sīmam
translated: he should inform him the following day. If he remembers when he has already entered the village for alms,

original: nātikkamati, tāva yā bhojanasālāya pakatiṭṭhitikā, tassāyeva vasena gāhetabbaṃ. Sacepi
analyzed: na atikkamati tāva yā bhojanasālāya pakatiṭṭhitikā tassāya iva vasena gāhetabbam sace pi
translated: as long as he does not go beyond the vicinity of the monastery, he should accept the meal according to the original arrangement. If

original: upacārasīmaṃ atikkantā bhikkhū ca upacārasīmaṭṭhakehi ekābaddhā honti, aññamaññaṃ🔽dvādasahatthantaraṃ avijahitvā gacchanti, pakatiṭṭhitikāya vasena gāhetabbaṃ. Bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: upacāra sīmam atikkantāḥ bhikkhū ca upacāra sīmaṭṭhakehi ekābaddhāḥ honti aññamaññam  dvādasa hatthantaram a vijahitvā gacchanti pakatiṭṭhitikāya vasena gāhetabbam bhikkhūnam
translated: the monks have gone beyond the vicinity of the monastery, but they are still connected with those who are within the vicinity,🔽and they have not gone more than twelve yards apart, he should accept the meal according to the original arrangement. But if

original: pana tādise ekābaddhe asati bahiupacārasīmāya yasmiṃ ṭhāne sarati, tattha navaṃ ṭhitikaṃ
analyzed: pana tādise eka ābaddhe asati bahi upacāra sīmāya yasmin ṭhāne sarati tattha navam ṭhitikam
translated: the monks are not connected in this way, he should make a new arrangement at the place where he remembers, outside the vicinity of the monastery,

original: katvā gāhetabbaṃ. Antogāme āsanasālāya sarantena āsanasālāya ṭhitikāya gāhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: katvā gāhetabbam antogāme āsanasālāya sarantena āsanasālāya ṭhitikāya gāhetabbam
translated: and accept the meal according to that. If he remembers in the village, in the assembly hall, he should accept the meal according to the arrangement for the assembly hall.

original: Yattha katthaci saritvā gāhetabbameva, agāhetuṃ na vaṭṭati. Na hi etaṃ dutiyadivase labbhatīti.
analyzed: yattha katthaci saritvā gāhetabbam eva a gāhetum na vaṭṭati na hi etam dutiya divase labbhati iti
translated: He should accept the meal wherever he remembers. He must not fail to accept it, thinking, “It is not possible on the second day.”

original: Sace sakavihārato aññaṃ vihāraṃ gacchante bhikkhū disvā koci uddesabhattaṃ uddisāpeti,🔽yāva antoupacāre vā upacārasīmaṭṭhakehi saddhiṃ vuttanayena ekābaddhā vā honti, tāva
analyzed: sace saka vihārataḥ aññam vihāram gacchante bhikkhū disvā koci uddesa bhattam uddisāpeti  yāva antoupacāre vā upacāra sīmaṭṭhakehi saddhim vutta nayena eka ābaddhāḥ vā honti tāva
translated: If, when he is going to another monastery from his own, he sees monks and they invite him for a meal,

original: sakavihāre ṭhitikāvaseneva gāhetabbaṃ. Bahiupacāre ṭhitānaṃ dinnaṃ pana “saṅghato🔽bhante ettake nāma bhikkhū uddisathā”ti vutte sampattānaṃ gāhetabbaṃ. Tattha dvādasahatthantaraṃ
analyzed: saka vihāre ṭhitikā vasena iva gāhetabbam bahi upacāre ṭhitānam dinnam pana saṅghato  bhante ettake nāma bhikkhū uddisatha iti vutte sampattānam gāhetabbam tattha dvādasa hatthantaram
translated: then as long as he is in the same communion with them, as described under the section on the monastery, he should accept it on the basis of the continuity of the observance-day ceremony in his own monastery.🔽But if it is given to those who are outside the enclosure, it should be accepted by those who have arrived after informing the Order thus, “Venerable sirs, please invite so many monks.”

original: avijahitvā ekābaddhanayena dūre ṭhitāpi sampattāyevāti veditabbaṃ. Sace yaṃ vihāraṃ
analyzed: a vijahitvā eka ābaddha nayena dūre ṭhitā api sampattāya iva ati veditabbam sace yam vihāram
translated: And here it should be understood that those who are standing outside the enclosure without an interval of twelve hatthas are “those who have arrived.”

original: gacchanti, tattha paviṭṭhānaṃ ārocenti, tassa vihārassa ṭhitikāvasena gāhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: gacchanti tattha paviṭṭhānam ārocenti tassa vihārassa ṭhitikā vasena gāhetabbam
translated: If they inform those who have entered the monastery where he is going, he should accept it on the basis of the continuity of the observance-day ceremony in that monastery.

original: Sacepi gāmadvāre vā vīthiyaṃ vā catukke vā antaraghare vā bhikkhū disvā koci saṅghuddesaṃ🔽āroceti, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne antoupacāragatānaṃ gāhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sace pi gāma dvāre vā vīthiyam vā catukke vā antaraghare vā bhikkhū disvā koci saṅgha uddesam 🔽āroceti tasmim tasmim ṭhāne antar upacāra gatānam gāhetabbam
translated: If, on seeing monks at the village gate or in the street or at the crossroads or in a house, someone announces the Order’s invitation, it should be accepted by those who have gone into the enclosure there.

original: Gharūpacāro cettha “ekaṃ gharaṃ ekūpacāraṃ, ekaṃ gharaṃ nānūpacāraṃ, nānāgharaṃ ekūpacāraṃ,
analyzed: ghara upacāro ca ittha ekam gharam eka upacāram ekam gharam nānā upacāram nānā gharam eka upacāram
translated: Herein, the definition of a house-to-house is to be understood in this way: “One house, one perambulation; one house, several perambulations; several houses, one perambulation;

original: nānāgharaṃ nānūpacāra”nti imesaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tattha yaṃ ekakulassa gharaṃ ekavaḷañjaṃ🔽hoti, taṃ suppapātaparicchedassa anto ekūpacāraṃ nāma. Tatthuppanno uddesalābho tasmiṃ
analyzed: nānā gharam imesam vasena veditabbo tattha yam eka kulassa gharam eka vaḷañjam  hoti tam suppapāta paricchedassa antar ekūpacāram nāma tattha uppannaḥ uddesa lābho tasmin
translated: several houses, several perambulations.” Herein, a house that is the property of one family and is surrounded by one wall

original: upacāre bhikkhācāravattenapi ṭhitānaṃ sabbesaṃ pāpuṇāti, etaṃ “ekaṃ gharaṃ ekūpacāraṃ” nāma.
analyzed: upacāre bhikkhā cāra vattena api ṭhitānam sabbesam pāpuṇāti etam ekam gharam ekūpacāram nāma
translated: is called “one house, one perambulation.” The learning that has arisen there is shared by all who are staying there even though they go on their alms round in different directions. This is called “one house, one perambulation.”

original: Yaṃ pana ekaṃ gharaṃ dvinnaṃ bhariyānaṃ sukhavihāratthāya majjhe bhittiṃ uṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: yam pana ekam gharam dvinnam bhariyānam sukha vihāra atthāya majjhe bhittim uṭṭhāpetvā
translated: But when a house is divided by a partition wall in the middle for the purpose of giving separate accommodation to two wives,

original: nānādvāravaḷañjaṃ kataṃ, tatthuppanno uddesalābho bhittiantarikassa na pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: nānā dvāra vaḷañjam katam tattha uppannaḥ uddesa lābhaḥ bhitti antarikassa na pāpuṇāti
translated: the learning that has arisen there does not belong to the space inside the partition wall.

original: tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne nisinnasseva pāpuṇāti, etaṃ “ekaṃ gharaṃ nānūpacāraṃ” nāma.
analyzed: tasmim tasmim ṭhāne nisinnassa iva pāpuṇāti etam ekam gharam nānūpacāram nāma
translated: It belongs only to the one who is sitting in that place. This is called “one house, several perambulations.”

original: Yasmiṃ pana ghare bahū bhikkhū nimantetvā antogehato paṭṭhāya ekābaddhe katvā paṭivissakagharānipi
analyzed: yasmin pana ghare bahū bhikkhū nimantetvā antogehataḥ paṭṭhāya ekābaddhe katvā paṭivissaka gharāni pi
translated: But if in a house many monks have been invited and they are seated in a continuous line from the inner door on, filling the house,

original: pūretvā nisīdāpenti, tatthuppanno uddesalābho sabbesaṃ pāpuṇāti. Yampi nānākulassa
analyzed: pūretvā tattha uppannaḥ uddesa lābhaḥ sabbesam pāpuṇāti yam pi nānā kulassa
translated: the recitation reward that arises there belongs to all of them. And if a house belongs to a number of families

original: nivesanaṃ majjhe bhittiṃ akatvā ekadvāreneva vaḷañjanti, tatrāpi eseva nayo. Etaṃ
analyzed: nivesanam majjhe bhittim a katvā eka dvārena iva vaḷañjanti tatra api esā iva
translated: and there is no partition wall in the middle but it has only one door, the same rule applies. This is called

original: “nānāgharaṃ ekūpacāraṃ” nāma.🔽Yo pana nānānivesanesu nisinnānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ uddesalābho uppajjati, kiñcāpi bhitticchiddena
analyzed: nānā gharam ekūpacāram nāma  yaḥ pana nānā nivesanesu nisinnānam bhikkhūnam uddesa lābhaḥ uppajjati kiñcā api bhitti chiddena
translated: “a house with one means of access.”

original: bhikkhū dissanti, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ nivesane nisinnānaṃyeva pāpuṇāti, etaṃ “nānāgharaṃ nānūpacāraṃ” nāma.🔽Yo pana gāmadvāravīthicatukkesu aññatarasmiṃ ṭhāne uddesabhattaṃ labhitvā aññasmiṃ
analyzed: bhikkhū dissanti tasmim tasmim nivesane nisinnānam yeva pāpuṇāti etam nānāgharam nānūpacāram nāma  yaḥ pana gāma dvāra vīthi catukkesu aññatarasmiṃ ṭhāne uddesa bhattam labhitvā aññasmiṃ
translated: But if a recitation reward arises for monks seated in different houses, even if the monks can be seen through a hole in the partition wall, it belongs only to those seated in each house. This is called🔽“a house with several means of access.”

original: bhikkhusmiṃ asati attanova pāpuṇāpetvā dutiyadivasepi tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne aññaṃ labhati,
analyzed: bhikkhusmim asati attanā uva pāpuṇāpetvā dutiya divase pi tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne aññam labhati
translated: But if a monk gets a recitation reward at a place such as a village gate, a street, or a crossroads, and if there is no other monk, he may have it brought to him; and if he gets another on the following day at the same place,

original: tena yaṃ aññaṃ navakaṃ vā vuḍḍhaṃ vā bhikkhuṃ passati, tassa gāhetabbaṃ. Sace koci
analyzed: tena yam aññam navakam vā vuḍḍham vā bhikkhum passati tassa gāhetabbam sace koci
translated: So if he sees another monk, whether junior or senior, he should get it from him. If there is no one else,

original: natthi, attanova pāpetvā bhuñjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: na atthi attanā iva pāpetvā bhuñjitabbam
translated: he should get it himself and then eat.

original: Sace āsanasālāya nisīditvā kālaṃ paṭimānentesu bhikkhūsu koci āgantvā “saṅghuddesapattaṃ
analyzed: sace āsanasālāya nisīditvā kālam paṭimānentesu bhikkhūsu koci āgantvā saṅghuddesa pattaṃ
translated: If, while the monks are sitting in the meal hall waiting for the right time, someone comes and says,

original: detha, uddesapattaṃ detha, saṅghato uddisitvā pattaṃ detha, saṅghikaṃ pattaṃ dethā”ti🔽vā vadati, uddesapattaṃ ṭhitikāya gāhetvā dātabbaṃ. “Saṅghuddesabhikkhuṃ detha, saṅghato
analyzed: detha uddesa pattam detha saṅghataḥ uddisitvā pattam detha saṅghikam pattam detha ati  vā vadati uddesa pattam ṭhitikāya gāhetvā dātabbam saṅgha uddesa bhikkhum detha saṅghato
translated: “Give me the bowl for the recitation of the Monastic Code,” “Give me the bowl for the recitation,” “Give me the bowl that has been designated by the Sangha,” or “Give me the communal bowl,”

original: uddisitvā bhikkhuṃ detha, saṅghikaṃ bhikkhuṃ dethā”ti vuttepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: uddisitvā bhikkhum detha saṅghikam bhikkhum detha ati vutte pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: he should take the bowl for the recitation of the Monastic Code and give it to him. If someone says, “Give me the monk for the recitation of the Monastic Code,” “Give me the monk who has been designated by the Sangha,” or “Give me the communal monk,” the procedure is the same.

original: Uddesako panettha pesalo lajjī medhāvī icchitabbo, tena tikkhattuṃ ṭhitikaṃ pucchitvā
analyzed: uddesakaḥ pana ittha pesalaḥ lajjī medhāvī icchitabbo tena tikkhattum ṭhitikam pucchitvā
translated: But the monk who recites the Monastic Code should be competent, conscientious, and intelligent. He should ask about the bowl for the recitation of the Monastic Code three times.

original: sace koci ṭhitikaṃ jānanto natthi, therāsanato gāhetabbaṃ. Sace pana “ahaṃ jānāmi,
analyzed: sace koci ṭhitikam jānantaḥ na atthi thera āsanato gāhetabbam sace pana aham jānāmi
translated: If no one knows about it, he should get it from the seniormost monk present. But if someone says,

original: dasavassena laddha”nti koci bhaṇati, “atthāvuso, dasavassā bhikkhū”ti pucchitabbaṃ.🔽Sace tassa sutvā “dasavassamha dasavassamhā”ti bahū āgacchanti, “tuyhaṃ pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: dasa vassena laddhanti koci bhaṇati attha āvuso dasa vassā bhikkhū iti pucchitabbam  sace tassa sutvā dasa vassamha dasa vassamha ati bahū āgacchanti tuyham pāpuṇāti
translated: If someone says, “I’ve been given by one who has ten years of seniority,” he should be asked, “Are there monks who have ten years of seniority?”

original: tuyhaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti avatvā “sabbe appasaddā hothā”ti vatvā paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapetabbā.🔽Ṭhapetvā “kati icchathā”ti upāsako pucchitabbo. “Ettake nāma, bhante, bhikkhū”ti
analyzed: tuyham pāpuṇāti iti a vatvā sabbe appasaddāḥ hotha ati vatvā paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapetabbā  ṭhapetvā kati icchatha ati upāsako pucchitabbo ettake nāma bhante bhikkhū ti
translated: If, after hearing this, many come saying, “I have ten years of seniority,” “You’re entitled,” “You’re entitled,” he should say, “Be quiet, all of you,” and he should then line them up in order of seniority.🔽After lining them up, he should ask the lay follower, “How many do you want?”

original: vutte “tuyhaṃ pāpuṇāti, tuyhaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti avatvā sabbanavakassa vassaggañca utu
analyzed: vutte tuyham pāpuṇāti tuyham pāpuṇāti iti avatvā sabbanavakassa vassaggam ca utu
translated: If the lay follower says, “Sir, there are so many monks,” he should not say, “You’re entitled,” “You’re entitled,” but should ask about the seniority, the season,

original: ca divasabhāgo ca chāyā ca pucchitabbā. Sace chāyāyapi pucchiyamānāya añño vuḍḍhataro
analyzed: ca divasa bhāgaḥ ca chāyā ca pucchitabbā sace pucchiyamānāya aññaḥ vuḍḍhataro
translated: the day, and the shadow of the most junior monk. If, while he is asking about the shadow, someone more senior

original: āgacchati, tassa dātabbaṃ. Atha chāyaṃ pucchitvā “tuyhaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti vutte vuḍḍhataro
analyzed: āgacchati tassa dātabbam atha chāyam pucchitvā tuyham pāpuṇāti iti vutte vuḍḍhataraḥ
translated: arrives, he should be given. But if, after asking about the shadow and saying, “You’re entitled,” someone more senior

original: āgacchati, na labhati. Kathāpapañcena hi nisinnassāpi niddāyantassāpi gāhitaṃ suggāhitaṃ,
analyzed: āgacchati na labhati kathā papañcena hi nisinnassa api niddāyantassa api gāhitam su gāhitam
translated: arrives, he is not entitled. For what is given while one is sitting and talking idly or while one is asleep is well given.

original: atikkantaṃ suatikkantaṃ, bhājanīyabhaṇḍañhi nāmetaṃ sampattasseva pāpuṇāti, tattha
analyzed: atikkantam su atikkantam bhājanīya bhaṇḍam hi nāma etam sampattassa iva pāpuṇāti tattha
translated: It is well surpassed, for this is not a thing to be shared out. It is only for one who has arrived. Herein,

original: sampattabhāvo upacārena paricchinditabbo. Āsanasālāya ca antoparikkhepo upacāro,
analyzed: sampatta bhāvaḥ upacārena paricchinditabbaḥ āsana sālāya ca anta parikkhepaḥ upacāro
translated: the state of having arrived is to be defined by the extent of the access. And the extent of the access in the case of the assembly hall is the inside of the surrounding wall.

original: tasmiṃ ṭhitassa lābho pāpuṇātīti.
analyzed: tasmin ṭhitassa lābho pāpuṇāti iti
translated: The gain belongs to one who is standing there.

original: Koci āsanasālato aṭṭha uddesapatte āharāpetvā satta patte paṇītabhojanānaṃ ekaṃ udakassa
analyzed: koci āsana sālato aṭṭha uddesa patte āharāpetvā satta patte paṇīta bhojanānaṃ ekam udakassa
translated: Someone has seven serving-bowls brought from the assembly hall, fills one of them with fine food and the other six with water,

original: pūretvā āsanasālāyaṃ pahiṇāti, gahetvā āgatā kiñci avatvā bhikkhūnaṃ hatthesu patiṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: pūretvā āsana sālāyam pahiṇāti gahetvā āgatā kiñci avatvā bhikkhūnam hatthesu patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: and sends them to the assembly hall. When they have been brought, they stand without being announced in the hands of the bhikkhus.

original: pakkamanti. Yena yaṃ laddhaṃ, tasseva taṃ hoti. Yena pana udakaṃ laddhaṃ, tassa atikkantampi🔽ṭhitikaṃ ṭhapetvā aññaṃ uddesabhattaṃ gāhetabbaṃ. Tañca lūkhaṃ vā labhatu paṇītaṃ
analyzed: pakkamanti yena yam laddham tassa iva tam hoti yena pana udakam laddham tassa atikkantam pi  ṭhitikam ṭhapetvā aññam uddesa bhattam gāhetabbam tat ca lūkham vā labhatu paṇītam
translated: What is got by each one belongs to him. But if anyone gets water, he should get another serving-bowl from the store,

original: vā ticīvaraparivāraṃ vā, tassevetaṃ. Īdiso hissa puññaviseso. Udakaṃ pana yasmā āmisaṃ
analyzed: vā ti cīvara parivāram vā tassa iva etam īdisaḥ hissa puñña visesaḥ udakam pana yasmai āmisam
translated: and he can have that, whether it is coarse or fine, and also the three robes to go with it. For this is the special merit of one who has arrived.

original: na hoti, tasmā aññaṃ uddesabhattaṃ labbhati.
analyzed: na hoti tasmai aññam uddesa bhattam labbhati
translated: But since water is not a material support, another serving-bowl can be got from the store.

original: Sace pana te gahetvā āgatā “idaṃ kira bhante sabbaṃ bhājetvā bhuñjathā”ti vatvā gacchanti,
analyzed: sace pana te gahetvā āgatāḥ idam kira bhante sabbam bhājetvā bhuñjatha ati vatvā gacchanti
translated: But if they have brought it themselves, saying, “Venerable sirs, please share out this and eat it,”

original: sabbehi bhājetvā bhuñjitvā udakaṃ pātabbaṃ. Saṅghato uddisitvā “aṭṭha mahāthere detha,
analyzed: sabbehi bhājetvā bhuñjitvā udakam pātabbam saṅghataḥ uddisitvā aṭṭha mahā there detha
translated: then it should be shared out by all and eaten. If they say, “Give it to the eight chief elders,”

original: majjhime detha, navake detha, paripuṇṇavassasāmaṇere detha, majjhimabhāṇakādayo detha,
analyzed: majjhime detha navake detha paripuṇṇa vassa sāmaṇere detha majjhima bhāṇaka ādayaḥ detha
translated: “Give it to the middle ones,” “Give it to the new bhikkhus,” “Give it to the novices who have completed ten years,” “Give it to the reciters of the Dīgha Nikāya, etc.,”

original: mayhaṃ ñātibhikkhū dethā”ti vadantassa pana “upāsaka, tvaṃ evaṃ vadasi, ṭhitikāya🔽pana tesaṃ na pāpuṇātī”ti vatvā ṭhitikāvaseneva dātabbā. Daharasāmaṇerehi pana uddesabhattesu
analyzed: mayham ñāti bhikkhū detha iti vadantassa pana upāsaka tvam evam vadasi ṭhitikāya  pana tesam na pāpuṇāti iti vatvā ṭhitikā vasena iva dātabbā dahara sāmaṇerehi pana uddesa bhattesu
translated: “Give it to my relations,” then they should be told, “Lay follower, you say this, but it does not come to pass.🔽It is given according to seniority,” and it should be distributed according to seniority.🔽But if the novices get a meal by invitation,

original: laddhesu sace dāyakānaṃ ghare maṅgalaṃ hoti, “tumhākaṃ ācariyupajjhāye pesethā”ti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: laddhesu sace dāyakānam ghare maṅgalam hoti tumhākam ācariya upajjhāye pesetha ati vattabbam
translated: if there is a festival in the donors’ house, they should be told, “Send for your teachers and preceptors.”

original: Yasmiṃ pana uddesabhatte paṭhamabhāgo sāmaṇerānaṃ pāpuṇāti, anubhāgo mahātherānaṃ,
analyzed: yasmin pana uddesa bhatte paṭhama bhāgaḥ sāmaṇerānam pāpuṇāti anubhāgaḥ mahātherānam
translated: But if in a meal by invitation the first portion goes to the novices and the second portion to the chief elders,

original: na tattha sāmaṇerā “mayaṃ paṭhamabhāgaṃ labhimhā”ti purato gantuṃ labhanti, yathāpaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: na tattha sāmaṇerāḥ mayam paṭhama bhāgam labhimha ati puratas gantum labhanti yathā paṭipāṭiyā
translated: The novices are not allowed to go in front, thinking, “We get the first portion.”

original: eva gantabbaṃ. “Saṅghato uddisitvā ‘tumhe ethā’ti vutte ‘mayhaṃ aññadāpi jānissasi,
analyzed: eva gantabbam saṅghataḥ uddisitvā tumhe etha ati vutte mayham aññadā api jānissasi
translated: They should go in order. If the novice monk is told, “You go, having been appointed by the Sangha,” he should say, “I’ll know another time.

original: ṭhitikā pana evaṃ gacchatī”’ti ṭhitikāvaseneva gāhetabbaṃ. Atha “saṅghuddesapattaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitikā pana evam gacchati iti ṭhitikā vasena iva gāhetabbam atha saṅgha uddesa pattam
translated: The one who is staying here is going.” He should be taken along as the one who is staying there. If it is said, “Give the bowl of the one who is appointed by the Sangha,”

original: dethā”ti vatvā agāhiteyeva patte yassa kassaci pattaṃ gahetvā pūretvā āharati, āhaṭampi
analyzed: detha iti vatvā patte yassa kassaci pattam gahetvā pūretvā āharati
translated: and if the bowl is taken from anyone at all, filled with food, and brought back, even though it has been brought back,

original: ṭhitikāya eva gāhetabbaṃ.🔽Eko “saṅghuddesapattaṃ āharā”ti pesito “bhante, ekaṃ pattaṃ detha, nimantanabhattaṃ🔽āharissāmī”ti vadati, so ce uddesabhattagharato ayaṃ āgatoti ñatvā bhikkhūhi “nanu
analyzed: ṭhitikāya eva gāhetabbam  ekaḥ saṅgha uddesa pattam āharāti pesitaḥ bhante ekam pattam detha nimantana bhattam  āharissāmi iti vadati saḥ ce uddesa bhatta gharataḥ ayam āgataḥ iti ñatvā bhikkhūhi nanu
translated: it should be taken by the one who is staying there.🔽If one person is sent, saying, “Bring the bowl of the one who is appointed by the Sangha,” and he says, “Venerables, give me a bowl. I’ll bring back a meal by invitation,”

original: tvaṃ asukagharato āgato”ti vutto “āma, bhante, na nimantanabhattaṃ, uddesabhatta”nti
analyzed: tvam asuka gharataḥ āgataḥ ti vuttaḥ āma bhante na nimantana bhattam uddesa bhattam ti
translated: and if he is recognized as having come from the house where the meal appointed by the Sangha is to be given, and if the monks say to him, “Didn’t you come from such-and-such a house?” and he replies, “Yes, Venerables, it wasn’t a meal by invitation, it was a meal appointed by the Sangha,”

original: bhaṇati, ṭhitikāya gahetabbaṃ. Yo pana “ekaṃ pattaṃ āharā”ti vutto “‘ki’nti vatvā
analyzed: bhaṇati ṭhitikāya gahetabbam yaḥ pana ekam pattam āharāti vuttaḥ kinti vatvā
translated: If he says, “I’ll take it for the sake of keeping it,” he should be told, “Bring a bowl.”🔽If he says, “What?”

original: āharāmī”ti vatvā “yathā te ruccatī”ti vutto āgacchati, ayaṃ vissaṭṭhadūto nāma. Uddesapattaṃ
analyzed: āharāmi iti vatvā yathā te ruccati iti vuttaḥ āgacchati ayam vissaṭṭhadūtaḥ nāma uddesa pattam
translated: If he says, “Take it,” it should be taken. But if he says, “Bring a bowl,” and the messenger replies, “What?” and the first monk says, “Bring it,” and the messenger replies, “As you say,” and then comes back, this is called a messenger who is not properly dismissed.

original: vā paṭipāṭipattaṃ vā puggalikapattaṃ vā yaṃ icchati, taṃ tassa dātabbaṃ. Eko bālo🔽abyatto “uddesapattaṃ āharā”ti pesito vattuṃ na jānāti, tuṇhībhūto tiṭṭhati, so “kassa
analyzed: vā paṭipāṭi pattam vā puggalika pattam vā yam icchati tam tassa dātabbam ekaḥ bālaḥ  abyattaḥ uddesa pattam āharāti pesitaḥ vattum na jānāti tuṇhībhūto tiṭṭhati so kassa
translated: The bowl that is to be given to him is either the bowl for the recitation, the bowl for the row, or a personal bowl.

original: santikaṃ āgatosī”ti vā “kassa pattaṃ harissasī”ti vā na vattabbo. Evañhi vutto pucchāsabhāgena
analyzed: santikam āgataḥ asi iti vā kassa pattam harissasi iti vā na vattabbaḥ evam hi vuttaḥ pucchā sabhāgena
translated: There was a certain foolish and inexperienced monk who, when sent to fetch the bowl for the recitation, did not know how to speak. He just stood there in silence. He should not be asked, “From whom did you come?” or “Whose bowl will you bring?”

original: “tumhākaṃ santikaṃ āgatomhī”ti “tumhākaṃ pattaṃ harissāmī”ti vā vadeyya, tato taṃ
analyzed: tumhākam santikam āgataḥ asmi iti tumhākam pattam harissāmi iti vā vadeyya tatas tam
translated: For if he is asked, he will reply in the manner of a question, “I have come from you,” or “I will bring your bowl.”

original: bhikkhuṃ aññe bhikkhū jigucchantā na olokeyyuṃ. “Kuhiṃ gacchasi, kiṃ karonto āhiṇḍasī”ti
analyzed: bhikkhum aññe bhikkhū jigucchantā na olokeyyum kuhim gacchasi kim karontaḥ āhiṇḍasi iti
translated: Other monks would then look down on him, thinking, “He is a thief.” He should be asked, “Where are you going? What are you looking for?”

original: pana vattabbo. Tassa “uddesapattatthāya āgatomhī”ti vadantassa gāhetvā patto dātabbo.
analyzed: pana vattabbo tassa uddesa patta tthāya āgataḥ ahi iti vadantassa gāhetvā pattaḥ dātabbo
translated: If he replies, “I have come to fetch the bowl for the recitation,” the bowl should be given to him after taking it.

original: Ekā kūṭaṭṭhitikā nāma hoti. Rañño vā hi rājamahāmattassa vā gehe atipaṇītāni aṭṭha
analyzed: ekā kūṭaṭṭhitikā nāma hoti raññaḥ vā hi rāja mahāmattassa vā gehe atipaṇītāni aṭṭha
translated: One is called “fixed on a day.”
